https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: CHEM 1330 and CH_ENG 3261 or their equivalents, or instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with CH_ENG 4464). The course covers the scientific and technological knowledge of electrochemical processes. It deals with fundamental principles relevant to electrochemical engineering (e.g., reaction kinetics, thermodynamics, and transport phenomena). Case studies would include, for example, electrochemical synthesis, electrocatalysis, and energy conversion and storage (e.g., batteries and fuel cells).  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Synthesis and Design of Chemical Process
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: CH_ENG 3262, CH_ENG 4363, CH_ENG 4385; C- or better in ENGLSH 1000Recommended: CH_ENG 4370 or concurrent enrollment
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with CH_ENG 4980). This is a heuristics-based design course intended to assist students in bringing together capabilities from previous course.  An emphasis is placed on the creation process of design.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Advanced Heat and Momentum Transfer
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Advanced study of these transport phenomena.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Analysis of Equilibrium Stage Processes
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Advanced study of stage processes.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Advanced Chemical Engineering Thermodynamics I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: An advanced course on chemical thermodynamics emphasizing the mathematical and physical foundations of thermodynamics. Topics include the postulates of thermodynamics, thermodynamic potentials and the Legendre transformation, thermodynamic stability and metastability, critical phenomena, models of non-ideal phase and chemical reaction equilibria, adsorption, surface and interfacial equilibria, irreversible thermodynamics, and a brief introduction to statistical thermodynamics.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Advanced Chemical Engineering Thermodynamics II
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Introduction to the methods of statistical thermodynamics and statistical mechanics.  The method of ensembles, Maxwell-Boltzmann statistics, the kinetic theory of gases, and theories of liquids.  Applications of statistical mechanics to the prediction of physical and chemical properties such as rate coefficients, diffusion coefficients, and conductivities.  Graded A-F only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Chemical Reaction Engineering Science
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Phenomenological behavior of catalysts. Theoretical interpretations for heterogeneous and homogeneous catalysts.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Mathematical Studies of Chemical Engineering Operation
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Analytical methods applied to solution of chemical engineering problems.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Atoms and Molecules with Laboratory - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: One-semester introduction for non-science majors to the basic concepts and important applications of chemistry. Satisfies A&S requirement for a laboratory science. No credit if taken after CHEM 1000 or CHEM 1320.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: College Chemistry I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: MATH 1100. MATH 1050 is NOT an appropriate substitution for College Algebra
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: First of two-course sequence emphasizing principles and applications of modern chemical sciences.  Covers chemical nomenclature, stoichiometry, kinetic molecular theory, atomic structure, periodic properties, and molecular structure and bonding.  Satisfies laboratory science requirement.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: College Chemistry I - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: MATH 1100 or equivalent. Honors eligibility required. MATH 1050 does not satisfy the math requirement
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: First of a two-course sequence emphasizing principles and applications of modern chemical sciences. Covers chemical nomenclature, stoichiometry, kinetic molecular theory, atomic structure, periodic properties, and molecular structure and bonding. Satisfies laboratory science requirement. Math Reasoning Proficiency Course.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: College Chemistry II
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: grade of C- or better in CHEM 1320 or CHEM 1320H
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Continuation of CHEM 1320. Covers intermolecular forces, solutions, kinetics, acid-base chemistry, electrochemistry, nuclear chemistry, thermodynamics.  Satisfies requirement for a laboratory science.  May be taken concurrently with CHEM 2030 or CHEM 2100.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: College Chemistry II- Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: grade of C- or better in  CHEM 1320 or CHEM 1320H. Honors eligibility required
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Continuation of CHEM 1320H. Covers equilibria, kinetics, electrochemistry, nuclear chemistry, thermodynamics. Satisfies requirement for a laboratory science. May be taken concurrently with CHEM 2030 or CHEM 2100.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: College Chemistry I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: MATH 1100. MATH 1050 is NOT an appropriate substitution for College Algebra
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: First of two-course sequence emphasizing principles and applications of modern chemical sciences. Covers chemical nomenclature, stoichiometry, kinetic molecular theory, atomic structure, periodic properties, and molecular structure and bonding. Satisfies laboratory science requirement. No credit for CHEM 1320 and CHEM 1400/CHEM 1401.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: College Chemistry II
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Continuation of CHEM 1400. Covers intermolecular forces, solutions, kinetics, acid-base chemistry, electrochemistry, nuclear chemistry, thermodynamics. No credit for CHEM 1330 and CHEM 1410/CHEM 1411.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Survey of Organic Chemistry
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Grade of C- or better in CHEM 1320 or CHEM 1320H or equivalent. Recommended CHEM 1330, or CHEM 1330 concurrently
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: One-semester introduction to structure and bonding, functional group chemistry, principles of reactivity, reaction mechanisms, the molecules of life.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Organic Chemistry I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: grade of C- or better in CHEM 1320 or equivalent or CHEM 1330 concurrentlyRecommended: CHEM 1330
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: First course of a two-semester sequence. Structure and bonding; chemistry of hydrocarbons, alkyl halides, alcohols and ethers; reaction mechanisms; principles of reactivity and synthesis; IR and NMR spectroscopy.  Only 1 hour credit if taken after CHEM  2030 or equivalent.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Organic Chemistry I - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: grade of C- or better in CHEM 1320 or equivalent or CHEM 1330 concurrently; Honors eligibility requiredRecommended: CHEM 1330
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: First course of a two-semester sequence. Structure and bonding; chemistry of hydrocarbons, alkyl halides, alcohols and ethers; reaction mechanisms; principles of reactivity and synthesis; IR and NMR spectroscopy.  Only 1 hour credit if taken after CHEM  2030 or equivalent.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Organic Chemistry II
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: grade of C- or better in CHEM 2100 or equivalent, or departmental consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Continuation of CHEM 2100.  Aromatic hydrocarbons, carbonyls, amines; chemistry of carbanions; reactions of polar double bonds; nucleic acids, proteins, carbohydrates and fats.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Organic Chemistry II   - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: grade of C- or better in CHEM 2100 or equivalent, or departmental consent; Honors eligibility required
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Continuation of CHEM 2100.  Aromatic hydrocarbons, carbonyls, amines; chemistry of carbanions; reactions of polar double bonds; nucleic acids, proteins, carbohydrates and fats.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Organic Laboratory I - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Honors eligibility requiredRecommended: Concurrent enrollment in CHEM 2110 or CHEM 2030.  No credit for students who have previous organic laboratory credit
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Basic lab techniques, functional group manipulations, and short syntheses.  Pre-lab and post-lab writing assignments. 1 hour recitation,  3 hours lab per week.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Organic Laboratory II
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: grade of C- or better in CHEM 2110 and CHEM 2130 or equivalent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Continuation of CHEM 2130.  Preparation and identification of organic compounds; application of instrumental techniques.  2 lab sessions, 1 recitation session per week.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Honors Organic Chemistry II with Lab - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: honors eligibility, grade of B or better in CHEM 2160H or instructor's permission
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Continuation of CHEM 2160H; includes laboratory. Content and structure similar to  CHEM 2110, but with increased depth and breadth.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Fundamentals of Inorganic Chemistry with Lab
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: grade of C- or better in CHEM 2130
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: A systematic introduction with laboratory to inorganic and organometallic compounds, reactions, and periodic properties.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Quantitative Methods of Analysis with Lab
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Principles and practice of quantitative analysis, including the basic principles of modern instrumental methods.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Fundamentals of Physical Chemistry
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: MATH 1700, a course in organic chemistry; PHYSCS 1210 and PHYSCS 1220 or PHYSCS 2750, or PHYSCS 2760
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Survey of physical chemistry.  Satisfies physical chemistry prerequisite for BIOCHM 8430.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Undergraduate Seminar in Chemistry
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Methods for locating and presenting chemical information, data analysis techniques, professional issues.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Undergraduate Seminar in Chemistry - Writing Intensive
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Methods for locating and presenting chemical information, data analysis techniques, professional issues.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to Archaeological Chemistry
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: One of CHEM 1320 and/or CHEM 1330Recommended: ANTHRO 2020 or ANTHRO 2021
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as ANTHRO 3820). This course will introduce students to the field of archaeological science and its contributions to our knowledge of the human past. It will review current topics, recent advances, and major debates in the field, with emphasis on the applied analytical chemistry methods that are commonly used. It will cover methodologies including neutron activation analysis, mass spectrometry, X-ray fluorescence, and biomolecular approaches used in the study of ceramics, pigments, glass, metals, biominerals (bone, teeth, shell), and sediments relevant to archaeological and cultural heritage contexts. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Advanced Chemistry Laboratory
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: CHEM 2400, CHEM 2140, or CHEM 2190H, CHEM 3200, CHEM 4330 (or CHEM 4330 corequisite)
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Advanced methods for the synthesis and characterization of organic, inorganic, and organometallic compounds.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Intermediate Organic Chemistry
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: at least one year organic chemistry
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Stresses synthetic organic chemistry at an intermediate level.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Medicinal Chemistry
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Chemical mechanisms of drug action. Topics include drug metabolism and action, chemical toxicology and medicines, enzyme activity, and specific drug case studies.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Instrumental Methods of Analysis with Lab
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: CHEM 3200, a semester of physical chemistry
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with CHEM 7200). Chemical instrumentation methods including electrochemistry, spectroscopy, and advanced separations techniques.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Environmental Chemistry
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: 8 hours chemistry including organic and analytical
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Surveys the chemistry of air and water environments; discusses the chemistry of waste treatment.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Physical Chemistry I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: CHEM 2100, MATH 1700, and PHYSCS 1220 or PHYSCS 2760
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Lecture only. Topics include the kinetic theory of gases, chemical kinetics, thermodynamics and chemical equilibrium.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Physical Chemistry II
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: MATH 2300 or instructor approval. May be taken independently of CHEM 4310
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Lecture only. Covers wave mechanics, bonding, molecular spectroscopy and statistical mechanics.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Physical Chemistry II - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: MATH 2300 or instructor approval. May be taken independently of CHEM 4310. Honors eligibility required
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Covers wave mechanics, bonding, molecular spectroscopy and statistical mechanics.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Physical Chemistry Laboratory
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Grade of C- or better in  CHEM 3200; CHEM 4330 or CHEM 4330 concurrently
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course is intended to introduce the practice of experimental physical chemistry including applying the principles of thermodynamics, kinetics, and spectroscopy in experiments.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Inorganic Chemistry
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with CHEM 7400). Atomic and molecular structure, bonding, kinetics and mechanism, ligand field theory, coordination compounds, acids and bases.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Physics and Chemistry of Materials
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: PHYSCS 2750, CHEM 1320 or equivalent, or instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as NU_ENG 4319, PHYSCS 4190, BIOL_EN 4480; BME 4480; cross-leveled with CHEM 7490, NU_ENG 7319, PHYSCS 7190, BIOL_EN 7480). Physics and Chemistry of Materials is a 3 credit hours course offered every spring semester for students from Physics, Chemistry, Engineering and Medical Departments and consists of lectures, laboratory demonstrations, two mid-term and one final exam. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to Radiochemistry with Lab
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Introduces application of radio-tracer techniques to chemical research.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Chemistry Teaching Practicum
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Provides practical experience teaching introductory chemistry in discussion and laboratory settings.  For students pursuing dual degrees in chemistry and secondary education. For students pursuing simultaneous dual degrees in chemistry and secondary education. Graded on S/U basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Senior Research
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: A laboratory research project with approved written goals and a final written report. It may be taken twice.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Senior Honors Research I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: a 3.33 GPA, departmental consent, and approval of project outline. Honors eligibility required
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: A laboratory research experience with a student-instructor prepared outline approved by the Honors Director, a final written report and a final oral presentation and examination. May replace CHEM 4950 in ACS Certification Track or 4000+ level elective requirement for Medicinal Chemistry track. Must take CHEM 4990H and CHEM 4991H for departmental honors.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Senior Honors Research II
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: a 3.33 GPA, departmental consent, approval of project outline. Honors eligibility required
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: A laboratory research experience with a student-instructor prepared outline approved by the Honors Director, a final written report and a final oral presentation and examination.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Seminar in Chemistry for Beginning Graduate Students
Instrumental Methods of Analysis with Lab
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: CHEM 3200, a semester of physical chemistry
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with CHEM 4200). Chemical instrumentation methods including electrochemistry, spectroscopy, and advanced separations techniques.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Intermediate Physical Chemistry
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Treatment of atomic and molecular, structure and spectroscopy based on quantum concepts. Designed to provide a broad base of knowledge in these fundamental areas to beginning graduate students in chemistry.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Inorganic Chemistry
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with CHEM 4400). Atomic and molecular structure, bonding, kinetics and mechanism, ligand field theory, coordination compounds, acids and bases.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Physics and Chemistry of Materials
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: PHYSCS 2750, CHEM 1320 or equivalent, or instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as NU_ENG 7319, PHYSCS 7190, BIOL_EN 7480; cross-leveled with CHEM 4490, NU_ENG 4319, PHYSCS 4190, BIOL_EN 4480, BME 4480). Physics and Chemistry of Materials is a 3 credit hours course offered every spring semester for students from Physics, Chemistry, Engineering and Medical Departments and consists of lectures, laboratory demonstrations, two mid-term and one final exam. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Organic Reaction Mechanisms
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: 1 year of Organic Chemistry and Physical Chemistry
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Organic reaction mechanisms are discussed within a framework of structure-reactivity relationships. Particular attention directed to the chemistry of reactive intermediates and the application of stereochemical and molecular orbital concepts.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Organic Spectroscopy
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: CHEM 4330 or equivalent or instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Structural analysis of organic compounds involving problem solving using modern NMR, IR, UV-VIS, MS CD/ORD and other spectroscopic techniques.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Applications of the Reactions of Organic Chemistry
Quantum Chemistry
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: CHEM 4330 or equivalent or instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Introduction to formal quantum mechanical theory, quantum measurement, simple model problems having exact solutions, angular momenta, approximation methods (perturbation theory, variation principle, WKB), and the structure of many-electron atoms.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Chemical Kinetics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: CHEM 4330 or equivalent or instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Factors affecting rates, orders and mechanisms of chemical reactions, with emphasis on current theories and experimental techniques.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Computational Chemistry
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: CHEM 3300 or equivalent or instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Theory and application of modern computational techniques (molecular mechanics, ab initio and semiempirical molecular orbital methods) for predicting the structures, energies, and properties of molecules and molecular systems.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Statistical Mechanics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: CHEM 4330 or equivalent or instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Principles of statistical mechanics and their application to chemical systems; ensemble theory; condensed phases.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Atomic-Scale Simulations
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course will provide an in-depth introduction to the methods and applications of atomic-scale simulation methods (mainly classical molecular dynamics, hereafter "MD") for graduate students in chemistry, physics, materials science, and engineering. One of the beauties of MD methods is that, if applied judiciously and with skill, they provide exquisitely high-fidelity information about the fundamental properties and processes that occur on time scales ranging from femtoseconds to nanoseconds (or longer) and space scales ranging from Ångstroms to approximately microns. In many cases, this information can be used to guide or assess theoretical developments, interpret experiments, or provide insights or predictions for thermodynamic or non-equilibrium states that are not easily achieved or are difficult to probe experimentally. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to Astrochemistry
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Introduction to Astrochemistry is a graduate-level course covering the chemistry and physics which gave rise to the Modern Universe, as well as that which currently governs the way in which new species are formed, destroyed, and measured.  We examine the events that immediately followed the Big Bang, the vast interstellar medium, Solar system and planet formation, and the number of routes by which complex organic molecules form. Throughout this course, it will be clear that the Universe, though largely inhospitable, is host to a rich chemistry that gave rise to life as we know it.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Chemistry of the Main Group Elements
Supramolecular Chemistry
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: BS in Chemistry, Biochemistry or Chemical Engineering
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: The basics of supramolecular chemistry will be covered, including host-guest complexes, reorganization, complementarily, thermodynamic interactions, self assembly and biochemical, molecular device and crystal engineering applications. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Coordination Chemistry and Reactivity
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: CHEM 4400 or equivalent; graduate standing in chemistry or instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: The chemistry of the transition elements (d-block) and their reactivity will be discussed, including bonding, coordination numbers, oxidation states, and reactivity (kinetics).  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Advanced Radiochemistry
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Reviews current advances in radiochemistry, hot atom chemistry, radiation chemistry, nuclear spectrometry.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Radiopharmaceutical Chemistry
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: undergraduate organic and inorganic chemistry; graduate standing in chemistry or instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: The radiotracer concept, history of nuclear medicine, radionuclide production, organic and inorganic chemistry of radiopharmaceutical chemistry, and applications will be discussed.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Springfield Child Health Clerkship
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Successful completion of the first two years of medical school
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Students have the opportunity to learn about common illnesses and abnormalities in children. Emphasis also is placed on the importance of preventive and developmental aspects of child care. Lectures and case presentations correlate with the clinical experiences.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: SCC Pediatric Intensive Care
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Successful completion of 5 of the 7 core clerkships. One of the 5 must be the Child Health clerkship. CH_HTH 6000, CH_HTH 6010, CH_HTH 6020, or CH_HTH 6100
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Student will learn the initial approach and daily management of children requiring care in the Pediatric Intensive Care Unit. Students will learn the evaluation of and the management of critically ill or injured children focusing on airway and pulmonary physiology, cardiac physiology, neurological diseases, traumatic injuries, acute overdoses, endocrine emergencies, basic fluid management, and the medically complex child. Pharmacologic and nutritional management of the critically ill or injured child will also be reviewed.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: SCC Neonatal Intensive Care Unit Selective
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Successful completion of 5 of the 7 core clerkships. One of the 5 must be Child Health clerkship
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Students will gain experience in the evaluation, diagnosis, and management of sick newborns, and in the performance of specialized procedures necessary for ICU care.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Springfield Pediatric Endocrinology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Successful completion of the first two years of medical school. Completion of M3 CH clerkship suggested but not required
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This rotation is primarily an outpatient experience, though the student may be asked to do inpatient consultations with the attending physician. This elective will present an in-depth experience of diabetes/endocrinology as a subspecialty, including but not limited to exposure to disorders in growth and puberty, obesity, abnormalities in thyroid function, and managing blood glucose levels in patients with type 1 diabetes. Additional teaching methods used may include mini-lectures and readings relevant to this subspecialty.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Remediation Child Health Clerkship
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: CH_HTH 6000 Child Health Clerkship, received unsatisfactory grade
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Enrolled students are those who received an unsatisfactory grade in a Child Health Clerkship at any Mizzou Med location or site. This course gives them the opportunity to rectify a deficiency.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Re-Remediation of Child Health Clerkship
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: First two years of medical school
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Re-Remediation of Child Health Clerkship.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Remediation of Springfield Child Health Clerkship
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Successful completion of the first two years of medical school
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Students have the opportunity to learn about common illnesses and abnormalities in children. Emphasis also is placed on the importance of preventive and developmental aspects of child care. Lectures and case presentations correlate with the clinical experiences.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Advanced Biomedical Science Medicine Problem Premature Infant
ABS Child Health Research and Review
Child Health Genetics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Goals/Objectives:  To develop an understanding of medical genetics, including genetic diagnosis, cytogenetics, metabolic genetic diseases, teratology, and the genetics literature, and computer databases. CURRICULUM: During the block, each student will see patients in consultation and in the genetics clinics (general genetics, metabolic, PKU, autism, Down Syndrome, outreach) where they will work up the patients and prepare a report and discussion of the diagnosis or diagnostic differential. Each student will also prepare a literature review around a specific patient or problem. For interested students, cytogenetics or metabolic problems are available.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Pediatric Diabetes and Endocrinology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Goals/Objectives:   1)   To understand the pathophysiology of endocrine and metabolic diseases in childhood.   2)   To understand the fundamentals of growth processes in infancy, childhood, and adolescence.     CURRICULUM:    The Department of Child Health has a large patient care and research program for children with diabetes mellitus.    In addition, the Department has a busy general endocrinology program.   Thus, students on the elective can participate in the care of patients with a wide spectrum of endocrine and metabolic diseases.    Students can carry out specific clinical or laboratory projects relating to specific aspects of either diabetes or endocrine disease, deepen their understanding of pathophysiology of disease and gain a better understanding of the impact of a chronic disorder on the child and his/her family.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Pediatric Cardiology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Goals/Objectives:  Clinical and laboratory material is available to achieve the following objectives:     1) Develop skills in auscultation, resuscitation, treatment of congestive heart failure, and recognition of congenital heart disease in infants.    2) Adequate exposure to pediatric electrocardiography, echocardiography, cineangiography, and interpretation of cardiac catheterization data.    3) Proficiency in the management of postoperative cardio-vascular patients.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Pediatric Pulmonology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Goals/Objectives:  To gain experience in the treatment of asthma, bronchopulmonary dysplasia, cystic fibrosis, sleep disorders, and other respiratory diseases and to learn about pulmonary function testing in children.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Pediatric Gastroenterology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Goals/Objectives:   1)   Gain experience in GI diseases of children noting the difference and similarities with adult diseases.   2)   To introduce the student to some of the most commonly encountered diagnoses in pediatrics and to its management.  3) To learn to focus on physical diagnosis skills.     CURRICULUM:    Preceptorship with a pediatric subspecialist for four weeks will include inpatient and outpatient service activities.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Child Adolescent Medicine
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Goals/Objectives:  To teach 4th year students the intricacies of care of the adolescent patient.  Specifically, the rotation will address the adolescent interview, important considerations in the adolescent "check-up", and managing the varied problems in adolescents, from attention deficit disorder to eating disorders and gynecological issues.  The student will leave the rotation with a better understanding of the care of adolescents.    CURRICULUM:  These objectives will be met in the following manner:   1)  Student will actively participate in adolescent medicine clinic with both clinical attendings.  He/she will be responsible for the initial evaluation of the patients in the clinic, will actively participate in clinical decision-making, and will be responsible for helping  with patient write-ups and referral letters (at the discretion of the attending).  The student will be expected to function on an extern level, following up on laboratory evaluations and checking in with patients seen, when needed.   2) The student will participate in the adolescent interview practice sessions with the interact teen theatre with the residents on the rotation.  This process will help to improve interviewing skills with adolescents.   3) The student will be responsible for helping with any inpatient care, including consultations and/or admissions.   4) The student will be asked to identify particular areas of interest to be used as topics for interactive discussion with one of the attendings or for a short paper.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Ped Renal and Rheumatology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: 3rd year Pediatrics/Child Health or Internal Medicine rotation
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: 4th year elective for renal/rheumatology rotation, four weeks.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Child Health Rural Elective
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: CH_HTH 6000; restricted to medical students only
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Students will enhance their knowledge about patient-centered care of children through active participation in a primarily outpatient clinical experience.  Limited inpatient experience may be offered as well.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: General Child Health - Inpatient
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Goals/Objectives:  To provide additional experience in general pediatrics in inpatient care.   CURRICULUM:   The student will function as a member of the house staff team assuming many of the roles of the first year resident in patient care.  This includes working up of patient's management plans, rounding, staffing, conferences, etc.  Night coverage with supervision is included.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: General Child Health - Outpatient
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Goals/Objectives:  To provide additional experience in general pediatrics in outpatient care.    CURRICULUM:  The student will function as a member of the healthcare team.   This includes taking histories, performing physical exams, and working up patient management plans.  This may require working evening clinic and Saturday clinic in addition to regular daytime clinics.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Neonatology/Neonatal Intensive Care Unit
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Goals/Objectives:  To gain experience:  1) in the evaluation, diagnosis, and management of sick newborns, and  2) in the performance of specialized procedures necessary for ICU care.        CURRICULUM:   The student will function as a first-year house officer, with his/her own neonatal ICU patients for initial work-up and management, under the supervision of the PL-2 or PL-3 and attending staff. (rotation at Columbia Regional Hospital)

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Pediatric Intensive Care Unit
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Goals/Objectives:   1)  To provide the student with the initial approach and management of children requiring care in the Pediatric Intensive Care Unit.    2)  To provide the student with the basics of airway management in children.    3)   To provide the student with an understanding of the preoperative assessment with preparation of pediatric patients.    4)    To provide the student with an introduction to the perioperative management of common pediatric surgical problems.     CURRICULUM:   Students in this elective will spend time in both the Pediatric ICU and the operating rooms.   They will be required to participate in daily rounds in the PICU and follow the medical/surgical patients admitted to the PICU.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Springfield Pediatric Neurology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Successful completion of 5 of the 7 core clerkships. Three of the 5 must be Child Health clerkship, Psychiatry clerkship and Neurology clerkships
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Management of common pediatric neurology issues such as: episodic/ paroxysmal disorders, seizures, headaches, developmental delay, cerebral palsy, muscle disorders, etc.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to Adolescent Medicine
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Successful completion of the first two years of medical school
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: The rotation is primarily an outpatient experience, though the student may be asked to do inpatient consultations with the attending physician on service. In addition to learning and practicing primary care of adolescent patients the elective will present an in-depth experience of adolescent medicine as a subspecialty, including, but not limited to, conditions such as eating disorders, disorders of puberty and menstruation, obesity, ADHD, and substance abuse. Additional teaching methods used include a pre-post test, lectures, and readings relevant to adolescent medicine.  Completion of the Child Health Clerkship: CH_HTH 6000 and CH_HTH 6010.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to Pediatric Endocrinology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Successful completion of the first two years of medical schoolRecommended: Completion of the Child Health Clerkship (CH_HTH 6000 or CH_HTH 6010) is suggested but not required
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: The rotation is primarily an outpatient experience, though the student may be asked to do inpatient consultations with the attending physician on service. The elective will present an in-depth experience of diabetes/endocrinology as a subspecialty, including, but not limited to, exposure to disorders in growth and puberty, obesity, abnormalities in thyroid function and managing blood glucose levels in patients with type 1 diabetes. Additional teaching methods used may include lectures and readings relevant to this subspecialty.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: SCC Pediatric Allergy and Immunology 2 week
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Successful completion of the first two years of medical school
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This subspecialty elective emphasizes an introductory experience in the evaluation and management of common clinical problems in allergy and immunology. The learner will assist in the diagnosis and management of asthma, rhinitis/conjunctivitis/rhinosinusitis, atopic dermatitis, contact dermatitis, urticaria, angioedema, anaphylaxis and adverse reactions to foods, drugs and stinging insects. Additional experience in immunodeficiency disorders, as well as experience in allergy skin testing, administration of allergen immunotherapy, performance and interpretation of pulmonary function tests, and performance of food challenges and/or drug challenges/desensitizations may also be provided. Outpatients will be evaluated by the student under supervision of the faculty physician. In addition, it is expected that the learner will complete recommended readings, participate in selected on-line learning activities and complete both pre-test and post-test assessments.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Springfield Neonatal Intensive Care Unit 2-Week
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Successful completion of the first two years of medical school and a core rotation in family medicine or pediatrics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: The course goals are for the student to gain knowledge and experience in the evaluation, diagnosis, and management of sick newborns, and in the performance of specialized procedures necessary for ICU care.  The student will demonstrate an introductory-level working understanding of these areas.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Springfield Intro to Pediatric Endocrinology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Successful completion of the first two years of medical school. Completion of M3 CH clerkship suggested but not required
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This rotation is primarily an outpatient experience, though the student may be asked to do inpatient consultations with the attending physician. This elective will present an in-depth experience of diabetes/endocrinology as a subspecialty, including but not limited to exposure to disorders in growth and puberty, obesity, abnormalities in thyroid function, and managing blood glucose levels in patients with type 1 diabetes. Additional teaching methods used may include mini-lectures and readings relevant to this subspecialty.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Elementary Chinese II
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: C- or better in CHINSE 1100 or equivalent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course is a continuation of Elementary Chinese I, consisting of 5 hours of classroom instruction and 1 hour of lab work weekly.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Everyday Spoken Chinese Level I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Reinforces and extends ability to use Chinese language for spoken communication. Studies situation-specific Chinese in real-life situations. Intended to supplement, not replace, Chinese language courses taught on MU campus. Students must be enrolled in MU China Study Abroad.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Intermediate Chinese I Conversation and Composition
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: C- or better in CHINSE 1200 or equivalent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course builds on Chinese language learned in the elementary Chinese Language Sequences I & II through conversation and writing.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Chinese Language and Culture
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Must be enrolled in MU China Study Abroad; sophomore standing required
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Presents information about the development of Chinese language over time, the variety of dialects spoken in China, and around the world.  Explores relationship between Chinese language and culture.  Considers different genres of Chinese literature.  Visits to sites significant to development of Chinese language and literature.  Introduction to calligraphy and basic daily Chinese.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Intermediate Chinese II Conversation and Composition
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Continuation of CHINSE 2160.  Introduces more complex grammatical constructions and extends ability to use those constructions for written and oral communication.  Successful completion of course will enable students to communicate in Mandarin Chinese regarding everyday topics, with a vocabulary of just over 1900 words, and about 380 sentence patterns.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Everyday Spoken Chinese Level II
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: C- or better in CHINSE 3160 or consent of instructor
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: For students who have completed 18 credits college-level Chinese. Reinforces and extends ability to use Chinese language for Spoken communication. Class-time spent studying situation-specific Chinese in real-life situations. Intended to supplement, not replace, Chinese language courses taught on UMC campus. Students must be enrolled in MU China Study Abroad.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Advanced Chinese I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: C- or higher in CHINSE 3160, or equivalent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Improves vocabulary, listening, spoken and written Chinese Skills.  Discusses basic cultural ideas.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Advanced Chinese II
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: C- or above in CHINSE 3180, or equivalent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Students will build on grammatical patterns and vocabulary learned in Advanced Chinese 1, and will be able to use the Chinese language to discuss, read, and write about topics related to Chinese culture and modern society. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Chinese Traditions and Global Integration
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Must be enrolled in MU China Study Abroad; sophomore standing required
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Focuses on developments in China's International relations that have led to prominence on world stage, and the impact of modernization and integration into world community on China's sense of national identity, shape of Chinese culture, and lives of the people.  Visits to cultural and business sites, guest lectures, and conversations with Chinese people.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Chinese Traditions and Global Integration - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Must be enrolled in MU China Study Abroad;  sophomore standing required.  Honors eligibility required
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Focuses on developments in China's International relations that have led to prominence on world stage, and the impact of modernization and integration into world community on China's sense of national identity, shape of Chinese culture, and lives of the people.  Visits to cultural and business sites, guest lectures, and conversations with Chinese people.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Chinese Poetry
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This is an introductory course to Chinese poetry, both classical and contemporary, in English. It will explore issues in the intercultural and interlingual interpretation of foreign literature through the study of Western translations of and scholarship on selected Chinese poets.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Modern and Contemporary Chinese Fiction (in translation)
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Studies Chinese fiction from 1920s to 1990s. Preceded by a brief historical survey of Chinese literature. Analyzes works by authors like Lu Xun, Ba Jin, Lao She, Wang Meng and many others of the younger generation. Readings and lectures in English.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Negotiating Chinese Culture
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: As political, business, religious, and personal encounters between Chinese and Americans increase, so also does the need for competence in negotiating these cross-cultural interactions.  Whether hosting Chinese guests, visiting China for business or as a scholar, or simply trying to understand current events, a clear understanding of cultural differences and similarities can be quite valuable.  Students will be introduced to multiple perspectives on American and Chinese cultural differences along with narratives of cross-cultural experiences. Course address issues related to American and Chinese cross-cultural communication in five spheres of interaction: political, religious, business, interpersonal, education.  Through related readings, discussions, and structured conversations with Chinese, students will explore how this information and a deeper understanding of Chinese and American culture can be applied to more fruitful and positive cross-cultural interactions in multiple contexts.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Negotiating Chinese Culture - Writing Intensive
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: As political, business, religious, and personal encounters between Chinese and Americans increase, so also does the need for competence in negotiating these cross-cultural interactions.  Whether hosting Chinese guests, visiting China for business or as a scholar, or simply trying to understand current events, a clear understanding of cultural differences and similarities can be quite valuable.  Students will be introduced to multiple perspectives on American and Chinese cultural differences along with narratives of cross-cultural experiences. Course address issues related to American and Chinese cross-cultural communication in five spheres of interaction: political, religious, business, interpersonal, education.  Through related readings, discussions, and structured conversations with Chinese, students will explore how this information and a deeper understanding of Chinese and American culture can be applied to more fruitful and positive cross-cultural interactions in multiple contexts.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Urban Transportation Data Science

This is a hands-on course that trains students to use advance data analytic techniques to analyze transportation data, develop indicators, and create visualizations using the Python programming language, open source tools, and public data.  The course will first introduce the fundamentals of programming in Python before moving on to a survey of data analysis/visualization tools and technologies. Students will be introduced to cloud computing concepts and tasked to build applications using cloud-based services. Classroom sessions will include lectures and workshops.  A series of exercises will reinforce the skills and topics being presented, and a final project/paper will provide an opportunity for students to develop a more complete project from harvesting data from Open Data portals to synthesizing and analyzing those data to explore a question or problem, to communicating their results through term projects and presentations.  Graded on A-F basis only.
