https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Junior or Senior Standing. Permission of instructor
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Course is for undergraduate researchers, scholars, and artists to enhance communicating their research and scholarship to a variety of audiences and in multiple modes of communication. Students will use their own research, scholarly interests, and creative projects to create several communication pieces that may include abstracts/artist statements, press releases, elevator talks, manuscripts, presentations, posters, and short videos. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Ethical Issues in Communication
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: junior standing or departmental consent.  May be restricted to Communication majors only during early registration
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as PEA_ST 4440; cross-leveled with COMMUN 7440). Exploration and analysis of ethical dimensions intrinsic to human communication.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Political Communication
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: junior standing or departmental consent.  May be restricted to Communication majors only during early registration
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with COMMUN 7473). Study of role and impact of communication in political campaigns; historical and contemporary study of influence by communication; case studies and practicum.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Theory and Research in Persuasion
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: junior standing and COMMUN 1200.  May be restricted to Communication majors only during early registration
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with COMMUN 7474). Studies the persuasive process, attitude formation, modification.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Organizational Communication
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: junior standing and COMMUN 1200.  May be restricted to Communication majors only during early registration
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with COMMUN 7476). Theories of communication systems and processes in organizational structures; study of communication behavior in formal and informal organizational settings.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Communication Competencies for a Diverse Workplace
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Junior standing. May be restricted to Communication majors only during early registration
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Review of communication skills that can help students provide leadership around diversity and inclusion issues in the workplace, work more effective in diverse work environments, and make workplaces more welcoming and inclusive for everyone. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Political Public Address
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Course focuses on the rhetorical criticism of public address; which involves analyzing the use of symbolic communication - primarily persuasive argument - in public settings on issues of political, social and cultural significance. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Children's Communication
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Junior standing or departmental consent.  May be restricted to Communication majors only during early registration
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Course focuses on the nature of children's communication. Students will examine the communicative abilities, practices, and behaviors of children ranging across preschool and school age years.  Graded of A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Family Communication
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: junior standing or departmental consent.  May be restricted to Communication majors only during early registration
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as H_D_FS 4680; cross-leveled with COMMUN 7520, H_D_FS 7680). Analysis of the functions and processes of communication within families.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Children, Adolescents and the Media
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Focus on social scientific research concerning the mass media and social media in the lives of children and adolescents. The course centers on media effects literature and controversies relevant to child and adolescent media users. Course involves readings, lectures, discussions of theories, concepts, methods, and findings. We will also consider social implication and personal choices in media use. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: New Technologies and Communication
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: junior standing or instructor's consent.  May be restricted to Communication Majors only during early registration
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with COMMUN 7638). Explores the social implications of new technologies designed for communication. Assumes basic computer knowledge.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Race, Ethnicity, and the Media - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Presents an overview of how social identities of race and ethnicity are constructed within the media landscape. Provides an overview of the effects of stereotypical imagery and prosocial representations on users across a variety of media. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Digital Storytelling Production II
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Consent of instructorRecommended: COMMUN 1880 and COMMUN 2880
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as ENGLSH 4880, DST_VS 4880). Digital Storytelling Production II introduces students to advanced techniques in digital storytelling production, while further developing skills in script writing, storyboarding, Adobe Premiere Pro, and video production with DSLR cameras. Assignments in digital video production emphasize how video narratives are created and how images and audio enhance the structure, mood, and theme of the narrative. Instruction will focus on planning a video production and developing the tools and practices in lighting, sound recording, image capturing, and editing. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Senior Project
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: admission to department, senior standing, and departmental consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Integration and adaptation of communication theories to an applied communication problem. Required for all majors.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Political Communication
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with COMMUN 4473). Study of role and impact of communication in political campaigns; historical and contemporary study of influence by communication; case studies and practicum.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Topics in Communication-General
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Study of selected topics in communication. Topic and credit may vary semester to semester. Repeatable upon consent of department.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to Graduate Study in Communication
Seminar in Quantitative Methods in Communication II
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: The focus of this course will be the study and practice of various multivariate statistical methods commonly used in communication research. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Advanced Topics in Quantitative Methods
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Seminar in advanced topics in quantitative methods and statistics. Topics will vary. Course may be repeated up to two times for a total of six credit hours. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Research Practicum
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: consent of mentor required; for advanced graduate students
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Student conducts research under close supervision of faculty mentor. Goal: produce research report suitable for submission as convention paper, article, or book chapter. May be repeated once for credit.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Topics in Interpersonal and Family Communication
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: The course will review theory and research on topics related to the study of family communication and/or interpersonal communication. Subjects will rotate and include areas such as relational conflict, gender communication, narrative theory, family diversity, or intercultural communication.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Seminar in Media Processes and Effects
Seminar in Disaster, Crisis, and Risk
Algorithm Design and Programming I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: C- or higher in MATH 1100 or MATH 1160 or MATH 1500 or sufficient ALEKS score or MyMathTest College Algebra score of 60% or higher
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course provides experience in developing algorithms, designing, implementing programs. Topics include syntax/semantics, flow control, loops, recursion, I/O, arrays, strings and pointers.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Algorithm Design and Programming I - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Honor eligibility required. C- or higher in MATH 1100 or MATH 1160 or MATH 1500 or sufficient ALEKS score or MyMathTest College Algebra score of 60% or higher
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course provides experience in developing algorithms, designing, implementing programs. Topics include syntax/semantics, flow control, loops, recursion, I/O, arrays, strings and pointers.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Computing with Data in Python
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: C- or higher in MATH 1100 or MATH 1160 or MATH 1500
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Introduction to computer programming for non-CS majors. The syntax and semantics of the python program language is taught. Students learn decision and repetition flow control for programming. Data files access using a variety of software libraries is covered for numerous file formats, such as test files, CSV, Excel files and more. Data structure such as lists, dictionaries, and data frames are covered, as well as programming patterns for data structure loading, manipulation, iteration and processing. Coursework is completed using Python programming language. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Algorithm Design and Programming II
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: C or higher in CMP_SC 1050. May be restricted to Engineering majors only
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: A study of fundamental techniques and algorithms for representing and manipulating data structures. Topics include data abstraction, recursion, stacks, queues, linked lists, trees, efficient methods of sorting and searching, and Big-O analysis.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to Logic Systems
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: C or higher in CMP_SC 1050 or INFOTC 1040
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as ECE 2210). Basic tools, methods and procedures to design combinational and sequential digital circuits and systems, including number systems, boolean algebra, logic minimization, circuit design, memory elements, and finite state machine design.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to Computational Data Visualization
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course is an introduction to data visualization using computational paradigms. The basic concepts of data visualization are introduced, including use of color, size, shape, and spatial organization to convey characteristics of data collections. Students learn to visualize univariate and multivariate data, customize style and formatting, and add plot enrichments to enhance visual information. Specialty visualization, such as timeseries, statistics, geospatial data, and interactive plots are also covered. Coursework is completed using the Python programming language. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Web Application Development I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: C- or higher in CMP_SC 2050 or INFOTC 2040
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as INFOTC 2830). This course focuses on the development of web pages and web applications using Full Stack Development methodologies and tools. Topics such as current events, cloud services, web servers, digital animations, images, audio and video, user interface design, and usability principles are also challenged.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Advanced Algorithm Design
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: CMP_SC 2050 with a C or higher
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This class surveys fundamental algorithms and data structures that have wide practical applicability, including search trees and graph algorithms.  Emphasis is placed on techniques for efficient implementation and good software development methodologies.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Computer Organization and Assembly Language
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: C or higher in CMP_SC 2270 or ECE 2210 or ECE 1210, and C or higher in CMP_SC 2050
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as ECE 3280). Introduces computer architectures, programming concepts including parameter passing, I/O, interrupt handling, DMA, memory systems, cache, and virtual memory. Graded of A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Object Oriented Programming
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: CMP_SC 2050 or INFOTC 2040 with a C or higher grade
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as INFOTC 3330). This course focuses on object-oriented programming concepts such as: Abstraction, Polymorphism, Encapsulation, Inheritance, Interfaces, Abstract Classes, Files, Streams, and Object Serialization. Topics such as GUI and event-driven programming, APIs, and design patterns are also tackled.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Database Applications and Information Systems
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: C or higher in CMP_SC 2050 or INFOTC 2040
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Covers fundamental topics of database management systems (DBMS) and database-enabled applications.  Topics include a brief history of secondary storage and databases, data modeling, introductory SQL, an overview of current database trends, and current popular database systems. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: UNIX Operating System
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: C- or higher in CMP_SC 1050 or INFOTC 1040
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as INFOTC 3530).This course is an introduction to UNIX and UNIX-like operating systems and interfaces, to include the file system, command shells, text editors, pipes and filters, input/output system, shell scripting and Regular Expressions. The course will also incorporate an aspect of programming in a UNIX environment, cloud computing, containers and an introduction to System Administration. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Signals and Linear Systems
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: A grade of C or better in ECE 3810, and a grade of C or better in CMP_SC 2270 or a grade of C or better in ECE 2210, or Instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as ECE 3830). Transform Analysis of Signals and Linear Systems. Laplace transforms, z-transforms, Fourier series and transforms.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Design and Analysis of Algorithms I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: C or higher in CMP_SC 3050 and MATH 2320
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with CMP_SC 7050). This course reviews and extends earlier work with linked structures, sorting and searching algorithms, and recursion. Graph algorithms, string matching, combinatorial search, geometrical algorithms and related topics are also studied.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: String Algorithms
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with CMP_SC 7060). This course provides an introduction to algorithms that efficiently compute patterns in strings.  Topics covered include basic properties of strings, data structures for processing strings, string decomposition, exact and approximate string matching algorithms.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Numerical Methods for Science and Engineering
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: C- or higher in CMP_SC 2050 and junior standing or instructor's consentRecommended: Students are expected to have basic knowledge in discrete math and algorithms
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as ECE 4070; cross-leveled with CMP_SC 7070, ECE 7070). This course introduces the basic numerical methods that are widely used by computer scientists and engineers. Students will learn how to use the MATLAB platform to find the computational solution of various problems arising in many real world applications. By completing this course, students will be able to master algorithms, compare their performances and critically assess which ones are viable options for the particular problem at hand. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Parallel Programming for High Performance Computing
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: C- or higher in CMP_SC 3280 or ECE 3210 and C- or higher in CMP_SC 3050 or ECE 3220
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as ECE 4080; cross-leveled with CMP_SC 7080, ECE 7080) This course will provide in-depth treatment of the evolution high performance computing architectures and parallel programming techniques for those architectures. We will cover topics such as: multi-process and multi-threaded programming; multi-node system architectures (clusters, grids, and clouds) and distributed programming; and general purpose GPU programming. To reinforce lecture topics, programming projects will be completed using multi-process and multi-threaded techniques for modern multicore, multiprocessor workstations; parallel and distributed programming techniques for modern multi-node systems; and general purpose GPU programming. Parallel algorithms will be investigated, selected, and then developed for various scientific data processing problems. Programming projects will be completed using C and C++ APIs and language extensions, e.g. threads (pthreads, Boost/C++), TBB, CILK, OpenMP, OpenMPI, CUDA and OpenCL.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Computer Architecture
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: C or higher in CMP_SC 2050 and CMP_SC 3280 or ECE 3280
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as ECE 4270; cross-leveled with CMP_SC 7270, ECE 7270). Advanced computer architectures and programming; memory, memory management and cache organizations, parallel processing, graphical processor units for general programming.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Network Systems Architecture
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: C- or higher in CMP_SC 2050 or ECE 3220 and C- or higher in CMP_SC 3280 or ECE 3210
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as ECE 4280; cross-leveled with CMP_SC 7280, ECE 7280). The course covers network systems (interconnects and switch fabrics, network considerations) and relevant networking applications at the network, transport and application layer.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Software Engineering I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with CMP_SC 7320). Overview of software life cycle, including topics in systems analysis and requirements specification, design, implementation testing and maintenance.  Uses modeling techniques, project management, peer review, quality assurance, and system acquisition.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Software Engineering I - Writing Intensive
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with CMP_SC 7320). Overview of software life cycle, including topics in systems analysis and requirements specification, design, implementation testing and maintenance.  Uses modeling techniques, project management, peer review, quality assurance, and system acquisition.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Object Oriented Design I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with CMP_SC 7330). Building on a prior knowledge of program design and data structures, this course covers object-oriented design, including classes, objects, inheritance, polymorphism, and information hiding. Students will apply techniques using a modern object-oriented implementation language.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Big Data Analytics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: C- or higher in CMP_SC 3330 and CMP_SC 3380
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with CMP_SC 7350). Big Data Analytics represents a new era of computing, where data in any format maybe processed and exploited to extract insights for industries and organizations to make informed decisions, whether that data is in-place, in-motion or at-rest, in large volume, structured or unstructured. More and more companies are embracing open source Big Data technologies, such as Hadoop and extending it into an enterprise ready Big Data Platform. This course will cover advanced analytics technologies and techniques that enable industries to extract insights from data with sophistication, speed and accuracy. You will learn practical industry best practices to bridge the gap between classroom learning and real world; and have access to cloud services for labs/projects.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Database Management Systems I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with CMP_SC 7380). Fundamental concepts of current database systems with emphasis on the relational model. Topics include entity-relationship model, relational algebra, query by example, indexing, query optimization, normal forms, crash recovery, web-based database access, and case studies. Project work involves a modern DBMS, such as Oracle, using SQL.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: iOS App Development I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: INFOTC 1040 or CMP_SC 1050 with C- or higher, or consent of instructorRecommended: Prior experience programming in any programming language. The student should understand basic language concepts such as variables, data structures, control structures, and functions
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as INFOTC 4405). This is a first in a series of courses on developing iOS applications using Xcode, and the Swift programming language on the macOS platform.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Theory of Computation I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with CMP_SC 7410). An introductory study of computation and formal languages by means of automata and related grammars. The theory and applications of finite automata, regular expressions, context free grammars, pushdown automata and Turing machines are examined. May not be counted toward Computer Science MS/PHD.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Software Security
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with CMP_SC 7420). This course would introduce students to fundamental principles of applied computer security who will learn to identify, detect, and defend against common security vulnerabilities. The goals of this course are: (1) to provide students with a solid background with basic software security concepts, (2) impart knowledge of common soft- ware security vulnerabilities and (3) foster understanding of secure design of software. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Compilers I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: C- or higher in MATH 2320, CMP_SC 3280 and CMP_SC 4450
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with CMP_SC 7430). Introduction to the translation of programming languages by means of interpreters and compilers. Lexical analysis, syntax specification, parsing, error-recovery, syntax-directed translation, semantic analysis, symbol tables for block structured languages, and run-time storage organization. May not be counted toward Computer Science MS/PHD.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Malware Analysis and Defense
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: C- or higher in CMP_SC 3280 or ECE 3210
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with CMP_SC 7440). Malicious software or "malware" is a security threat.  This course teaches students to understand the nature and types of viruses and how they are threats; teaches techniques used to prevent, detect, repair and defend against viruses and worms; teaches program binary examination tools to detect malicious code; and teaches ethical issues surrounding computer security violations.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Principles of Programming Languages
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with CMP_SC 7450). An introduction to the structure, design and implementation of programming languages. Topics include syntax, semantics, data types, control structures, parameter passing, run-time structures, and functional and logic programming.  May not be counted toward Computer Science MS/PHD.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to Cryptography
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: C- or higher in CMP_SC 3050 and MATH 2320
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with CMP_SC 7460). Cryptography is an important technique used to achieve security goals in an untrusted and possibly adversarial environment. The goals of this course are: (1) to provide students with a solid background with basic cryptographic techniques and their applications, (2) to impart knowledge of standard cryptographic algorithms and (3) to foster understanding of the correct use of cryptographic techniques.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Operating Systems I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: C or higher in CMP_SC 3050, C or higher in CMP_SC 3280, and C- or higher in MATH 1700
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with CMP_SC 7520). Basic concepts, theories and implementation of modern operating systems including process and memory management, synchronization, CPU and disk scheduling, file systems, I/O systems, security and protection, and distributed operating systems.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Cloud Computing
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: C- or higher in CMP_SC 3330 or instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with CMP_SC 7530). This course covers principles that integrate computing theories and information technologies with the design, programming and application of distributed systems. The course topics will familiarize students with distributed system models and enabling technologies; virtual machines and virtualization of clusters, networks and data centers; cloud platform architecture with security over virtualized data centers; service- oriented architectures for distributed computing; and cloud programming and software environments. Additionally, students will learn how to conduct some parallel and distributed programming and performance evaluation experiments on applications within available cloud platforms. Finally we will survey research literature and latest technology trends that are shaping the future of high performance, distributed and cloud computing.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Neural Models and Machine Learning
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: MATH 1500 or consent of instructorRecommended: Introductory software programming, and introductory cell biology or consent of instructor
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as ECE 4540, BME 4540, BIOL_EN 4540; cross-leveled with CMP_SC 7540, ECE 7540, BIOL_EN 7540).  The projects-based course has three inter-linked components: (I) math models of neurons and neural networks, (II) machine learning in neuroscience, after a brief introduction to python and (III) software automation and cyberinfrastructure to support neuroscience. Extensive projects focusing on software automation and machine learning components, with brief in-class presentations. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Cyber Defense
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with CMP_SC 7550). Familiarize students with intrusion detection systems; application and network attacks; security architectures; design principles; compliance standards; risk assessment and management; policy management; authentication and access control; and moving target defense. The course also will provide hands-on skills to apply cyber defense at the application and network levels. Course students will conduct experiments on the "Mizzou Cyber Range" relating to attack detection, resource adaptation as well as human/behavioral aspects. Finally, students will collaboratively survey research literature, real-world case studies and latest trends in data science, artificial intelligence, and human-centered design that are shaping nextgeneration cyber defense services in enterprise systems and critical infrastructures. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Computational Neuroscience
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as BIO_SC 4590, BIOL_EN 4590, ECE 4590, BME 4590; cross-leveled with BIO_SC 7590, ECE 7590, BIOL_EN 7590). Interdisciplinary course in biology and quantitative sciences with laboratory and modeling components. Explores basic computational and neurobiological concepts at the cellular and network level. Introduction to neuronal processing and experimental methods in neurobiology; modeling of neurons and neuron-networks. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Computer Graphics I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: C- or higher in CMP_SC 3050 and MATH 1500 or C- or higher in CMP_SC 3050 and MATH 1300 and MATH 1400
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with CMP_SC 7610).Basic concepts and techniques of interactive computer graphics including hardware, software, data structures, mathematical manipulation of graphical objects, the user interface, and fundamental implementation algorithms.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Physically Based Modeling and Animation
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: C- or higher in CMP_SC 4610Recommended: Good knowledge of C or C++ programming, no physics background necessary
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with CMP_SC 7620). This course introduces students to physically based modeling and animation methodology for computer graphics and related fields such as computer vision, visualization, biomedical imaging and virtual reality.  We will explore current research issues and will cover associated computational methods for simulating various visually interesting physical phenomena. This course should be appropriate for graduate students in all areas as well as advanced undergraduate students.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Game Development
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: INFOTC 3630  with C- or better, or INFOTC 2040 with C- or higher, or CMP_SC 2050 with a C- or better
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as INFOTC 4630).  The course focuses on rapid game prototyping and development utilizing the Unity game engine and C#. tools. You will learn the fundamentals of game programming and also a platform which is actually used t to make published games across multiple platforms (Mac, PC, web, iOS, Android etc). Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Digital Image Processing
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: C- or higher in CMP_SC 2050 and STAT 4710 or instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as ECE 4655; cross-leveled with CMP_SC 7650, ECE 7655). Fundamentals of digital image processing hardware and software including digital image acquisition, image display, image enhancement, image transforms and segmentation.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Digital Image Compression
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as ECE 4675; cross-leveled with ECE 7675, CMP_SC 7670).  Covers digital image formation, information theory concepts, and fundamental lossless and lossy image compression techniques including bit plane encoding, predictive coding, transform coding, block truncation coding, vector quantization, subband coding and hierarchical coding.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to Machine Learning and Pattern Recognition
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: C- or higher in CMP_SC 2050 and STAT 4710 or instructor consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as ECE 4720; cross-leveled with ECE 7720, CMP_SC 7720) This course provides foundations and methods in machine learning and pattern recognition that address the problem of programming computers to optimize performance by learning from example data or expert knowledge. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Building Intelligent Robots
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: junior standingRecommended: programming experience in one of the following programming languages - Basic, C, C++, or Java
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as ECE 4340; cross-leveled with CMP_SC 7730, ECE 7340). Covers the design and development of intelligent machines, emphasizing topics related to sensor-based control of mobile robots.  Includes mechanics and motor control, sensor characterization, reactive behaviors and control architectures.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Interdisciplinary Introduction to NLP
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as LINGST 4740; cross-leveled with CMP_SC 7740; LINGST 7740). The goal of this course is to enable students to develop substantive NLP applications.  Focus on current structural and statistical techniques for the parsing and interpretation of texts.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Artificial Intelligence I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: C- or higher in CMP_SC 3050 and junior standing
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as ECE 4750; cross-leveled with CMP_SC 7750, ECE 7750).This course is intended to be a general introduction to the field of Artificial Intelligence (AI). It will provide exposure to a range of core AI topics including intelligent agent, problem solving by search and game playing, constraint satisfaction problems, propositional and first-order logic, probability in AI, and machine learning. The topics covered in this course are closely related to the common core of Computing & Information education -- about C&I know-how and the ways of thinking and problem solving that characterize C&I community: a system view of the world, a focus on mathematical and computational representation of systems, information representation and transformation, and so forth.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Web Application Development II
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: C- or higher in CMP_SC 2830 or INFOTC 2830
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as INFOTC 4830; cross-leveled with CMP_SC 7830). This course will study science and engineering of the world-wide web, languages, protocols, services, and tools that enable the web. Topics such as virtual machines, model-view-controller, data interchange formats, data analytics, web services and APIs, templates, authentication, security, scalability, protocols, and version-control are also challenged. Emphasis will be placed on cloud services and technologies.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Computer Networks I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with CMP_SC 7850). Introduction to concepts and terminology of data communications and computer networking. Basic protocols and standards, applications of networking, routing algorithms, congestion avoidance, long-haul and local networks.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Digital Forensics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: CMP_SC 3530 or INFOTC 3530 with a C- or higher
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as INFOTC 4910; cross-leveled with CMP_SC 7910, INFOTC 7910). This course introduces an overview of basic Digital Forensics procedures and techniques to enable students to perform a digital investigation of physical storage media and volume analysis, including preservation, analysis and acquisition of artifacts that resides in hard disk and random access memory, for Linux and Windows systems. Work is completed in Unix/Linux environments and in Microsoft Windows environment. Students will need to setup a virtual private infrastructure to perform multiple tasks. The course emphasizes "learning by doing" and has a 90% hands-on and 10% theory. Much of this information consists of skills and abilities that employers want and expect in the real world of IT - in a small to medium size organization. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Senior Capstone Design I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: C or higher in CMP_SC 4320 and senior standing
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Communication skills, and prototyping.  Covers professional ethics, intellectual property/patenting, knowledge of engineering literature, safety, economic and environmental impact of technology.  Essays, oral and written reports.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Senior Capstone Design I - Writing Intensive
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: C or higher in CMP_SC 4320 and senior standing
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Communication skills, and prototyping.  Covers professional ethics, intellectual property/patenting, knowledge of engineering literature, safety, economic and environmental impact of technology.  Essays, oral and written reports.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Senior Capstone Design II
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Course entails completion of CMP_SC 4970 design project.  Design prototyping, testing, evaluation, presentation, and preparation of documentation.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Undergraduate Research in Computer Science - Honors
Computational Methods in Bioinformatics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as INFOINST 7010)  Introduces the fundamental concepts and basic computational techniques for mainstream bioinformatics problems.  Emphasis will be placed on the computational aspect of bioinformatics, including formulation of a biological problem in a computable problem, design of scoring functions and algorithms, confidence assessment of prediction results and software development.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Design and Analysis of Algorithms I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with CMP_SC 4050). This course reviews and extends earlier work with linked structures, sorting and searching algorithms, and recursion.  Graph algorithms, string matching, combinatorial search, geometrical algorithms and related topics are also studied. Cannot be counted toward CS MS/PHD.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: String Algorithms
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with CMP_SC 4060). This course provides an introduction to algorithms that efficiently compute patterns in strings.  Topics covered include basic properties of strings, data structures for processing strings, string decomposition, exact and approximate string matching algorithms.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Numerical Methods for Science and Engineering
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: C- or higher in CMP_SC 2050  or instructor's consentRecommended: Students are expected to have basic knowledge in discrete math and algorithms
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with CMP_SC 4070). This course introduces the basic numerical methods that are widely used by computer scientists and engineers. Students will learn how to use the MATLAB platform to find the computational solution of various problems arising in many real world applications. By completing this course, students will be able to master algorithms, compare their performances and critically assess which ones are viable options for the particular problem at hand. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Parallel Programming for High Performance Computing
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: CMP_SC 3280 or ECE 3210 and CMP_SC 3050 or ECE 3220
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as ECE 7080; cross-leveled with CMP_SC 4080, ECE 4080). This course will provide in-depth treatment of the evolution high performance computing architectures and parallel programming techniques for those architectures. https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: C or higher in CMP_SC 2050 and CMP_SC 3280 or ECE 3280
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as ECE 7270; cross-leveled with CMP_SC 4270, ECE 4270). Advanced computer architectures and programming; memory, memory management and cache organizations, parallel processing, graphical processor units for general programming.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with CMP_SC 4320). Uses modeling techniques, project management, peer review, quality assurance, and system acquisition.   May not be counted toward CS MS/PHD.

Students will apply techniques using a modern object-oriented implementation language.
