https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with ECONOM 7328). Financial economics is economics applied to tradeable financial assets, such as stocks and bonds. The main topics covered are the valuation of stocks, bonds, and other financial assets; portfolio theory; the capital asset pricing model; the efficient market hypothesis; capital structure theories; options and other derivatives; principal/agent issues; and behavioral finance. The course uses simple math and current examples to understand and apply the theories.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: The Banking System and the Money Market
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: ECONOM 1015 or ABM 1042 or ECONOM 1000 or ECONOM 1051
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with ECONOM 7329). Organization of the money market; credit control procedures and aims, effect of bank expansion and contraction on money market and national income deregulation.

An introduction to the theory of games, viewed as a set of tools used widely in economics to study situations in which decision-makers (consumers, firms, governments, etc.) interact. The course introduces the basic theory, emphasizing the concepts and their economic applications.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Economics of Education

Topics include: human capital theory, cost and performance measures for public and private schools, market based approaches to school reform, school finance, higher education cost and access.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Economic theory is used to analyze the market for educational services and education policy. Topics include: human capital theory, cost and performance measures for public and private schools, market based approaches to school reform, school finance, higher education cost and access.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with ECONOM 7351). Theory of rational behavior in consumption, production, and pricing decisions of households and firms. Partial equilibria in product and factor markets under competition, monopoly, oligopoly, and monopolistic competition. A brief introduction to general equilibrium and welfare economics is provided. Calculus is employed.

Partial equilibria in product and factor markets under competition, monopoly, oligopoly, and monopolistic competition. A brief introduction to general equilibrium and welfare economics is provided. Calculus is employed.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Intermediate Macroeconomics

Topics include: long-term economic growth, aggregate economic fluctuations, unemployment, and inflation; consequences for national economies of being part of the global economic system; government policies and macroeconomic performance.

Topics include oligopoly, competition, collusion, price discrimination, product differentiation, advertising, entry and exit.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Industrial Organization and Competitive Strategy - Writing Intensive

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Health Economics

It examines the demand for health care and the structure and consequences of public and private health insurance; the supply of health care, including professional training, licensure, specialization and compensation, hospital competition and finance, and the determinants and consequences of technical change in medicine and health care reform.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Health Economics - Writing Intensive

It examines the demand for health care and the structure and consequences of public and private health insurance; the supply of health care, including professional training, licensure, specialization and compensation, hospital competition and finance, and the determinants and consequences of technical change in medicine and health care reform.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with ECONOM 7370). The aim of this course is to provide an introduction to the mathematical language of economic theory.  Topics include linear models, matrix algebra, rules of differentiation and comparative static analysis, optimization.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introductory Econometrics

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: ECONOM 3271 or STAT 2500Corequisites: ECONOM 4371 or STAT 3500
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course surveys economic research on the causes and consequences of race and sex disparities in economic and social indicators, with a particular emphasis on recent empirical studies and current domestic policy debates.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Economics of Discrimination - Writing Intensive
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: ECONOM 3271 or STAT 2500Corequisites: ECONOM 4371 or STAT 3500
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course surveys economic research on the causes and consequences of race and sex disparities in economic and social indicators, with a particular emphasis on recent empirical studies and current domestic policy debates.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Honors Thesis
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Not open to non-majors.  Capstone course required for Economics honors students.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Labor Economics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with ECONOM 4311).  Surveys theoretical explanations of wage and employment determination in contemporary labor markets.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Public Economics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with ECONOM 4315). Analyzes economic effects of government expenditures, taxes and debt. Expenditure and taxation principles, tax reform, cost-benefit analysis, fiscal policy.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: State and Local Finance
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: ECONOM 3251 or ECONOM 7351 or instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: State and local tax and expenditure problems, intergovernmental fiscal relations, problems of metropolitan areas.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: History of Economic Thought
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with ECONOM 4320). Origins of modern economic thought in the context of social and intellectual environment of the time in which they originated, their contribution to their period and to modern thought.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Economics of International Trade
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with ECONOM 4326). The microeconomic theory of international trade. Topics include comparative advantage, the theory of commercial policy, economic integration, trade with LDC's and the trade effects of economic growth.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Financial Economics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: ECONOM 1014; (MATH 1400 or MATH 1500); and (STAT 2500 or ABM 2225)
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with ECONOM 4328). Financial economics is economics applied to tradeable financial assets, such as stocks and bonds. The main topics covered are the valuation of stocks, bonds, and other financial assets; portfolio theory; the capital asset pricing model; the efficient market hypothesis; capital structure theories; options and other derivatives; principal/agent issues; and behavioral finance. The course uses simple math and current examples to understand and apply the theories.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: The Banking System and the Money Market
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: ECONOM 1015 or ABM 1042 or ECONOM 1000 or ECONOM 1051
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with ECONOM 4329) Organization of the money market; credit control procedures and aims, effect of bank expansion and contraction on money market and national income deregulation.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to Game Theory
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: ECONOM 3251 or ECONOM 7351 or instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with ECONOM 4340). An introduction to the theory of games, viewed as a set of tools used widely in economics to study situations in which decision-makers (consumers, firms, governments, etc.) interact. The course introduces the basic theory, emphasizing the concepts and their economic applications.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Economics of Education
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: (ECONOM 1014 or ECONOM 1024 or ABM 1041 or ECONOM 1000) and (STAT 2200 or STAT 2500) or equivalent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with ECONOM 4345). Economic theory is used to analyze the market for educational services and education policy. Topics include: human capital theory, cost and performance measures for public and private schools, market based approaches to school reform, school finance, higher education cost and access.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Intermediate Microeconomics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with ECONOM 4351). Theory of rational behavior in consumption, production, and pricing decisions of households and firms. Partial equilibria in product and factor markets under competition, monopoly, oligopoly, and monopolistic competition. A brief introduction to general equilibrium and welfare economics is provided. Calculus is employed.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Intermediate Macroeconomics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: (ECONOM 1000 or ECONOM 1015 or ABM 1042) and (MATH 1400 or MATH 1500) or equivalent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with ECONOM 4353). The study of the structure and performance of national economics. Topics include: long-term economic growth, aggregate economic fluctuations, unemployment, and inflation; consequences for national economies of being part of the global economic system; government policies and macroeconomic performance.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Industrial Organization and Competitive Strategy
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with ECONOM 4355). Analyzes the structure of industry, its impact on the operations of the firm and significance for public policy. The focus is on strategic interaction among firms with market power.  Topics include oligopoly, competition, collusion, price discrimination, product differentiation, advertising, entry and exit.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Health Economics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: ECONOM 3251 or ECONOM 4351 and (STAT 2200 or STAT 2500) or equivalent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as PUB_AF 7357; cross-leveled with ECONOM 4357). Analyzes the economics of health care in the United States with particular attention paid to the role of government.  It examines the demand for health care and the structure and consequences of public and private health insurance; the supply of health care, including professional training, licensure, specialization and compensation, hospital competition and finance, and the determinants and consequences of technical change in medicine: and examination of recent proposals and initiatives for health care reform.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Comparative Economic Systems
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with Econom 4361). Study of capitalism, market socialism, and central planning.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Quantitative Economics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: MATH 1300 and MATH 1400 or MATH 1500 or equivalent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with ECONOM 4370). The aim of this course is to provide an introduction to the mathematical language of economic theory.  Topics include linear models, matrix algebra, rules of differentiation and comparative static analysis, optimization.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introductory Econometrics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: ECONOM 3251 or ECONOM 4351 and (STAT 2200 or STAT 2500) or equivalent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with ECONOM 4371). Study methods for quantitative analysis of economic data. Estimating techniques, tests of significance, prediction and forecasting reviewed with respect to problems presented by economic data and information demands of economic decision models.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Dynamic Optimization and its Applications to the Natural Sciences and Economics
Topics in Economics- General
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Organized study of selected topics. Subjects and earnable credit may vary from semester to semester.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Game Theory
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: ECONOM 4351 or equivalent; MATH 1320 or equivalent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Game theory is the study of strategic behavior by agents who perceive themselves as "large" relative to the market and who therefore consider the effect of their behavior on others. This course examines the rigorous theory of strategic interaction of rational agents. May be repeated for credit. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Mathematics for Economics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: The aim of this course is to cover essential mathematics used in economics. Topics include introductory linear algebra, multivariate calculus, comparative statics analysis, unconstrained optimization, and equality constrained optimization. May be repeated for credit. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Research Workshop I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: ECONOM 8451, ECONOM 8453, and ECONOM 8473 or instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Required course for economics MA students.  Combines instruction, student presentations, and seminar participation to introduce research methods and practice. A major research paper are required.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Macroeconomic Theory
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: ECONOM 4353 or equivalent; at least concurrent enrollment in ECONOM 8451.  Instructor's consent required for non graduate level students
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Basic models in macroeconomics will be covered with emphasis on assumptions and on how hypotheses can be tested.  Course is an introductory survey for students intending to develop ability for research in macroeconomics.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Applied Econometrics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: ECONOM 7371 or ECONOM 8472; and ECONOM 7370 or ECONOM 8370
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Topics include: nonlinear least squares, numerical optimization, maximum likelihood and basic panel data and time series methods.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Advanced Money and Banking
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: The working and structure of institutional arrangements, welfare aspects of structural policies, operation of money and credit markets, and behavior of returns on assets.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Central Banking Policies
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Examines central banking procedures, policies and the role they play in maintaining economic stability. Special attention to connection of Federal Reserve System with money and capital markets.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Advanced Empirical Methods
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: ECONOM 8451, ECONOM 8473Recommended: Concurrent enrollment in ECONOM 8473 or ECONOM 9473
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Empirical and modeling techniques for evaluation of microeconomic policy questions.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Advanced Empirical Methods II
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: ECONOM 9446Recommended: Concurrent enrollment in ECONOM 8473 or ECONOM 9473
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Applies the methods and techniques of microeconomics and to specific timely policy questions.  Taught by applied-microeconomics faculty and focuses on current topics in labor economics, public economics, crime economics, the economics of education, health economics, and other applied areas of microeconomics.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Advanced Microeconomic Theory I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: The theory of rational behavior and partial equilibrium in markets.  Topics include consumer behavior, theory of the firm, decisions making under uncertainty, perfect competition, monopoly and monopsony, and imperfect competition.  Graded on A/F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Advanced Microeconomic Theory II
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Survey of equilibrium theory and market failures in economics. Topics include the structure and modeling of games, and cooperative and non-cooperative equilibrium concepts.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Advanced Macroeconomic Theory I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Aggregate models of life-cycle microfoundations, of macroeconomics fluctuations and growth.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Advanced Macroeconomic Theory II
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Analyzes topics in income analysis, including capital theory and economic dynamics.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Monopoly and Competition
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: A survey of the theoretical and empirical literature on the organization of industries. Includes study of monopolized markets, competitive markets, and strategic interaction among firms in imperfectly competitive markets. Both the rationale and practice of anti-trust policy are studied.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Computational Economics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Covers numerical and computational methods to solve economic models at the research frontier. Emphasis is on practical applications to prepare students for independent research. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Advanced Game Theory
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Presents core concepts in game theory and illustrates their uses with a range of applications.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Econometric Theory II
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Analysis of nonlinear regression models and other essential econometric tools not covered in ECONOM 9472 from an advanced statistical perspective.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Advanced Topics in Econometrics I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Equips students with some essential tools for conducting publishable econometric research. Topics at the discretion of the instructor - typically time series analysis.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Advanced Topics in Econometrics II
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Equips students with some essential tools for conducting publishable econometric research.  Topics at the discretion of the instructor - typically microeconometrics.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Advanced Topics in Econometrics III
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Equips students with some essential tools for conducting publishable econometric research. Topics at the discretion of the instructor - typically the second semester of a two-semester time series sequence beginning with ECONOM 9474 or a two-semester microeconometrics sequence beginning with ECONOM 9476.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Undergraduate Reading Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course is designed to introduce students to a variety of readings from a broad array of research, historical, contemporary and philosophical documents and writings.  Selection of topics and additional readings are determined by the faculty instructor for the course.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Civil Rights and Advocacy in Education
Broadening Participation in Science and Engineering Fields
Listening Skills for College Student Success
Data and Decision Making for Education Leaders
Introduction to Research in Educational Settings
Inquiring into Schools, Community and Society II
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as ED_LPA 7060). Required 3 hour course for students pursuing teacher certification.  Designed to transition students into the teaching internship through study of teacher roles, school organizations and cultures, and community contexts.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Leading Educational Organizations in Global Contexts
Leadership for Student Learning in a Global Context
Leading Professional Development in Global Contexts
Leadership for School-Community Partnerships in a Global Context
Introduction to Ethics and PK-12 Policymaking
Undergraduate Administrative Internships
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with ED_LPA 7481). These administrative internships are designed for students in the Bachelor's of Educational Studies (BES) degree program and those students who are a part of the Dean of Students Internship Program. It may also serve as an elective for any undergraduate student at the University of Missouri. The intent of this course is to integrate practice, theory, and ethical standards within a supervised education setting called an internship. Specific activities during the internship may vary greatly from one field placement to another in that different students may have different learning needs and desires, and different settings will offer different learning opportunities. In some circumstances and situations, an off-campus/off-site setting for an internship is also possible. The course may be repeated depending on student interests, internship site availability, and additional experiences needed by the student. Graded on S/U basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Educational Studies Senior Capstone- Writing Intensive
Inquiring into Schools, Community and Society II
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as ED_LPA 4060). Required 3 hours course for students pursuing teacher certification.  Designed to transition students into the teaching internship through study of teacher roles, school organizations and cultures, and community contexts.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Leading Educational Organizations in Global Contexts
Leadership for Student Learning in a Global Context
Leading Professional Development in Global Contexts
Leadership for School-Community Partnerships in a Global Context
Introduction to Ethics and PK-12 Policymaking
Applying Higher Education Research to Practice
Learning, Curriculum and Assessment for School Leaders
Superintendent: Structures and Processes for Effective Schools
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: A comprehensive view of district leadership will focus on organizational health and adult issues that impact school culture and require strong, caring leadership. A focus will be on how to efficiently lead and manage change, as this is a requirement for leaders of all organizations, including schools. Of particular interest will be the research and practices that are currently associated with the evaluation of program effectiveness.    A continuation of the study of state and national legal and policy issues will focus on special education programs and services, Missouri Comprehensive Guidance Program, District Student Behavioral Practices and Disparities, District Health Program, and Limited English Programs.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: School Law and Finance for Principal Leadership
Education Toward Bi/Multilingualism: Theory, Policy, and Practice
Grounded Theory and Situated Inquiry
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: ED_LPA 8957, LTC 8957, or ESC_PS 8957Recommended: ED_LPA 9620, LTC 9620, or ESC_PS 9620
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as LTC 8951). For qualitative researchers attempting to understand social processes, Grounded Theory (GT) offers a way of developing theory empirically, 'from the bottom up.' In fact, this is what most distinguishes GT from other methods. It is explicitly emergent. It does not test a hypothesis. It provides useful tools to learn about participants' understandings and experiences of a social issue, process, or phenomena and to discover and construct theory to account for the social processes being studied. In this course, we will consider the theoretical underpinnings and practices of classic and contemporary GT methodologies. Importantly, we will conduct research and a GT analysis of data.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Discourse Analysis in Education
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as LTC 8955). This course introduces the theories and methods of discourse analysis, including conversation, critical discourse, and multimodal. Students will analyze the role of context and ethics, as they transcribe and analyze discourse, especially from analytical settings. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Qualitative Methods in Educational Research I
Research in Educational Leadership and Policy Analysis
Problems in Educational Leadership and Policy Analysis
Inquiry into Educational Leadership and Policy Analysis
Seminar in Educational Leadership and Policy Analysis
Proseminar in Educational Leadership and Policy Analysis
Theories in District-Level Administration
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course is designed to provide an overview of the theories and best practice related to the job duties of superintendent of schools. Since all students will have a principal certification, this course will explore/examine the differences in building administration versus district-level administration. The course will also provide a framework for the cohort EdS program. Providing an overview of topics that will be explored in greater detail later in the program. Finally, the course will lay out the expectations and process for the capstone action research topic that will be due at the end of the central office internship course. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: School Personnel Administration
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: In this course, candidates will explore/examine: How to develop a school-wide system for effective staff evaluation and feedback; How to craft a vision for teacher development and growth and bring that vision to life within the structures required for Missouri Educator Evaluation System; How to effectively implement the Missouri Educator Evaluation System for teachers and administrators; How to engage in courageous conversations designed to enhance teaching practice and student outcomes; How to integrate all school staff, including those who do not report directly to the superintendent, into the process of staff supervision and feedback; Develop an understanding of effective leadership including building mission, vision and core values; Increase skills in communications in all scenarios; Demonstrate the ability to accurately rate principals and other leadership staff using appropriate district evaluation tools. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Race, Gender, and Ethnicity in Higher Education
Curriculum Philosophy and Development in Higher Education
History of Higher Education in the United States
Administration and Governance of Higher Education
Policy Analysis Using Large Data Bases
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: an understanding of inferential statistics and experience with SPSS and SAS program
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Intends to develop students' capacity to process national level large databases and to conduct policy-related research.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Organizational Analysis for Educational Leadership
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Open only to students in Ed.D. program in Educational Leadership
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Schools of organizational theory, six frames to analyze organizations and their underlying concepts, organizational change and leadership for change, and rationale for reframing organizations.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Educational Leadership Inquiry I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Open only to students in EdD Program in Educational Leadership
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course focuses on change, diversity, and ethics in educational leadership and educational organizations.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Professional Seminar I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Open only to students in EdD Program in Educational Leadership
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: The intent of the course is to support students during the writing of their dissertation-in-practice. This course provides instruction in the writing and design research studies in educational settings. Topics covered will include defining a problem of practice, writing a literature review, formulation of research questions, qualitative and quantitative data collection methods, and research design.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Professional Seminar II
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Open only to students in EdD Program in Educational Leadership
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: The intent of the course is to support students during the writing of their dissertation-in-practice. This advanced course builds upon previous coursework related to the writing of the dissertation-in-practice. Topics covered will include data analytic methods, data analysis, and the interpretation and discussion of research findings. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Leadership Theory and Practice
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Open only to students in Ed.D. Program in Educational Leadership
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: An advanced study of leadership theories, concepts, and inquiry as applied to educational organizations. Explores power and authority in organizations, leader effectiveness, and organizational reform.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Policy Analysis for Educational Leadership
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Open only to students in Ed.D. Program in Ed. Leadership
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Analysis and investigation of educational policy utilizing various knowledge bases; organizational politics and culture's impact on policy processes; interpretation and application of policy-making activities.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Content and Context of Learning
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Open only to students in Ed.D. Program in Educational Leadership
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Students develop the knowledge and skills for examining designing, and implementing organizational, classroom, and training conditions that support quality learning experiences for learners.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Internship in Educational Leadership and Policy Analysis
Quantitative Tools for Applied Research in Educational Leadership
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Only students in the Statewide Cooperative Ed.D. program in Educational Leadership can enroll
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: General introduction to quantitative methods of data analysis. Develop concepts of measurement, design, and analysis.  The focus is on data driven decision marking and using various quantitative methods to investigate problems of educational leadership practice. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Qualitative Tools for Applied Research in Educational Leadership
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Restricted to students in the Statewide Cooperative Ed.D. Program in Educational Leadership
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Students will learn about a number of qualitative research designs that leaders can use to critically examine research questions in their practice. They will also learn to analyze educational issues and execute processes to effectively explore those issues. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Program Evaluation and Planning for Educational Leaders
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Only students in the Statewide Cooperative Ed.D. Program in Educational Leadership can enroll
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Participants develop thorough knowledge of theoretical underpinnings of selected approaches to program planning and evaluation and their necessary integration. Affords participants the opportunity to plan, conduct and deliver the results of a program evaluation to actual client. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Qualitative Methods in Educational Research II
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as ESC_PS 9620 and LTC 9620).  This course constructs a conceptual and methodological bridge between the understandings of qualitative research developed in Qualitative Methods I and more advanced study of theories, designs, and methods.  The focus is on theory, approaches to data analysis, and interpretation.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Experiencing Cultural Diversity in the United States
Inquiry into Learning I - Field Experience
Inquiry into Learning I - Field Experience - Honors
Problems in Educational, School, and Counseling Psychology
African-American Psychology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as BL_STU 3100 and PSYCH 3880). The research, theories and paradigms developed to understand the attitudes, behaviors and psychosocial realities of African-Americans are discussed.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Seminar in Educational, School, and Counseling Psychology
Health Behavior: Drug and Sexuality Education
Positive Psychology - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Using self-actualization and self-determination theory, the course builds on identifying personal strengths in people.  An emphasis is placed on developing interventions that promote positive thinking.  Some sections graded on either A-F or S/U basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Exploring Mental Health Issues in Schools
MU Youth Development Academy: Positive Youth Development in Practice
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Restricted to upper level (junior/senior standing) students
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with ESC_PS 7575). This course prepares students to apply principles of positive youth development to practice, including leading youth programs, developing organizational and community systems that support youth, and engaging others to create positive environments in which youth ages 5-19 grow, thrive, and make successful transitions to adulthood. Course topics include ages and stages of development, experiential learning, program planning, diversity and inclusion, youth/adult partnerships, volunteer systems, risk management, community partnerships, and creating environments for healthy relationships. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Foundation of Teacher Prep I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Designed for graduate students seeking teacher certification, this course addresses content and application in comprehensive classroom management, development, behavior management, and diversity. Field work is required and integrated with course content.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Seminar in Educational, School, and Counseling Psychology
Human Learning
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: An introduction to the basic principles of learning. Focus is on principles of learning which have the greatest utility for professional educators. This course provides a foundation for more advanced courses in human learning. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Theories and Techniques of Counseling
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Survey of contemporary theories underlying individual, feminist, family systems, and multicultural approaches to counseling.  Introduction to professional and ethical issues in Counseling Psychology.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Parent Counseling and Consultation
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: For personnel working with parents in professional settings. Examines current family needs and child-rearing practices. Basic skills in diagnosis, counseling, consultation, parent education are developed.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Child and Adolescent Development in Schools
Introduction to Applied Statistics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Introduces statistical techniques including descriptive statistics, correlation, simple regression and hypothesis testing. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Health Behaviors: Drug and Sexuality Education
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: ESC_PS 7195; Restricted Positive Coaching degree seeking students (distance students) or permission of department
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Psychological, social and physical factors related to drug taking and sexuality behaviors.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Sport and Applied Coaching Psychology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Restricted Positive Coaching degree seeking students (distance students) or permission of department
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Sport and Applied Coaching Psychology is a fusion of positive psychology and sport psychology. Positive psychology teaches coaches a healthy approach based in positive motivation and behavior modeling. Sport psychology helps coaches identify with the mental training of athletes and its role in delivering maximum performance. Course focus is on helping coaches maximize the potential of their athletes and teams, while also building upon their emotional and psychological wellbeing.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Development of Character and Talent Strengths
MU Youth Development Academy: Positive Youth Development in Practice
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: restricted to graduate students (Master's and PhD)Recommended: Prior course work in education, human development, family studies, sociology, social work, or other child and youth-related programs is highly preferred
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with ESC_PS 4575).  This course prepares students to apply principles of positive youth development to practice, including leading youth programs, developing organizational and community systems that support youth, and engaging others to create positive environments in which youth ages 5-19 grow, thrive, and make successful transitions to adulthood. Course topics include ages and stages of development, experiential learning, program planning, diversity and inclusion, youth/adult partnerships, volunteer systems, risk management, community partnerships, and creating environments for healthy relationships. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Overview of Research Methods
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Survey of research design and methods of data collection for masters, educational specialists, and doctoral students.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Lifespan Development
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: A comprehensive analysis of normal development across the lifespan with a primary focus on children and adolescents. Will investigate the cognitive, affective, academic, physical, moral, social/cultural/racial, religious/spiritual and sexual domains. Examples of atypical development will be discussed.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Ethical and Legal Issues in Psychological Practice
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: ESC_PS 4120 or ESC_PS 7120 or instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Legal and ethical concepts and issues relevant to the practice of psychology and student personnel services.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Foundations of Educational and Psychological Measurement
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: ESC_PS 4170 or ESC_PS 7170 or instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Basic principles of educational and psychological measurement including test construction, validity, reliability, item analysis, and derived scores.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Problems in Educational, School, and Counseling Psychology
Seminar in Educational, School, and Counseling Psychology
Master's Thesis in Educational, School, and Counseling Psychology
Research in Educational, School, and Counseling Psychology
Psychological Assessment of Children and Adolescents: Cognitive Assessment
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Basic principles in intelligence theory and intermediate measurement concepts.  Practice in administering, scoring, and interpretation of data from individually administered intelligence tests with school aged children and adolescents. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Methods in Group Counseling
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: ESC_PS 8040, demonstrated knowledge of ethical principles and departmental consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Study of group counseling methods and techniques. Participation in a group is required.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Psychological Assessment of Children and  Adolescents:Psychoeducational Assessment
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Practice in administering, scoring, and interpretation of data from academic achievement, nonverbal intelligence, memory, adaptive behavior, and perceptual/motor assessments with school-age youth and adolescents.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Professional Iss. in Sch. Psych. I:Hist., Trends & Ethical Pract.
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Must be admitted to school psychology program
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: For first-year doctoral students in school psychology. History, current issues, trends, professional organizations, legal-ethical standards of doctoral level school psychology are discussed. The scientist-practitioner model and scientific reasoning process as they apply to both science and practice are reviewed.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Psychological Assessment of Adults
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Students develop and practice skills in writing psychological reports with special emphasis on assessing psychological social-vocational functioning.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Foundations of Career Psychology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Theoretical orientations to counseling for career development; nature and structure of work, education, and leisure; work and family issues; career concerns of special populations; use of career information in counseling.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Psychological Assessment in Children and Adolescents: Behavior and Social Emotional Assessment
Psychological Interventions with Children and Adolescents: Behavioral  Intervention
Crisis Prevention, Intervention, and Response in Schools
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: The course provides students with basic knowledge, theoretical frameworks, and skills/strategies for crisis prevention, intervention, response, and recovery in school and community settings, with a primary focus on addressing the mental health needs.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Psychological Interventions with Children and Adolescents: Educational Instruction
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course investigates models of school instruction in both general and special education, and how instruction can be adapted for learners who exhibit a range of academic and psychological problems and disabling conditions.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Psychological Interventions with Children and Adolescents: Evidence-Based Therapies
Applied Behavior Analysis: Principles, Assessment, and Evaluation
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course is designed to provide students with an understanding of operant conditioning principles and concepts, single-case design methodology, and behavior analytic assessments and evaluation.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Applied Positive Coaching
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: ESC_PS 7195; Restricted Positive Coaching degree seeking students (distance students) or permission of department
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Explores concepts of sport, coaching and positive psychology, particularly the interventions and applications designed to further develop a coach's philosophy, communication skills, understanding of motivation, leadership skills, and the coach's and athlete's well-being.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Applied Positive Psychology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course will require students to implement positive psychology concepts from the introductory course into their personal, professional, and/or social lives. We will also study specific ways in which these concepts and theories are being applied throughout various realms of well-being. Among the topics in this course are therapeutic lifestyles, goal-setting and attainment, self-care, meaning making, transformational leadership, influence and sustainable happiness theory.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Foundations of Sport Performance
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Restricted Positive Coaching degree seeking students (distance students) or permission of department
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Focuses on principles and methods to become an effective sport performance coach. Examines the development of athletes and education of basic sports nutrition, strength, and conditioning.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Sport in America
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Sociological perspectives of sport in America. Attention given to the influence of society on sport as in institution, and the role of sport as an agent of social change.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Legal Aspects of Sport and Coaching
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Restricted Positive Coaching degree seeking students (distance students) or permission of department
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Emphasis is to provide insight about how the law is applied is sport settings, the types of litigation involved, and the standard of care required. Fundamental terminology and concepts, and contemporary issues in sport law will be addressed.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Administration of Athletic Programs
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Restricted Positive Coaching degree seeking students (distance students) or permission of department
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Examines methods, principles, and roles of athletic administrators. Also, examines the job responsibilities and competencies required of sport leaders in athletic administration.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Student-Athlete Wellbeing
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Restricted Positive Coaching degree seeking students (distance students) or permission of departmentRecommended: ESC_PS 7200 Positive Psychology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: The Theory of Well-being will guide our study as we examine: (a) the physical, mental, and social "energies" of athlete well-being and (b) well-being in the context of athlete support services provided by the school or organization. Positive Coaches and Athletic Leaders will analyze their character strengths as a foundation to build a unique well-being model specific to their athletes' well-being needs. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Resiliency, Grit and Mental Toughness
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Restricted to Positive Coaching degree seeking students or permission of department
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course is intended to help coaches and leaders understand the scientific constructs of grit and resiliency and how to develop it within individuals and group settings for the purpose of peak performance. Course objective will be met first by critically debunking the construct of mental toughness and then exploring resiliency and grit within the context of performance domains. Content will come in part from case study analysis of real-life scenarios from coaching and leadership arenas, case studies provided by student experiences, and applied evidence-based interventions. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Coaching for Inclusive Excellence
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Restricted Positive Coaching degree seeking students (distance students) or permission of department
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Coaching for inclusive excellence is an increasingly important practice for Positive Coaches and Athletic Leaders. As we build connection and foster relationships with our athletes, it is our responsibility to recognize the role identity plays to individual well-being and performance. Therefore, Positive Coaches and Athletic Leaders must (re)commit to inclusive coaching and leadership practices to foster a sense of community among all athletes in order to work toward individual and collective performance and well-being goals. Coaching for Inclusive Excellence explores culture, race, gender identities, and sexual identities to more closely understand athletes lived experiences. By recognizing our own biases, or blind spots, coaches and athletic leaders will build organizational cultures where athletes of all identities feel valued and capable.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Psychology of the Injured Athlete
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Restricted to Positive Coaching degree seeking students or permission of department
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course will cover the psychological, emotional, and behavioral responses athletes' encounter during injury by teaching students about the cognitive appraisal cycle an athlete goes through while being injured.  Objective will be to understand injury from as a contextual intelligence lens where individual appraisal drives emotional and behavioral responses to injury.  Case study format will be utilized, including real-life scenarios experienced by athletes with the intention of helping coaches understand how to best address the psychoemotional health of their injured athletes through their return to sport.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Multicultural Issues in Sport
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Restricted Positive Coaching degree seeking students (distance students) or permission of department
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: The purpose of this course is to increase the level of multicultural awareness, knowledge, skills, and relationship of athletic coaches working with diverse student populations. Activities and assignments are designed to assist, encourage, and challenge each student to more fully develop awareness and knowledge of self, and to use this information to improve intercultural interactions with others in professional settings as well as other settings.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Character and Ethics in Sport
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Restricted to Positive Coaching degree seeking students or permission of department
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course is designed to develop students' skills and knowledge regarding principled character leadership and development, ethics, and values in sport. The course will use values-based leadership from Acceptance-Commitment Therapy and other leadership philosophies as a framework for integrating ethics and core values into the sport and leadership environment. Particular emphasis will be placed on ethical codes and regulations at both the collegiate and scholastic levels. Learning will be provided through text readings, personal evaluations/analysis, current issues in sport, video review, case studies, interviews, and collaborative discussions. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Cognition, Learning and Instruction
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Examines the topics of memory and cognition as they apply to the process of learning and instruction.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Advanced Counseling Theories and Interventions
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Contemporary theories and interventions of counseling.  Advanced study of efficacious techniques. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Analysis of Research in Career Psychology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Examination of career development theories, the research supporting the theories, and the practical application of these ideas in career counseling and career programs.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to School Counseling
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Provides knowledge and skills in the development and management of school counseling programs including program planning, structuring, implementing, and evaluating.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Program Evaluation for School Counselors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Program Evaluation is a graduate seminar intended to provide students with the skills needed to evaluate comprehensive guidance and counseling programs.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Effects of Maltreatment on Child and Adolescent Development
Mental, Emotional, and Behavioral Disorders in Youth
School Mental Health: Policy, Law and Ethics
Building Resiliency and Optimism in Youth
Diversity Issues in School Mental Health
Bully and Youth Violence: Prevention and Reduction
Communication and Collaboration with Children and Families
Vital Issues in School Mental Health
Preventions and Interventions in School Mental Health
Mental Health in Schools Capstone Paper
Sport Psychology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Current topics of research in sport psychology are examined. Topics include: sport personality, attention, activation and anxiety intervention, motivation, sport aggression, audience effects, team cohesion, leadership, and health psychology.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Diversity and Multiculturalism II - Practical Application
African American Education - Historic and Current Issues
Gay, Lesbian and Bisexual Issues in the Schools
Multicultural Counseling Competencies: Theory and Research
Item Response Theory
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Introduces modern scaling with Item Response Theory, and includes how it can be used to statistically specify information about latent variables and the stimuli (e.g., tests) used to represent them.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Educational Planning and Evaluation
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course addresses major issues and models used in educational program planning and evaluation, including the appropriate use of various evaluation models and different types of data.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Life/Career Coaching and Development
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Designed to teach life and career coaching strategies with roots in career psychology and positive psychology.  It provides the tools and knowledge on how to coach people to achieve their personal and professional goals.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Meaning In Work
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Covers a broad look at meaning and vocation using theoretical and empirical frameworks.  Also explores the influence of culture, environment, relationships and personal values on meaning development while providing a framework for working from a coaching/counseling standpoint to help others identify or develop meaningful vocations.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Community and Stewardship
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Examines the concepts of community and stewardship, explores the literal roots of the word (common-unity) and our ability to respond (responsibility) to and build our communities.  Also explores the connections between altruism, personal well-being, and social stewardship.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Positive Organizational Psychology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Surveys the impact of positive organizational psychology research throughout professional organizations.  Students will learn empirically defined elements of positive work environments and learn the building blocks associated with this field including: Appreciative Inquiry, the Abundance Approach, Strengths-Based Organizations, Positive Work Environments, and Employee Engagement and Satisfaction.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Quantitative Foundations in Educational Research
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course is designed to provide students the fundamental and necessary quantitative methods skills in educational research. Topics include one-way and factorial analysis of variance (ANOVA), analysis of covariance (ANCOVA), repeated measures ANOVA, random-effects ANOVA, simple linear regression, multiple regression, regression diagnostics, introduction to logistic regression, and statistical power analysis. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Statistical Data Management and Analysis in Educational Research
Qualitative Methods in Educational Research I
Advanced History and Systems of Psychology
Doctoral Dissertation Educational School & Counseling Psychology
Advanced Psychological Measurement and Assessment
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Introduction to the scientific and psychometric foundations of clinical assessment, including measurement theory, reliability, validity, and scale/test construction. Primary focus on the development and validation of evidence-based, psychometrically-sound assessment tools. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Professional Iss. in Sch. Psych. II: Rsrch. Design & Application
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Must be admitted to school psychology doctoral program
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: For first-year doctoral students in school psychology. Includes study of research design and methodological issues in the field of school psychology.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Prevention Science Research Design and Analysis
Theories and Practices in Supervision
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: ESC_PS 8940 or ESC_PS 8944 and instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Instruction and practice in the supervision of psychological services conducted in appropriate laboratories and agencies. Sections titled Counseling Psychology are graded on S/U basis only. Sections titled School Psychology are on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Motivation
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Investigates human motivation applied to performance in schools, athletics, and personal life.  Topics include goals, attributions, self-efficacy, interest, cultural differences, and rewards. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Scientific Fdns of Counseling Psych I: Prof Iss &
Scientific Foundations of Counseling Psych II: Rsrch, Dsgn & Appl
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: For first-year doctoral students in applied psychology. Includes study of research design and methodological issues in the field of counseling psychology.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Scientific Writing in Counseling Psychology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: ESC_PS 9530 and ESC_PS 9540 and instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course focuses on the technical skills needed for developing a scientific research proposal in counseling psychology.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Applied Sport Psychology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Building upon the knowledge base of sport psychology, this course integrates and synthesizes student's understandings of the wide array of concepts and theories of the field into meaningful applications and strategies aimed at enhancing the sport experience of others. A case study approach will be employed.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Qualitative Methods in Educational Research II
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as ED_LPA 9620 and LTC 9620). This course constructs a conceptual and methodological bridge between the understandings of qualitative research developed in Qualitative Methods I and more advanced study of theories, designs, and methods.  The focus is on theory, approaches to data analysis, and interpretation.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to Theory of Educational Measurement
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Classical and modern test theory, including IRT, generalizability theory and test bias. Also covered are advanced strategies for investigating reliability and validity.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Application of Multivariate Analysis in Educational Research
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: The focus of this course will be on applications of multivariate analysis in educational research.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Generalized Linear Modeling
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: ESC_PS 8850Recommended: Familiarity with the basics of the R statistical programing environment (see www.r-project.org) is assumed
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course is designed to introduce students to the theory and application of generalized linear models (GLMs). GLMs provide a flexible generalization of the ordinary linear regression model. While the latter is restricted to continuous dependent variables (with normal error term), the GLM framework has been developed to analyze dependent variables that are, e.g., binary, polytomous nominal, ordinal, counted, censored, or bounded continuous. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Structural Equation Modeling
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Simultaneous analysis of relationships among variables.  Topics included are path analysis, confirmatory factor analysis, hybrid models, and special types of structural models involving longitudinal data, multiple groups and analysis of means. May be repeated for credit.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Hierarchical Linear Modeling
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Hierarchical Linear Modeling (HLM), including multilevel and longitudinal approaches, in applied research settings for the social, educational psychological, and health-related sciences. May be repeated for credit.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to Electrical  and Computer Engineering
Circuit Theory I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: A grade of C- or better in MATH 1700
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: DC circuit analysis, inductors and capacitors, first order response, AC circuit analysis, single-phase AC power. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to Logic Systems
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: C or higher in CMP_SC 1050 or INFOTC 1040
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as CMP_SC 2270). Introduces basic tools, methods and procedures to design combinational and sequential digital circuits and systems.  Topics include number systems, Boolean algebra, logic minimization, circuit design, memory elements, and finite state machine design.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Microprocessor Engineering for Electrical Engineers
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: A grade of C or better in CMP_SC 1050 and ECE 2210 or CMP_SC 2270
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Introduction to microprocessor architectures and programming; memory, memory management and cache organizations, bus configurations and timing implications; parallel I/O and serial communication interfaces.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Software Design in C and C++
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: ECE 3280 or CMP_SC 3280 or ECE 3210 with a grade of C or better
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Software/Hardware development for embedded systems, including memory, I/O and interrupts; an overview of C and C++, class structures in object oriented programming; software development with UML and testing and debugging strategies. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Computer Organization and Assembly Language
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: C or higher in CMP_SC 2270 or ECE 2210, and C or higher in CMP_SC 2050
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as CMP_SC 3280). Introduces computer architectures, programming concepts including parameter passing, I/O interrupt handling, DMA, memory systems, cache, and virtual memory. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Electromagnetic Fields
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: A grade of C- or better in PHYSCS 2760 and a grade of C or better in ECE 2100Corequisites: MATH 4100
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Elements of vector analysis, transmission line theory, electrostatics, magnetostatics, time varying fields and plane waves. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Semiconductors and Devices
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: A grade of C or better in ECE 3510
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Crystal structure; quantum aspects of energy, radiation and matter; quantum mechanics and energy bands in solids; electronic and optical properties of semiconductors; p-n junctions and diodes; bipolar and field-effect transistors.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Circuit Theory II
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: A grade of C or better in ECE 2100Corequisites: MATH 4100
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Impulse and step responses, RLC circuits, classical differential equations solutions, complex plane stability, frequency and Bode Analysis, Resonance, Laplace transforms, two-port networks, mutual inductance and transformers.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Signals and Linear Systems
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: A grade of C or better in ECE 3810
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Transform Analysis of Signals and Linear Systems. Laplace transforms, z-transforms, Fourier series and transforms.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Measurement and Instrumentation
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: A grade of C or better ECE 3210 or ECE 3280, ECE 3410, ECE 3830, and a grade of C- or better in STAT 4710Corequisites: ECE 4960W
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Covers 1) theory and applications of measurement and instrumentation systems; 2) signal conditioning circuits; 3) software-controlled automatic test equipment (ATE); and 4) software-controlled data acquisition systems. Graded on an A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Topics in Electrical and Computer Engineering
Energy Systems and Resources
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as NU_ENG 4315, MAE 4371; cross-leveled with ECE 7020, NU_ENG 7315). Analysis of present energy usage in Missouri, USA and the world, evaluation of emerging energy technologies and trends for the future. Economics and environmental impact of the developed technologies.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Engineering
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as NU_ENG 4346; cross-leveled with ECE 7030, NU_ENG 7346). Engineering principles of nuclear power systems, primarily for the production of electrical energy.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to Nuclear Physics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: senior standing or graduate standing in engineering or equivalent mathematical preparation
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with ECE 7040). Introduction of Quantum mechanics for non-physics majors.  Course topics include nuclear properties; alpha, beta and gamma radioactive decay; and nuclear reactions. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Numerical Methods for Science and Engineering
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: CMP_SC 2050, junior standing, or Instructor's consentRecommended: Students are expected to have basic knowledge in discrete math and algorithms
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as CMP_SC 4070; cross-leveled with ECE 7070, CMP_SC 7070). This course introduces the basic numerical methods that are widely used by computer scientists and engineers. Students will learn how to use the MATLAB platform to find the computational solution of various problems arising in many real world applications. By completing this course, students will be able to master algorithms, compare their performances and critically assess which ones are viable options for the particular problem at hand. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Parallel Programming for High Performance Computing
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: CMP_SC 3280 or ECE 3210 and CMP_SC 3050 or ECE 3220
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as CMP_SC 4080; cross-leveled with ECE 7080, CMP_SC 7080). This course will provide in-depth treatment of the evolution high performance computing architectures and parallel programming techniques for those architectures. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Problems in Electrical and Computer Engineering
Real Time Embedded Computing
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: A grade of C or better in ECE 3220
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with ECE 7220). Embedded systems development with real time constraints including RTOS, task management and synchronization, real time scheduling algorithms, deadlocks, performance analysis and optimization, interfacing to external devices, and device drivers. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: VHDL and Programmable Logic Devices
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: ECE 3210 or ECE 3280 or CMP_SC 3280 with a grade of C or better
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with ECE 7250). Design techniques including module definition, functional partitioning, hardware design language descriptions and microprogramming; design examples include arithmetic units, programmable controllers, and microprocessors.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Computer Architecture
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: CMP_SC 2050 and ECE 3280 or CMP_SC 3280 or ECE 3210 with a grade of C or better
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as CMP_SC 4270; cross-leveled with ECE 7270, CMP_SC 7270). Advanced computer architectures and programming; memory, memory management and cache organizations, parallel processing, graphical processor units for general programming.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Network Systems Architecture
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: C- or higher in CMP_SC 2050 or ECE 3220 and C- or higher in CMP_SC 3280 or ECE 3210
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as CMP_SC 4280; cross-leveled with ECE 7280, CMP_SC 7280). The course covers network systems interconnects and switch fabrics, network considerations: and relevant networking applications at the network, transport and application layer.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Feedback Control Systems
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as BIOL_EN 4310, MAE 4750; cross-leveled with BIOL_EN 7310, ECE 7310, MAE 7750). System modeling and time and frequency response, closed loop control, stability, continuous system design, introduction to discrete time control, software and hardware experiments on compensator design and PID control.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Architectural Robotics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with ECE 7320). Architectural robotics has been defined as "intelligent and adaptable built environments (featuring embedded robotic components) that sense, plan, and act". This course will cover the basic concepts required for understanding, developing, and testing embedded robotic systems for the built environment. Students will work together in teams in a studio-style format which emphasizes hands-on projects to develop working prototypes. The goal is to offer students an opportunity for creativity in an interdisciplinary setting.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to Mechatronics and Robotic Vision
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: ECE 3220 or ECE 4220Recommended: a C/C++ languages
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with ECE 7330). Covers 1) mechatronic systems; 2) the mathematical tools used to model industrial and mobile robots; and 3) vision sensors, their underlying models and algorithms that allow us to control and interact with robots.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Building Intelligent Robots
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as CMP_SC 4730; cross-leveled with ECE 7340, CMP_SC 7740). Covers the design and development of intelligent machines, emphasizing topics related to sensor-based control of mobile robots.  Includes mechanics and motor control, sensor characterization, reactive behaviors and control architectures.   Recommended:  programming experience in one of the following programming languages: Basic , C, C++, or Java.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Programmable Logic Controllers
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with ECE 7350). Hardware and software aspects of PLC's; computer/PLC Communications; developing ladder logic programs; interfacing I/O devices, including sensors, to the PLC; labeling and documentation; utilizing analog capabilities; applications; developing Supervisory Control and Data Acquisitions (SCADA) applications.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Power Electronics I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with ECE 7410). Power electronic device characteristics, important circuit and component concepts, loss mechanisms and thermal analysis, phase controlled rectifiers, dc-dc converters, and dc-ac inverters. Includes laboratory projects.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Electronic Circuits and Signals II
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with ECE 7430). Advanced study of electronic devices including frequency response of amplifiers, nonlinear effects in transistor amplifiers, oscillators, and feedback amplifiers.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Power Systems Analysis
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: ECE 3810 and MATH 4100 or instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with ECE 7440). Selected topics related to modern power system analysis.
