https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with F_S 7360). Capstone course integrating various food science disciplines to comply with regulations concerned with protection of the nation's food supply.  Applies practices to insure consumers of healthful foods.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Food Chemistry and Analysis
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with F_S 4310). Structure, composition and chemical properties of food.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with F_S 4315). The quantitative determination of the constituents of food.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with F_S 4331). Technology, chemistry, and nutrition of dairy foods as well as functional properties of dairy ingredients.

Experience problem-solving through further processing of complex ingredients and develop skills by practicing operations in a pilot plant facility.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as AN_SCI 7354; cross-leveled with F_S 4354, AN_SCI 4354). https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Food Microbiology Laboratory
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with F_S 4375). Examination of foods for microorganisms and characterization of major species.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: F_S 1030; junior or senior standingRecommended: one statistics course
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with F_S 4380). Methodological principles of the sensory analysis of food and beverages.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as AG_S_TCH 7390; cross-leveled with F_S 4390, AG_S_TCH 4390). This course is designed to introduce the student to the concept of layers and interacting systems within an operation and the analytical methods of modeling and simulation to make effective management decisions for optimal system design and function.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Principles of Winemaking and Wine Chemical Analysis
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: 5 hours inorganic chemistry and organic chemistry or concurrent, or instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with F_S 4440). The theoretical and practical basics needed by enologist/winemakers including sensory analysis of grapes; chemical, microbiological and technological aspects of winemaking; and the analytical methods used for juice and wine analysis. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Cellar Operations and Special Vinifications
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: 5 credit hours inorganic chemistry and organic chemistry and F_S 4440 or instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with F_S 4441). The theoretical and practical basics needed by winemakers to supervise the operations of the winemaking, wine stabilization and packaging equipment.  The theoretical and practical basics needed by winemakers to make special wines including rose, dessert, carbonic maceration, and sparkling wines. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Food Product Development
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Capstone course integrating the various disciplines of food science to create new food products.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Strategic Human Resource Management in Hospitality
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course is designed to familiarize students with a wide range of theories, concepts, business practices and applications associated with managing human resources in business. Topics include micro-human resource issues such as recruitment, hiring, performance measurements, employee relations, and retention, macro human resource topics such as organizational performance measurement, and interrelationship between micro and macro human resources such as individual differences and job performance and organizational performance. Students will learn the key theories and applications through reading, discussion, research, and writings. Graded on A-F only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Advanced Hospitality Marketing
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course provides students with an advanced-level view of marketing strategies with the focus in hospitality and tourism. Students will be exposed to a general overview of theoretical frameworks and seminal work in this field. They will gain appreciation of the contemporary social-scientific research on marketing and persuasion. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Strategic Management and Competitive Strategy in the Hospitality Industries
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course introduces to students and enables them to develop a comprehensive understanding of the concepts and principles of strategic management and competitive strategy as applied to the hospitality industries. Students will be acquainted with the key concepts of strategic management through discussions, research, critiquing and writings. This course will cover a wide variety of topics related to environmental scanning, strategic direction, organizational structure and culture, administration and evaluation of existing and challenging business practices, concepts and theories in the management distinctive to that of hospitality, tourism and service. Emphasis will place on the identification of relevant interdisciplinary paradigms and theory and research techniques for analysis, using advanced concepts and quantitative methods in the scientific investigation problems related to hospitality. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Theory Construction
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Graduate level research methods course or instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course focusses on theory construction in the area of hospitality management, identification of relevant interdisciplinary paradigms in theory development, and evaluation of theory and research models in the context of social science research. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Service Operations Management: Revenue Management
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course offers an opportunity for students to learn the theory, concepts, and knowledge applied in service operations management. Students will find them useful in trying to cope with the dilemmas faced by operating managers in the hospitality industry. Especially, the course focuses on revenue management.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Ethnic Foods: Food Safety, Food Protection and Defense Challenges
A Multidisciplinary Overview of Food Safety and Security
Advanced Food Microbiology and Biotechnology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: F_S 4370 or equivalent or instructor's permission
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Advanced applied food microbiology and microbial physiology, and basic principles in biotechnology and genetic engineering, including current topics of interest and case studies in food biotechnology.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Risk Assessment for Food, Agriculture and Veterinary Medicine
Food Chemistry II
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Study of chemical content of food, emphasizing aspects that exist uniquely in food.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Meat Quality
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as AN_SCI 8414). Discussion of factors affecting meat quality in beef, pork, lamb and poultry. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Meat Investigations
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as AN_SCI 8424). Discussion of literature, special reports, assigned readings, techniques, interpretation of results.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Functional Foods and Nutraceuticals
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: BIOCHM 3630 or equivalent and F_S 4310 or equivalent, or instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Principles and challenges involved in developing foods with health benefits beyond basic nutrition; efficacy, safety, regulatory and marketing aspects of functional foods and nutraceutical; current controversies and evidence of therapeutic properties of functional foods and Dietary supplements. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Advanced Food Technology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: F_S 4310, or equivalent or instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: To understand the physical and chemical changes that occur during the processing and storage of food; study the quality and safety issues of foods and learn traditional and recent advances in food science and technology.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Advanced Research Methods in Food and Hospitality Systems
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Introductory research method course or statistics course; instructor's consent required
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course provides doctoral students with introduction and review of research methods available for use in the study of food science, hospitality management and agricultural system management.  Hence, the emphasis of this course is on empirical studies in the field, and will examine research conducted by scholars in the  academic area.  This course assists as baseline preparation for graduate students' continuing work in the graduate program.  Specifically, the course provides students with knowledge and research experience in regard to 1) research fundamentals and backgrounds, 2) types of research, and 3) data analysis.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Dendrology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: BIO_SC 1200. Restricted to School of Natural Resources students (Environmental Sciences, Natural Resource Science and Management, and Parks, Recreation and Sport) during early registration. Other students may register after early registration, provided there is space available
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: An introduction to the biology of trees, emphasizing identification in the field, taxonomy, ecology, geographic distribution and economic significance of forest species.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Tree Physiology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course introduces and develops understanding of physical and chemical phenomena involved in the functions and activities of trees that produce growth.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Forest Health and Protection - Writing Intensive
Urban Forestry
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: The culture and management of trees in urban areas, including ownership patterns, species composition, growth environment, amenities provided and evaluation. One-day field trip required.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Forest Ecology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: At least sophomore standing.  Recommended FOREST 2151
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Principles of community, ecosystem, and population ecology and examination of the influence of environmental factors and human activity on forest dynamics, composition, structure and function. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Forest Ecology - Writing Intensive
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Principles of community, ecosystem, and population ecology and examination of the influence of environmental factors and human activity on forest dynamics, composition, structure and function. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Practice of Silviculture
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with FOREST 7330). Applied ecological principles, cultural practices, tree improvement techniques and treatments to forest stands and other lands for systematic production of goods and services.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Forest Economics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Economic principles applied to production/marketing of goods and services from forest land: emphasizes capital and land factors and investment alternatives related to time.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Forest Resource Management
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: FOREST 4330 and FOREST 4350; Senior Standing only
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Teaches resource managers how to develop a plan for the management of forest resources using managerial, economic, silvical and wildlife techniques for its enhancement and to meet the landowner's objectives.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Forest Resource Management-Writing Intensive
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: FOREST 4330 and FOREST 4350; Senior Standing only
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Teaches resource managers how to develop a plan for the management of forest resources using managerial, economic, silvical and wildlife techniques for its enhancement and to meet the landowner's objectives.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Agroforestry I: Theory, Practice and Adoption
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Understand biophysical, ecological, social and economic features of temperate and tropical agroforestry. Covers the basics of design, planning and implementation of agroforestry practices.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Watershed Management and Water Quality
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with FOREST 7390). Hydrologic processes on wildland watersheds. Effects of forest land management on streamflow, erosion and water quality.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Experiential Learning in Industry Internship in Forestry
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Learning experience combining observation, application, and reflection in a discipline-based industry internship. Course appears on transcript for zero credit and does not count toward full-time enrollment. No tuition or fees are charged. Graded on S/U basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Experiential Learning in Research in Forestry
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: A supervised learning experience contributing to faculty research. Course appears on transcript for zero credit and does not count toward full-time enrollment. No tuition or fees are charged. Graded on S/U basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Forest Ecology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: FOREST 2151 or BIO_SC 3210 or instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with FOREST 4320). Principles of community, ecosystem, and population ecology and examination of the influence of environmental factors and human activity on forest dynamics, composition, structure and function.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Practice of Silviculture
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with FOREST 4330). Applied ecological principles, cultural practices, tree improvement techniques and treatments to forest stands and other lands for systematic production of goods and services.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Forest Economics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Mathematics requirement completed; ABM 1042 or ABM 1041 or ABM 2070
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with FOREST 4350).  Economic principles applied to production/marketing of goods and services from forest land: emphasizes capital and land factors and investment alternatives related to time.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Forest Stand Dynamics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with FOREST 4375). Examines the development of forest structure, the role of disturbance on forest change and the use of this knowledge in applying silvicultural systems. Both forest stand dynamics theories, structure diagrams, forest growth models, and long term data sets are used to understand stand dynamics.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Forest Resource Management
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with FOREST 4380). Teaches resource managers how to develop a plan for the management of forest resources using managerial, economic, silvical and wildlife techniques for its enhancement and to meet the landowner's objectives.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Agroforestry I: Theory, Practice and Adoption
Watershed Management and Water Quality
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with FOREST 4390). Hydrologic processes on wildland watersheds. Effects of forest land management on streamflow, erosion and water quality.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Ecological Principles of Agroforestry
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: FOREST 4385 or FOREST 7385 or permission of instructor
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: The course prepares students to develop an understanding of the complexity of agroforestry.  Students will critically analyze classical and contemporary ecological theories and apply them in designing agroforestry practices to solve complex production and environmental issues.   May be repeated for credit.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Physical Hydrology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Students will obtain an understanding of hydrologic processes in terms of the occurrence, distribution and movement of water spanning the atmosphere and lithosphere.  Students will have an opportunity to develop an understanding of physical processes governing mass and energy flux in wildland and anthropogenic systems.  May be repeated for credit. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Agroforestry Economics and Policy
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: FOREST 4385 or FOREST 7385, ABM 1041 or permission of instructor
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course discusses basic economic and financial principles, and their applications in agroforestry. Specifically, the discussion includes market demand and supply, market failure, non-market valuations, cost and benefit analysis, short term and long term economic analysis, economic valuation of ecosystem services, and the applications in agroforestry. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Applied Silviculture
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Ecological and economic factors affecting application of silviculture in each of eighteen forest regions in United States.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Forest Soils
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Physical, chemical and biological properties of forest soils in relation to tree growth.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Advanced Forest Management
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Modern quantitative methods to facilitate decision-making in harvest scheduling and regulation, land use allocation, and production planning in natural resource management.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Advanced Forest Biometrics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: An introduction to the topics and philosophy of ecological modeling. The course will guide students through the process of developing a conceptual model, formalizing the model, formulating, parameterizing, and running the model as well as analyzing the results.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Ecosystem Management: The Human Dimension
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Overview of cultural, social, political and economic dimensions of natural resource problems and issues from an ecologically grounded management perspective.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Elementary French I - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: FRENCH 1100 is a beginning French course and the first course of the beginning language sequence, but many students will have had 1 or 2 years of high school French. It places emphasis on communicating, with students using all four skills--listening, speaking, reading, and writing. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Elementary French II - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Honors eligibility requiredRecommended: Grade in the B range or better in FRENCH 1100 or equivalent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as FRENCH 1200). The second course of the beginning language sequence is the continuation of FRENCH 1100.  It places equal emphasis on communicating using listening, speaking, reading, and writing. Students who have prior knowledge of French are encouraged to take this course.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Elementary French III - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: grade in the B range or better in FRENCH 1200, or equivalent course. Honors eligibility required
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: A multi-skill course following FRENCH 1200, centering on cultural/ literary reading, and including a grammar review, practice of the spoken language, as well as practice in written expression.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Intermediate French Composition and Conversation
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: A course designed to develop the ability to speak, read, and write in French via the reading of French short stories and/or a short novel. Grammar review.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: French Civilization
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Open to any student interested. No knowledge of French required. May not be included in area of concentration in French.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: French Civilization - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Open to any student interested. No knowledge of French required. May not be included in area of concentration in French.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: French Civilization - Writing Intensive
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Open to any student interested. No knowledge of French required. May not be included in area of concentration in French.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: French Literature and Thought in English Translation I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course examines how the masterworks of French literature, from the Middle Ages to the eighteenth century, have influenced Western literary, cultural and philosophical traditions.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: French Literature in Translation II
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course examines how the masterworks of French literature of the nineteenth and twentieth centuries have influenced Western literary, cultural and philosophical traditions.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: New World Francophone Literature in Translation
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: A survey of literature written by Caribbean writers of French expression. Writers include M. Conde, P. Chamoiseau, A. Cesaire, E. Glissant, S. Bart-Schwartz, R. Depestre and G. Etienne.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: French Cinema
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course will introduce to students to a variety of French cinematic genres, periods, and styles. Students will explore social, historical, political and cultural contexts of selected films in order to enhance their analysis of visual, ideological and thematic elements. Each semester's topic (e.g, "The French New Wave," "French Film History," "French Direct Cinema and Cinema Verite," and "French Film noir," etc.) announced at time of registration. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Advanced French Composition and Conversation I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Development of more sophisticated skills of written and oral expression.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Advanced French Composition and Conversation I - Writing Intensive
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Development of more sophisticated skills of written and oral expression.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Les Fondations de la Civilisation Francaise
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Overview of French civilization from its origins to French Revolution.  Studies will examine key cultural objects from art, literature, and popular culture as well as political and historical movements that have shaped development of French civilization.  Ideal for students interested in engaging with issues, debates, and problems that helped to define the nascent French state.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Commercial French
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Composition and Conversation course based on materials related to the French business world. Acquisition of business-related vocabulary. Introduction to French business operations and correspondence.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Intro a la pensee critique / Introduction to Critical Analysis
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Students will acquire skills and vocabulary to develop and defend critical perspectives in French, using studies of literature, media, and popular culture.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to French Culture
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course provides a general introduction to cultural analysis in French. Exploration of a variety of sources from film and literature, social media, and objects of material culture in order to analyze key moments in French cultural history.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to French Culture - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: FRENCH 3160 and FRENCH 3410; Honors eligibility required
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course provides a general introduction to cultural analysis in French. Exploration of a variety of sources from film and literature, social media, and objects of material culture in order to analyze key moments in French cultural history.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to French Culture - Writing Intensive
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course provides a general introduction to cultural analysis in French.   Students will employ a variety of sources from film and literature, along with social media and objects of material culture to revisit and analyze key moments in French cultural history.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: French Masterworks: Texts and Contexts
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course will prepare students to analyze masterworks of French expression and develop an understanding of the historical and literary contexts in which they were written. It will also promote a deeper awareness of the French-speaking world's cultural specificity and diversity. Tracking texts across time periods (medieval to present) and, on occasion, across continents as well (Africa, Canada, the Caribbean), students will focus on how literary expression responds to cultural crises and consider how writers deal with issues of gender, race, ideology, class and/or self-actualization. As they make their way through a select group of works, students will have the opportunity to hone their language skills in all four fundamental areas (speaking, listening, reading comprehension, and writing). Beyond the scope of literary texts, reference to a variety of visual arts will inform and enhance class discussion.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: French Masterworks: Texts and Contexts - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course will prepare students to analyze masterworks of French expression and develop an understanding of the historical and literary contexts in which they were written. It will also promote a deeper awareness of the French-speaking world's cultural specificity and diversity. Tracking texts across time periods (medieval to present) and, on occasion, across continents as well (Africa, Canada, the Caribbean), students will focus on how literary expression responds to cultural crises and consider how writers deal with issues of gender, race, ideology, class and/or self-actualization. As they make their way through a select group of works, students will have the opportunity to hone their language skills in all four fundamental areas (speaking, listening, reading comprehension, and writing). Beyond the scope of literary texts, reference to a variety of visual arts will inform and enhance class discussion.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: French Masterworks: Texts and Contexts - Writing Intensive
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course will prepare students to analyze masterworks of French expression and develop an understanding of the historical and literary contexts in which they were written. It will also promote a deeper awareness of the French-speaking world's cultural specificity and diversity. Tracking texts across time periods (medieval to present) and, on occasion, across continents as well (Africa, Canada, the Caribbean), students will focus on how literary expression responds to cultural crises and consider how writers deal with issues of gender, race, ideology, class and/or self-actualization. As they make their way through a select group of works, students will have the opportunity to hone their language skills in all four fundamental areas (speaking, listening, reading comprehension, and writing). Beyond the scope of literary texts, reference to a variety of visual arts will inform and enhance class discussion.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Francophone Literature of North America
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: A survey course of Francophone literature of New France, Louisiana territory and the French West Indies from its beginnings in the seventeenth century to the late twentieth century.  Selected novels, poems and plays will be studied in their historical and social context.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Survey of Minority and Creole Languages of the U.S. and the Caribbean
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as SPAN 3710 and LINGST 3710). Analysis of the state of the minority languages of the U.S. and the Creole languages of the Caribbean with particular attention to the social status of these languages and speakers' attitudes toward them in the context of ethnic, cultural and national identity (taught in English).

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Intensive Beginning French
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Rapid acquisition of a reading knowledge of French. Cannot be taken to fulfill undergraduate language requirement.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Foreign Language Teaching Methodology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as SPAN 4120, LATIN 4121; cross-leveled with FRENCH 7120, SPAN 7120). Theory and techniques of current foreign language methodology and their application in the classroom. Presentation of instructional projects, classroom observations, and strategies for classroom management. May not be used toward Arts and Science major.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Stylistics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: FRENCH 3160 or FRENCH 3280Recommended: FRENCH 3420, FRENCH 3430 or FRENCH 3410
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with FRENCH 7130). A technical study of French as a means of communication and of self-expression, involving levels of meaning, rhetorical structure, and textual analysis.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Stylistics - Writing Intensive
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: FRENCH 3160 or FRENCH 3280Recommended: FRENCH 3420, FRENCH 3430 or FRENCH 3410
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: A technical study of French as a means of communication and of self-expression, involving levels of meaning, rhetorical structure, and textual analysis.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: French Medieval Literature
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with FRENCH 7410). Survey of representative works from the principal literary genres of the Middle Ages:  epic (La Chanson de Roland), courtly romance (Chretien de Troyes), chantefable (Aucassin et Nicolette), short story (lai, fabliau), theatre, and lyric poetry.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: French Renaissance
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with FRENCH 7420). Survey of prose and poetry of the sixteenth century with significant emphasis on Montaigne, Rabelais, and the poetry of the Pleiade.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Eighteenth-Century French Literature
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with FRENCH 7440). Through systematic and representative readings, this course familiarizes students with the literary trends and intellectual currents of 18th century France.  The course includes works by Montesquieu, Voltaire, Rousseau, Laclos, Diderot, Marivaux, Prevost, and Beaumarchais.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Twentieth-Century French Novel
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with FRENCH 7460). The course is a historical survey that deals with three topics: the modernist writings of the early twentieth century. (Proust, Gide, and Colette), existentialism of the mid-century (Sartre, Camus), and contemporary forms of writing (Beckett, Robbe-Grillet, Sarraute, among others).

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to the Contemporary French Theatre
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Survey of twentieth-century French drama.  Students read plays by Claudel, Giraudoux, Sartre, Anouilh, Beckett, Ionesco, Genet, and others.  Strong emphasis is played on class discussions.  Written analyses of two plays are assigned, and there is an hourly exam and a final.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Nineteenth-Century French Novel
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with FRENCH 7490). Study of the three major currents in prose fiction: romanticism, realism, and naturalism.  Representative readings from Chateaubriand, Balzac, Stendhal, Flaubert, and Zola are included.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Gender Studies in French
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with FRENCH 7500). Will acquaint students with basic theories of gender study by reading and exploring diverse media from the French speaking world. Topics may vary, focusing on feminism, queer studies, women writers, masculinities, etc. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: History of the French Language
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as LINGST 4710). Study of the French language from its Latin origin to the present.  The course includes a survey of the external social, political, and historical factors that have affected the development of French, followed by a diachronic study of the internal structural features of the language.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Structure of Modern French
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: FRENCH 3160 or equivalent or instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as LINGST 4720; cross-leveled with FRENCH 7720, LINGST 7720). An introductory presentation of the phonological and syntactic systems of contemporary standard French.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Blogging the World: The Web in Cultural Context
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as GERMAN 4820 and RUSS 4820). Innovative interdisciplinary course addresses issues of access to international news and specific cultural context working in cross-disciplinary teams. Students in journalism, foreign language, international studies, political science and various other disciplines track cultural developments and information on non-US Web sites, blogs and digital social networks along with exploring various historical forms of communication that preceded the digital era of the Web.  Students analyze the potential and limitations/ effects of blogs and the web in specific contemporary cultural contexts and as part of the broader historical evolution of the web.  The course is taught in English.  The goal of this course is two-fold; students learn the particulars of web blogging, explore various features of the contemporary social network landscape while focusing on the concept of culture, in particular the cultures of Europe and the US.  Questions asked are: what is culture? What is common or popular right now in other cultures? And how do new social networks amplify or alter certain features or culture across national and international contests?

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Blogging the World: The Web in Cultural Context - Writing Intensive
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as GERMAN 4820 and RUSS 4820). Innovative interdisciplinary course addresses issues of access to international news and specific cultural context working in cross-disciplinary teams. Students in journalism, foreign language, international studies, political science and various other disciplines track cultural developments and information on non-US Web sites, blogs and digital social networks along with exploring various historical forms of communication that preceded the digital era of the Web.  Students analyze the potential and limitations/ effects of blogs and the web in specific contemporary cultural contexts and as part of the broader historical evolution of the web.  The course is taught in English.  The goal of this course is two-fold; students learn the particulars of web blogging, explore various features of the contemporary social network landscape while focusing on the concept of culture, in particular the cultures of Europe and the US.  Questions asked are: what is culture? What is common or popular right now in other cultures? And how do new social networks amplify or alter certain features or culture across national and international contests?

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Special Themes in French
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Subject varies according to instructor.  May be repeated for credit.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: The Capstone Experience in French - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course is required of all majors. Topics vary but all courses synthesize and review essential components of the major: speaking, writing, reading in French, and the ability to think critically and analytically.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Stylistics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: FRENCH 3160 or FRENCH 3280 and FRENCH 3420 or FRENCH 3430
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as FRENCH 4130). A technical study of French as a means of communication and of self-expression, involving levels of meaning, rhetorical structure, and textual analysis.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: French Medieval Literature
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with FRENCH 4410).

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: French Renaissance
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with FRENCH 4420). Survey of prose and poetry of the sixteenth century with significant emphasis on Montaigne, Rabelais, and the poetry of the Pleiade.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Eighteenth-Century French Literature

Through systematic and representative readings, this course familiarizes students with the literary trends and intellectual currents of 18th century France.  The course includes works by Montesquieu, Voltaire, Rousseau, Laclos, Diderot, Marivaux, Prevost, and Beaumarchais.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Nineteenth-Century French Novel
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with FRENCH 4490). Study of the three major currents in prose fiction: romanticism, realism, and naturalism.  Representative readings from Chateaubriand, Balzac, Stendhal, Flaubert, and Zola are included.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Gender Studies in French
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: FRENCH 3410 or permission of the instructor
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with FRENCH 4500). Will acquaint students with basic theories of gender study by reading and exploring diverse media from the French speaking world. Topics may vary, focusing on feminism, queer studies, women writers, masculinities, etc. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: History of the French Language
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as LINGST 7710; cross-leveled with FRENCH 4710, LINGST 4710). Required of M.A. candidates.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Structure of Modern French
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: FRENCH 3160 or equivalent or instructor's consent

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as ATM_SC 1050). Physical processes of atmosphere in relation to day-to-day changes in weather.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Enrollment restricted to students enrolled in the College of Arts and Science; Honors eligibility required

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Regions and Nations of the World I
Regions and Nations of the World I - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Introductory analysis for general education. Regional character, spatial relationships, major problems of Europe, North America (United States and Canada) and Latin America. Organized around basic concepts in field of geography.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Regions and Nations of the World II
Climate Change: Science and Public Policy
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Explores the role of physical science, environmental politics and public policy in shaping contemporary debate concerning climate change, mitigation, and adaptation strategies.  Examines the scientific rationale and statistical basis underwriting the concept of climate change, why aspects of the science remain controversial, the prospects of institutional action and the difficulties inherent in developing public policies targeting mitigation and adaptation.   Course includes a role-playing simulation where students will play roles based on 2009 climate negations in Copenhagen, Denmark.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Climate Change: Science and Public Policy - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Explores the role of physical science, environmental politics and public policy in shaping contemporary debate concerning climate change, mitigation, and adaptation strategies.  Examines the scientific rationale and statistical basis underwriting the concept of climate change, why aspects of the science remain controversial, the prospects of institutional action and the difficulties inherent in developing public policies targeting mitigation and adaptation.   Course includes a role-playing simulation where students will play roles based on 2009 climate negations in Copenhagen, Denmark.  Graded on A-F basis only.      Honors eligibility required

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Digital Earth: Introduction to the Geospatial Technologies
United States and Canada
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Intensive examination of selected areas and distributions. Regional systems, problems and planning.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Geography of Missouri
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Physical, human, economic, and political geography of Missouri; regions of the state; geography applied to current state issues.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Geography of Missouri - Honors

Data management, current data models, GIS applications and course topics are reinforced through hands-on computer laboratory exercises.

Historical Geography of North America

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: MATH _0110 or equivalent or graduate standingCorequisites: By permission, only
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as ATM_SC 3600). A study of the world distribution of climates based on "cause and effect" relationships. Special attention is given to the impacts of climate on humanity.

May be repeated for credit.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Resources and Indigenous Peoples
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with GEOG 7560). Survey of Indigenous peoples' struggle to control and use natural resources, to have a say in determining the path of economic development, and to restrain the destructive tendencies of colonialism and capitalism, challenging traditional state-to-state relations.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Resources and Indigenous Peoples - Writing Intensive
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with GEOG 7560). Survey of Indigenous peoples' struggle to control and use natural resources, to have a say in determining the path of economic development, and to restrain the destructive tendencies of colonialism and capitalism, challenging traditional state-to-state relations.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with GEOG 7860). Class project heavily involved.

Environment and Empire in Russia and Eurasia - Writing Intensive
Topics in Geography-Social Science - Writing Intensive
Advanced Geographic Information Systems (GIS II)

Focus on project management, research applications, and geostatistical analysis through independent research projects.

Senior Seminar in Geography

Landscape Ecology and GIS Analysis I

Research Design
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Restricted to graduate geography majors graduate or instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Application of scientific methods in geographic research. Critical evaluation of current geographical methodology.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Geographic Thought
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Discussion of the historic roots of the discipline, especially the ideas, theories and underlying philosophies that have defined Geography in the past century and a half. Students will also explore the philosophical and theoretical ideas that shape the way geographers approach the study of the world.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Field Geography
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: restricted to graduate Geography majors or instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Techniques of geographical investigation in the field.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Seminar: Applied Remote Sensing
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Applied project in remote sensing.  Data selection, image processing, land-use and land-cover change, and quantitative biophysical information extraction from remotely sensed data.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to the Earth with Laboratory
Introduction to Soil Science with Laboratory
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as SOIL 2110). Introduction to Soil Science with emphasis placed on physical, biological, and chemical properties and applications to land use, plant growth, and environmental problems with laboratory application of these concepts.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Faults and Earthquakes: Past, Present, and Future - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Seminar in science and societal ramifications of earthquakes. Geologic background includes causes, behavior, and distribution of faults. Student-led discussions cover historical disasters, economic, political, psychological, and cultural perspectives.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Physical Geology for Scientists and Engineers
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Introduction to physical geology and Earth processes with a focus on applications and societal relevance. In addition to basic geologic processes, physical principles will illustrate the interactions between geology and engineering, using a calculus-based approach.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: The Age of the Dinosaurs
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Study of the evolution of dinosaurs during the Mesozoic Era. New information on dinosaur life habits, food resources, dispersal by plate tectonics, and theories of extinction will be covered.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Volcanoes and the Human Environment - Honors
Seminar: Headline Topics in the Geological Sciences
Honors Seminar: Headline Topics in the Geological Science
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Seminar organized around a central theme that is the focus of intense ongoing research and public debate.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Earth and Life Through Time
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Summary of principles and techniques used in reconstructing Earth's history. Survey of major events that have affected Earth and its inhabitants. Review of geologic history of North America.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Earth and Life Through Time Laboratory
Surficial Earth Processes and Products with Laboratory
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: GEOL 1100 or GEOL 2130 or GEOL 1200, and MATH 1100
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Semiquantitative analysis of geologic processes that shape the earth's surface. Includes topics in sedimentation and geomorphology.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Global Water Cycle
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Study of environmental geochemical factors controlling the composition of natural waters, and sources of water's constituents (natural or human-produced).  Math Reasoning Proficiency Course.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Regional Geology Field Trip
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Field based study of a particular geologic region, including classroom preparation prior to the field trip. The trip will last 7-10 days, either during Spring Break or immediately after finals week.  May be repeated for credit.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Mineral and Energy Resources of the Earth
Geology of Missouri
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: ENGLSH 1000 and either GEOL 1100 or  GEOL 1200
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: The physical, historical, and environmental geology of Missouri are described, discussed and interpreted.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to Geochemistry
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: MATH 1400 or MATH 1500, and GEOL 1100 or GEOL 2130 or GEOL 1200
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Fundamentals of chemistry as applied to geology.  Includes phase diagrams, thermodynamics, redox chemistry, aqueous chemistry, stable and radiogentic isotopes.  Computer-based homework problems (satisfies computing requirement for Geology majors).

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to Paleontology with Laboratory
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Study of the morphology, paleontology, patterns of evolution, and causes of extinction in geologically important groups of invertebrate and vertebrate fossils. Lab concentrates on identification of biostratigraphically important fossils (mostly invertebrates). Several half-day field trips.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Sedimentology and Stratigraphy with Lab
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Mechanics of sediment transport by fluid flow and gravity flow, origins of stratification and sedimentary structures, facies characteristics depositional environments.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Groundwater Hydrology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: GEOL 1100 or GEOL 2130 or GEOL 1200, and PHYSCS 1210 or PHYSCS 2750, and MATH 1400 or MATH 1500
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with GEOL 7100). Analysis of groundwater occurrence, flow, recovery, and solute transport within shallow levels of the Earth's crust.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Engineering Geology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: GEOL 1100 or GEOL 2130 or GEOL 1200, and MATH 1500, or instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with GEOL 7120). Fundamentals of earth materials and geological processes and their applications in engineering works and environmental sciences. Includes properties of minerals and rocks, rock and soil mechanics, surficial geological processes, and practice of engineering.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Groundwater Modeling
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with GEOL 7130). Use of leading groundwater flow and contamination modeling software.  Theory of groundwater flow, solute transport, and selected numerical solution techniques.  Applications to water resource, environmental, and geological problems.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Structural Geology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: GEOL 1100 or GEOL 2130 or GEOL 1200 and MATH 1140 or MATH 1160 or MATH 1500
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with GEOL 7150). The mechanical behavior of earth materials. Analysis of the geometry and mechanics of faults, fractures, and folds. Laboratory includes problems on stresses and strains associated with deformation, geometric analysis of deformation structures, and interpretation of geologic maps.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Solar System Science
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: MATH 1700 and PHYSCS 1220 or PHYSCS 2760 or instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as PHYSCS 4180, ASTRON 4180; cross-leveled with GEOL 7180).  Investigates physical states, interior structures and comparative geology of solar systems bodies:  planets, moons, asteroids, comets, sun. Solar system formation and evolution.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Economic Geology with Laboratory
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Geochemistry of ore deposits. Introduction to types of mineral deposits, genesis of ore, and current areas of research. Laboratory emphasizes hand-specimen and polished-section studies of a wide variety of ore deposit types.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to Low-Temperature Geochemistry
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Introduction to the chemical alteration of rock-forming minerals in weathering environments and to factors controlling the chemical composition of subsurface water.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Environmental Soil Chemistry
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: SOIL 2100 or GEOL 2400, CHEM 1320 and CHEM 1330.  Junior standing or instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as SOIL 4318 and ENV_SC 4318; cross-leveled with GEOL 7318, SOIL 7318, ENV_SC 7318). Study of chemical constituents and processes occurring in soils. Topics include soil minerals and weathering processes, organic matter, solution chemistry, oxidation-reduction reactions and adsorption processes.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Taphonomy
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with GEOL 7350). The purposes of this course are to 1) analyze patterns in the history of life and 2) to recognize the biased processes that led to its preservation. We will accomplish these goals by examining two disparate fossil preservation pathways: 1) Konservat lagerstätten: fossil deposits that are notorious for the exceptional and rare preservation of soft tissues and 2) Konzentrat lagerstätten: fossil deposits that are exceptional for the enormous amount of fossilized skeletal material they contain. Through careful examination of both the rare and the hyper-abundant, we can address the fundamental question of paleobiology: how literally can the fossil record be read as the history of life? Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Organic Geochemistry
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with GEOL 7500). Topics include chemistry of petroleum-forming reactions and their kinetic parameters; use of organic-chemical criteria in source-rock evaluation; carbon isotope fractionation in organic precursors of biological molecules; early history of earth's atmosphere.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Plate Tectonics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: GEOL 3250 or GEOL 4150 or instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with GEOL 7650). Formation, evolution, and structure of the earth. Rules, causes, and implications of plate tectonics with emphasis on present-day features.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Plate Tectonics - Writing Intensive
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: GEOL 3250 or GEOL 4150 or instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Formation, evolution, and structure of the earth. Rules, causes, and implications of plate tectonics with emphasis on present-day features.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Neotectonics and Earthquake Geology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with GEOL 7680). Introduction to techniques and concepts of active crustal deformation from the geological and geodetic perspectives.  Topics include tectonic geomorphology, paleoseismology, Quaternary dating, tectonic geodesy, numerical models of faults, and earthquake hazard assessment.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Microanalysis for Geological Sciences
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Instructor's Consent (instrument time is limited so enrollment must also be limited)
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with GEOL 7750). This course is intended to provide a working knowledge of electron and X-ray microbeam analytical instruments - both in principle and in practice. Lectures will focus on the physics of how these instruments collect data, and how these data can be interpreted. In addition, students will gain hands-on experience with operating these instruments, specifically on their own samples, as well as preparing their samples for microanalysis and interpreting/manipulating the resulting data.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to Geophysics

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with GEOL 7800). Introduction to the fundamentals of geophysical methods and their applications in geology, environmental studies, and exploration. Topics include seismic, gravity, magnetic, and electric methods.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Igneous and Metamorphic Petrology with Laboratory
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Introduction to igneous and metamorphic rock associations and rock-forming processes. Emphasis on understanding the evolution of the Earth in view of igneous and metamorphic rock petrogenesis.

Topics include thermodynamics of fluids, gases and solids in geological materials, phase diagrams, equilibrium constants, electrolyte theory, oxidation-reduction reactions.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Microanalysis for Geological Sciences
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Instructor's consent (Instrument time is limited; graduate students who will use the instruments in their research will have priority)
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with GEOL 4750). This course is intended to provide a working knowledge of electron and X-ray microbeam analytical instruments - both in principle and in practice. Lectures will focus on the physics of how these instruments collect data, and how these data can be interpreted. In addition, students will gain hands-on experience with operating these instruments, specifically on their own samples, as well as preparing their samples for microanalysis and interpreting/manipulating the resulting data. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to Geophysics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: GEOL 1100 or GEOL 2130 or GEOL 1200 and MATH 1700 or instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with GEOL 4800). Introduction to the fundamentals of geophysical methods and their applications in geology, environmental studies, and exploration. Topics include seismic, gravity, magnetic, and electric methods.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Continental Tectonics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: The structural, metamorphic, and igneous evolution of mountain belts and continental rifts with emphasis on convergent margin settings and terrane accretion processes and products. Case studies are considered from the Precambrian to the recent.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Metamorphic Petrology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Petrography and petrology of metamorphic rocks. Emphasis on textures, mineral assemblages, and mineral chemistry in order to determine the physico-chemical condition of metamorphism.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Earthquake Seismology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Theory and techniques used in analyzing earthquake seismograms and seismicity data. Ray theory and phase identification for the whole earth. Epicenter determination. Frequency-magnitude relationships. Earthquake source mechanisms and parameters.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Igneous Petrology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Studies of the origin and evolution of magmas with use of phase equilibria, physical properties, and kinetics.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Radiogenic Isotope Geochemistry
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Studies of the application of trace element and radiogenic isotope systematics to petrogenesis of rocks.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Advanced Paleontology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Principles of taxonomy, biostratigraphy, functional morphology and paleoecology are illustrated by individual projects that combine field collecting, laboratory examination and literature research.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Advanced Structural Geology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Advanced analysis of deformation structures in rocks. Theory and techniques of stress and strain analysis and their application to the mechanics of formation of faults, folds, shear zones, and rock fabric. Techniques of multideformation structural analysis.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Hydrolgeologic Processes
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Quantitative analysis of role of groundwater in major geologic processes.  Theory review of fluid flow, heat transport, reactive solute transport in porous media.  Applications to sedimentary diagenesis, hydrothermal ore deposits, petroleum migration, earthquakes, magmatism, metamorphism.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to Seismology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Principles of wave propagation in layered elastic media. Applications of digital signal processing to seismological problems. Emphasis on theoretical basis behind modern analysis techniques.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Ancient Greenhouse Climate
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Will explore a wide range of data concerning greenhouse climates and different techniques used in paleoclimatology. Graded on A/F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Tectonics and Sedimentation
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Global survey of modern and ancient convergent plate boundaries with an emphasis on sedimentary facies and structural styles.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Geodynamics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course is designed to cover the fundamentals of the quantitative aspects of Plate Tectonics.  The study of these subjects s generally referred to as Geodynamics or Geodynamic Theory.  This theory revolutionized the earth sciences and the way people think of earth processes.  By definition Geodynamics is an interdisciplinary paradigm therefore it is necessary to cover a wide range of topics from heat transfer to gravity.  This course will overlap with subjects covered in both Plate Tectonics and Geophysics but we will emphasize the quantitative aspects of this theory in this course.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Stable Isotope Geochemistry
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Mechanisms and fundamental concepts of fractionation of light stable isotopes in nature. Emphasizes application of hydrogen, carbon, oxygen and sulfur isotopes to igneous, metamorphic and sedimentary rocks, metallic ore deposits, and to natural waters.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Thermal Processes in the Solid Earth
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Principles of heat transfer in solid earth by conduction, advection and convection. Basic analytic and numerical solutions. Application in Earth's dynamic system, environmental sciences, and geological problems.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Silicate Glasses, Liquids and Magmas
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: GEOL 4900 and  GEOL 4700, or instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Theory of silicate liquid viscosity, heat capacity and configurational entropy, emphasizing the role of volatile components.  Applications to magma rheology and eruptive behavior.  Lab instruction in viscometry techniques.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Applied Numerical Analysis
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: MATH 1700 or MATH 2300, PHYSCS 1220 or PHYSCS 2760
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: A study of applied mathematical analysis of spatial and temporal data as applied in the geosciences.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Elementary German I - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course is designed for Honors students with little or no German language background and will provide students with a foundation in vocabulary and grammar in order to develop communication proficiency in German. Students will be trained using the five skills: listening, speaking, writing, reading and cultural knowledge.  The course will be taught as a total immersion class and thus differs from the standard elementary German sequence.  Furthermore, students will be required to complete lengthier reading and writing tasks as well as present a final oral multimedia project at the end of the semester.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Elementary German II - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course is designed for Honors students who either took the GERMAN 1100H section or are placing into GERMAN 1200 as honors eligible students. The main focus of this course is on further development of basic communication skills in speaking, listening, reading, and writing in German adding more nuanced cultural and sociolinguistic competencies in a total immersion environment.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Undergraduate Topics in German-Humanities - Writing Intensive
Intermediate German I - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Honors eligibility requiredRecommended: C- or better in GERMAN 1200, or equivalent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: A continuation of GERMAN 1200.  This course helps learners develop the skills they need to use German as a means of communication in their personal and professional life.  It covers a wide variety of vocabulary pertaining to everyday life; emphasis is on all types of communication - oral and listening skills, reading and writing.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Intermediate German II: Language and Culture
German Civilization I: Barbarians, Valkyries, Knights, Poets
German Civilization I: Barbarians, Valkyries, Knights, Poets - Writing Intensive
German Civilization: 1850 to Present
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: some sections may enforce prerequisite of ENGLSH 1000
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Second Empire, Weimar Republic, Nazi era, two Germanies after 1949. Historical, social, artistic, literary themes. Films and recordings. May be taken independently of  GERMAN 2310. No foreign language credit.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: German Civilization: 1850 to Present - Writing Intensive
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: some sections may enforce prerequisite of ENGLSH 1000
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Second Empire, Weimar Republic, Nazi era, two Germanies after 1949. Historical, social, artistic, literary themes. Films and recordings. May be taken independently of  GERMAN 2310. No foreign language credit.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: The Cultural History of Germans in Missouri, or: Oktoberfest in the Midwest!
The Cultural History of Germans in Missouri, or: Oktoberfest in the Midwest! - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Have you ever been to an Oktoberfest in the Midwest or wondered why so many Missourians like Bratwurst? In this course we will seek to answer these and many more questions by delving into the cultural history of Germans and German immigration to the state from the nineteenth century to the present. The purpose of this course is to learn about the cultural history of the state and region and its connections to global histories. This course will speak to students interested in regional tourism and commerce; state and US history; German studies; international studies; refugee and migration studies; and more. We will explore the forces that shaped the lives of German immigrants and their descendants in Missouri: large numbers of German immigrants play formative roles in local and state governments; they are involved in transforming much of the landscape into farmland; they create a wide range of businesses, most notably the many breweries that blanketed the state; they found a variety of churches, settle in religious communities, and establish most of the early synagogues. They are involved in debates about the Civil War and in the build up to the World Wars of the twentieth century. The history of Missouri, in this sense, is part and parcel of both German and American history, and the goal of this class is to allow students to participate in writing it. This is not a typical course based on lectures and discussions. It is based on a joint effort to learn more about German Missouri with a strong component of project-based learning. Students will be encouraged to explore parts of the state and its history, and when applicable, to explore their own family backgrounds as immigrants. As a final project, students will do a history of a specific cultural object, working in tandem with Missouri Humanities and the German Heritage project. Anything used will be credited to students in the displays. This course is conducted in English.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: The Cultural History of Germans in Missouri, or: Oktoberfest in the Midwest! - Writing Intensive
Trends in World Cinema
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: sophomore standing, ENGLSH 1800 or FILMS_VS 1800 or instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as FILMS_VS 2820 and LG_LT_CT 2820). This course is a historical overview of the major trends in international cinema. It focuses on the intersection of aesthetics, industry, and ideological and social concerns in cinematic production.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: German Conversation and Composition
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course expands communicative competence in German and provides a review of advanced grammar concepts. Primary emphasis is on the further development of oral and written skills, reading comprehension, vocabulary expansion, and a broad exposure to relevant topics of contemporary German culture and society. Conducted in German.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Business German
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Examines language within the economic and professional context of German-speaking countries. Introduces different economic concepts of Germany's turbulent 20th century, modern-day business systems and everyday commercial activities such as job applications, professional routines, capital investment and banking. Provides students with vocabulary, cultural knowledge and communicative abilities in order to participate in the professional German-speaking world using linguistically-solid and stylistically-persuasive writing and speaking skills.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Contemporary German Culture
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This content-driven course provides insights into essential subjects of 20th century German history and contemporary society, using a variety of literature, journalistic sources and film.  The course will improve German conversation and literacy skills, and will strengthen critical reading and writing, as well as interpretative abilities.  Significant grammatical concepts will be thoroughly reviewed  throughout the semester.  Conducted in German.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to German Literature
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course introduces students to German-language literary texts, images, and films in their cultural and historical context through exposure to major genres (poetry, drama, short stories, and the novel). It further builds their vocabulary and teaches them critical interpretive skills as preparation for the analysis of literary texts in upper-division courses - and in life.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Readings in German Literature
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Readings of selected works and genres of German literature from the eighteenth century to the present. Conducted in German.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Folk and Fairytales in a Global Context
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Analyzes the most famous European collection of fairytales, namely the Kinder-und  Hausmarchen (Children's and Household Tales) by the Brothers Grimm and juxtaposes them to folktales from other cultures. Looks at the genre of fairytales, studies the historical context of the genesis of the collection of tales, and modern versions of the tales. Compares and contrasts Grimm's fairytales with folktales of different cultural traditions, analyzes and identifies the formal structure of fairytales and motifs, discusses various interpretive models/perspectives and juxtaposes several historical and contemporary literary fairytales and fairytale adaptations. Cultural unit examples will be on Mongolian culture and history and the Maori culture of New Zealand. Students are expected to create their own cultural unit based on the course's units. Course is taught in English.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Folk and Fairytales in a Global Context - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: sophomore standing required. Honors eligibility required
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Analyzes the most famous European collection of fairytales, namely the Kinder-und  Hausmarchen (Children's and Household Tales) by the Brothers Grimm and juxtaposes them to folktales from other cultures.
