Other students may register after early registration, provided there is space available. NO OVERRIDES/PERMISSIONS will be given for this class once the lectures/labs fill
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: The legal aspects of business related to society--introduction to the legal system; constitutional, criminal, tort law; contracts and sales law cases and problems; administrative regulation of business and consumer issues.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: The Entrepreneurial Mindset
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Individual sections may be restricted to business students only and/or Management emphasis students and/or students who have declared the Entrepreneurship & Innovation Minor on their academic planRecommended: ABM 3283, MANGMT 4700, T_A_M 3800
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: The course will engage students in experiences that develop entrepreneurial characteristics such as a passion for business, tenacity despite failure, self-determination, management of risk, self-confidence, creating opportunities, creativity, initiative, and detail orientation. The product of this course intends to be a well-prepared student-entrepreneur fully confident to launch a thought-out business model. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Design Thinking for New Business Innovation
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Individual sections may be restricted to business students only and/or students who have declared the Entrepreneurship & Innovation Minor on their academic plan
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: The Design Thinking for New Business Innovation course is ideally taken as the second course in a three course sequence (sequencing of courses is not required). Students, working in teams, first learn how to recognize potential opportunities in a range of business contexts (MANGMT 4700). Next, students learn how to identify meaningful issues for customers in a more focused context, how to generate multiple solutions and form these into cohesive business concepts, and how to carefully test for feasible value with potential customers using rough prototypes (this course). Finally, students learn how to develop a comprehensive business plan in areas like operations, marketing, finance, and human resources based on a business model concept for a given industry (MANGMT 4730). Such a detailed plan can used to appeal to potential funding sources and serves as a guide for strategic action by a new venture. This course, as the middle course, bridges into the domains of both of the other two courses to give students a flavor for what can be learned in both. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Managing People in the Global Enterprise
Supply Chain Management
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Individual sections may be restricted to business students only and/or Management emphasis students and/or students who have declared the Global Supply Chain Certificate on their academic plan
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with MANGMT 7070). An examination of the concepts, processes and institutions that are fundamental to an understanding of supply chain management in a global environment. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Managing Global Trade
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Individual sections may be restricted to business students only and/or students who have declared the Global Supply Chain Certificate on their academic plan and/or students who have declared the Global Business Certificate on their academic plan
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with MANGMT 7080). International trade is the exchange of goods and services between countries giving rise to a world economy that is affected by global events. This course will focus on global trade management issues, procedures, requirements, and strategies. The implementation of international market strategy, global supply chains, and trade finance will also be explored. These topics will be examined by exploring trade factors that influence organizations and trade relations such as different cultural norms, government regulations, technology, resources, and logistics. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Managing Global Trade - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Honors eligibility required; Individual sections may be restricted to business students only and/or students who have declared the Global Supply Chain Certificate on their academic plan and/or students who have declared the Global Business Certificate on their academic plan
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with MANGMT 7080). International trade is the exchange of goods and services between countries giving rise to a world economy that is affected by global events. This course will focus on global trade management issues, procedures, requirements, and strategies. The implementation of international market strategy, global supply chains, and trade finance will also be explored. These topics will be examined by exploring trade factors that influence organizations and trade relations such as different cultural norms, government regulations, technology, resources, and logistics. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Purchasing and Supply Management
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: MANGMT 4010. Individual sections may be restricted to business students only and/or students who have declared the Global Supply Chain Certificate on their academic plan
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with MANGMT 7090). This course examines the critical role of the procurement function within the organization. The objective is to provide students with a fundamental understanding of the purchasing/sourcing function, key issues and developments in purchasing and supply management within the context of SCM, and to identify ways that purchasing can make a positive contribution to the competitiveness of the firm. Topics include an intro to the field/role in SCM; developing global sourcing strategies using commodity/channel/category management; make-or-buy decisions; supplier identification and selection; contract and pricing practices; negotiation; spend analytics including value analysis for services; contract performance monitoring; traditional verse collaborative supplier development; cross-functional relationship management, and ethics. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Human Resource Management Law
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Individual sections may be restricted to business students only and/or students who have declared the Human Resource Management Certificate on their academic plan
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Analysis and evaluation of legal and administrative regulations of terms of employment; Fair Labor Standards, discriminatory practices, safety and health regulations, other regulations.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Advanced Organizational Behavior
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: MANGMT 4030. Individual sections may be restricted to business students only and/or students who have declared the Human Resource Management Certificate on their academic plan
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Based upon behavioral science concepts and research findings directed toward understanding and explaining human behavior within organizations. Case studies, individual or team projects.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Business Communication
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Restricted to Trulaske College of Business students admitted to upper levelCorequisites: MANGMT 3000
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: The course provides the fundamentals of business communication skills, including written, oral communication, listening, multicultural communication, and teamwork skills, with an emphasis on written communication skills as a method to communicate with important stakeholders.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Business Communication - Writing Intensive
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Restricted to Trulaske College of Business students admitted to professional degree program during early registration
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: The course provides the fundamentals of business communication skills, including written, oral communication, listening, multicultural communication, and teamwork skills, with an emphasis on written communication skills as a method to communicate with important stakeholders.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Topics in Management
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Individual sections may be restricted to business students only
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Selected current topics in management. Offered on an experimental, one-semester basis only. (Individual sections may be cross-leveled with MANGMT 7201).

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Topics in Management - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: will vary with different topics.  Honors eligibility required
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Selected current topics in management. Offered on an experimental, one-semester basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Compensation and Benefits: Theory and Practice
Selected Problems in Human Resource Management
Negotiation
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Individual sections may be restricted to business students only and/or students who have declared the Human Resource Management Certificate on their academic plan
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course helps students develop expertise and confidence to engage in negotiations that occur in a variety of business contexts. Students engage with challenging negotiation exercises and post-exercise debriefings. These are supported by frequent feedback and practical conceptual frameworks and other knowledge about negotiation processes that serve as guides for improvement. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Consulting Tools and Strategies
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Junior standing. Individual sections may be restricted to business students only and/or students who have declared the Human Resource Management Certificate on their academic plan and/or students who have declared the Entrepreneurship & Innovation Minor on their academic plan
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with MANGMT 7490). This course teaches a structured approach to bulletproof problem-solving. Designed as a foundation course for students interested in consulting, it is also for those that want to learn to think like a consultant. Strategies for approaching problems and clients are introduced as well as frameworks for investigation and analysis. The majority of class work involves casework, completed in teams, on the practical application of diagnostic, communication and problem-resolution tools as they would present in a client/employer environment. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Legal Aspects of Business Organization and Operation
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: MANGMT 3540. Individual sections may be restricted to business students only
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with MANGMT 7540). Includes agency and employment relationships, sole proprietorships, partnerships, and corporations, also operational aspects of business associations such as administrative regulation, taxation, bankruptcy, and trade regulation.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Web Development Fundamentals
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: ACCTCY 2258; MANGMT 3000, MANGMT 3000H, MANGMT 3000HW, or MANGMT 3000W. Individual sections may be restricted to business students only
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: An introduction to the fundamentals of design, technology and project management aspects of developing websites.  Some web based programming languages including HTML, CSS, JavaScript and ASP/VBScript and an introduction to Adobe Photoshop and Macromedia Dreamweaver.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Principles of Entrepreneurship
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Individual sections may be restricted to business students only and/or students who have declared the Entrepreneurship & Innovation Minor on their academic plan
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: An introductory course designed to provide a solid foundation of the role of entrepreneurship.  The focus is on the creation of new ventures, the decisions leading to their development, and the factors that lead to their success.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: New Business Planning and Management
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Individual sections may be restricted to business students only and/or students who have declared the Entrepreneurship & Innovation Minor on their academic plan
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Analysis of the major functional areas of the start-up firm including accounting, finance, human resources, information systems, logistics, management, marketing, production/operations, purchasing and sales. Focus is also placed on generating ideas, scanning for environmental trends, and critically evaluating opportunities.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Facilitation of Entrepreneurship and Innovation
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Individual sections may be restricted to business students only and/or students who have declared the Entrepreneurship & Innovation Minor on their academic plan
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course aims to introduce students to a specific area of consulting, being that of assisting entrepreneurs and inventors to create new ventures. Assisting others in creating new ventures is very different from creating your own business or consulting to established companies and facilitators are required to take different actions depending on the situation. In this course students will work directly with aspiring entrepreneurs and/or investors and be guided through the process of conducting an entrepreneurial human and social capital analysis, before conducting an in-depth audit of resources available to the entrepreneur that will fill identified gaps. In the second half of the course, students work with the entrepreneur/inventor and other relevant resource providers in a structured and disciplined manner using a design-innovation process that has been shown to dramatically increasing the probability of creating a successful innovation. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Human Resource Management Problems and Consulting
Professional Management Internship
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: COB student with a management concentration, and Internship Coordinator's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Provides experience with management activities in business organizations (or, occasionally, in a governmental or not-for-profit setting). Students are required to prepare and execute a plan of study approved by the instructor and to complete written assignments detailed in the plan. Course only satisfies a professional elective requirement of the program. Graded on S/U basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Strategic Management
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: MANGMT 3000, MRKTNG 3000, FINANC 3000 and 102 credit hours earned. Open only to seniors admitted to a professional program in the CoB
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Enterprise-level case studies, simulations, similar exercises to integrate business functional decisions; assessment of environmental influences on business. Development, implementation of company strategies.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Strategic Management
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: MANGMT 3000, MRKTNG 3000, FINANC 3000 and 102 credit hours earned. Open only to seniors admitted to a professional program in the CoB
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Enterprise-level case studies, simulations, similar exercises to integrate business functional decisions; assessment of environmental influences on business. Development, implementation of company strategies.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Organizational Behavior
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Some sections may be restricted to execMBA only
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with MANGMT 4030). Examines theoretical constructs and research findings on human behavior in work organizations such as businesses, especially individual differences, dyadic relations and small group behavior. May require consent.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Organizational Behavior and Management: The Individual
Legal Aspects of Business Organization and Operation
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with MANGMT 4540). Includes agency and employment relationships, sole proprietorships, partnerships, and corporations, also operational aspects of business associations such as administrative regulation, taxation, bankruptcy, and trade regulation.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: MBA Professional Development - Executive Career Development
MBA Professional Development - Managing Conflict and Designing Effective Teams
Entrepreneurship and Media of the Future
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: graduate standing in Journalism or MBA program
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as JOURN 8054). This course will give students an intense hands-on experience in working with real entrepreneurs on complex business problems in the journalism field.  Example companies are the Associated Press, Kachingle, the Chicago Sun-Times, Spot-Us and the Media Policy Center.  The goal is to offer a solution or solutions to the stated problem, and to present these ideas in a competitive, symposium environment.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Exploring the Digital Globe
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: enrollment in CDiG Graduate Certificate Program or instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Impacts of technological change and globalization are explored from the perspective of business, law and journalism.  The first course required for the "CDiG certificate".  Issues involving electronic commerce, digitization and globalization will be analyzed through online and in-class projects, class discussion and guest lectures.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Current Issues in Human Resource Management
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Exploration of current trends, issues, and controversies involving the managing of human resources in organizations, with an emphasis on how human resources can provide competitive advantage. Considers multiple perspectives, including that of employers, employees, and other stakeholders.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Organizational Behavior and Management: Dyadic, Group and Organizational Processes
Business Consulting: Field Project
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This is an experiential-base course in which students work in a team consulting capacity. Students learn to apply functional areas of business to real-world, real-time issues of business partner organizations working with faculty and business leaders. Client organizations range from large multi-national firms to start-ups. The final deliverable consists of an oral presentation of recommendations and a written consulting report. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Advanced Business Consulting: Project Lead
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Students work in a team consulting capacity, with medium to large organizations, identifying and defining relatively complex and often ambiguous business problems. Solutions are both innovative and integrative in nature, as students are encouraged to think creatively by making expert resources available. Particularly unique to this class is its lack of classroom setting. All meetings take place in small teams; weekly meetings in the instructor's office and regular meetings scheduled with experts and client leaders at off-site locations or remotely. The final deliverable consists of an oral presentation of recommendations and a written consulting report. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Research Methods in the Organization Sciences
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Identifying research questions, critiquing research ideas, planning, conducting, and communicating research using experimental, cross-sectional, survey and qualitative methods.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Seminar in Macro Organizational Behavior
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course is designated to introduce students to content areas within the organizational behavior literature.  Topics in "macro" organizational behavior will be covered, including groups and teams, organizational culture, and national culture.  We will also cover a number of topics outside of traditional organizational behavior topics, including negotiation and social conflict, creativity, empowerment, and other topics as the instructor sees fit.  Readings will consist of a combination of recent and classic journal articles on the topics.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Seminar in Human Resource Management
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Intensive study of current research, issues and methodology of the applied science of human resource management.  Topics include recruitment and selection, training, job performance and performance feedback, and career success.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Seminar in Corporate Strategy
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: The doctoral seminar in strategy focuses on the topics of strategy content research (what strategies are used by firms, and what is their effect on performance, corporate and competitive strategy, etc.) but also considering important related research streams of strategy process and implementation.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Seminar in Entrepreneurship
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: The doctoral seminar in Entrepreneurship is intended to provide students with a broad coverage of the literature.  It focuses on the foundations and "cutting edge" research in entrepreneurship content research.  Topics covered in the course include:  a theoretical overview of entrepreneurship, identification of opportunities, the decision to exploit opportunities, resource assembly and new markets, founders and entrepreneurial teams, venture capital and venture capitalists, entrepreneurship and efficient governance, initial public offerings (IPOs), new ventures (strategy, growth, performance), entrepreneurial networks and alliances, and international entrepreneurship.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Principles of Marketing
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Institutions, processes, and problems involved in producing and transferring goods and services from producer to consumers; emphasis on economics and social aspects.   May be restricted during early registration to: Business students only and/or Students who have declared the Business Minor on their academic plan.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Principles of Marketing - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Institutions, processes, and problems involved in producing and transferring goods and services from producer to consumers; emphasis on economics and social aspects.  May be restricted during early registration to: Business students only and/or Students who have declared the Business Minor on their academic plan; Honors eligibility required.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: International Business
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: MANGMT 3000, MANGMT 3000H, MANGMT 3000HW, or MANGMT 3000W or MRKTNG 3000 or MRKTNG 3000H. May be restricted during early registration to business students only and/or students who have declared the Global Business Certificate on their academic plan
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as MANGMT 3900). Analyzes the essential business functions within a global economy and provides a basic literacy in international business strategy and decision-making. Global markets are examined using legal, technological, ethical, and cultural considerations. Business principles in planning, organizing, leading, and controlling international trade and commerce are examined. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Marketing Management
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: MRKTNG 3000, and ACCTCY 2010 or ACCTCY 2026, or ACCTCY 2036 or ACCTCY 2136H. https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Further examination of marketing issues: market analysis, market research, positioning, products, pricing, promotion, distribution, relationship management, other topics.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Marketing Management - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: MRKTNG 3000; ACCTCY 2010 or ACCTCY 2026 or ACCTCY 2036 or ACCTCY 2136H; Honors eligibility required
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Further examination of marketing issues: market analysis, market research, positioning, products, pricing, promotion, distribution, relationship management, other topics.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Topics in Marketing
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: MRKTNG 3000. May be restricted during early registration to business students only
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Selected marketing-related topics.  Subjects may vary across semesters.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Dimensions of the consumer market and decision-making process of consumers; analyzing economic, psychological and socio-psychological influences on consumer market and buying behavior.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Consumer Behavior - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: MRKTNG 3000. May be restricted during early registration to business students only and/or students who have declared the Sales Certificate on their academic plan; Honors eligibility required
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Dimensions of the consumer market and decision-making process of consumers; analyzing economic, psychological and socio-psychological influences on consumer market and buying behavior.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Retail Marketing
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: MRKTNG 3000. May be restricted during early registration to business students only and/or students who have declared the Sales Certificate on their academic plan
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Strategies, policies, tactics, and procedures of marketing in a retailing environment.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Retail Marketing - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: MRKTNG 3000 and Honors eligibility required. May be restricted during early registration to business students only and/or students who have declared the Sales Certificate on their academic plan
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Strategies, policies, tactics, and procedures of marketing  in a retailing environment.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Sales Management
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: MRKTNG 3000. May be restricted during early registration to business students only and/or students who have declared the Sales Certificate on their academic plan and/or students who have declared the Entrepreneurship & Innovation Minor on their academic plan
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Methods and tools employed by salespeople and field sales managers; emphasis on underlying behavioral and quantitative theory.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Advanced Professional Selling
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: MRKTNG 3410 and MRKTNG 4420. May be restricted during early registration to business students only and/or students who have declared the Sales Certificate on their academic plan
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Emphasis on the analytics approach to sales. This reflects the overall trends in business practice, and specifically in the world of sales with increasing reliance on Sales Force Automation (SFA) and Customer Relationship Management (CRM) tools. Students will need to come to class with laptops or tablets. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Services Marketing
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: MRKTNG 3000. May be restricted during early registration to business students only and/or students who have declared the Sales Certificate on their academic plan
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Challenges, problems, and strategies specific to marketing in service industries.  Topics include the unique characteristics of services and managing service-oriented businesses; service design and service recovery; service quality and customer satisfaction service pricing issues and demand management; and management of service customers and employees.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning Applications in Sales and Marketing
Integrated Marketing Communications
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: MRKTNG 3000. May be restricted during early registration to business students only and/or students who have declared the Sales Certificate on their academic plan and/or students who have declared the Digital Marketing Certificate on their academic plan
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Design, coordination, and management of marketing communications.  Focus on the role of integrated marketing communications in the overall marketing process, with emphasis on advertising and sales promotion strategies and tactics.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Integrated Marketing Communications - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: MRKTNG 3000 and Honors eligibility required. May be restricted during early registration to business students only and/or students who have declared the Sales Certificate on their academic plan and/or students who have declared the Digital Marketing Certificate on their academic plan
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Design, coordination, and management of marketing communications.  Focus on the role of integrated marketing communications in the overall marketing process, with emphasis on advertising and sales promotion strategies and tactics.  During early registration, some sections may be restricted to College of Business students with emphasis in Marketing, or International Business with emphasis in Marketing.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Digital Marketing
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: MRKTNG 3000. May be restricted during early registration to business students only and/or students who have declared the Digital Marketing Certificate on their academic plan and/or students who have declared the Entrepreneurship & Innovation Minor on their academic plan
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Strategic and managerial challenges and issues related to use of the Internet and other electronic channels as marketing tools.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Digital Marketing - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: MRKTNG 3000; Honors eligibility required.  May be restricted during early registration to business students only and/or students who have declared the Digital Marketing Certificate on their academic plan and/or students who have declared the Entrepreneurship & Innovation Minor on their academic plan
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Strategic and managerial challenges and issues related to use of the Internet and other electronic channels as marketing tools.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Social Media Marketing
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: MRKTNG 3000. May be restricted during early registration to business students only and/or students who have declared the Digital Marketing Certificate on their academic plan
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Develop an understanding of Social Media Marketing (SMM) and how it is used by marketers to increase brand awareness, identify key audiences, generate leads and to build meaningful relationships with customers. Students will learn how social media marketing is utilized by business to gain competitive advantages through the creation and distribution of valuable, relevant and consistent content to attract and retain clearly defined audiences. During early registration, some sections may be restricted to College of Business students who have declared a Digital Marketing certificate on their plan of study. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Search Engine Strategies
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: MRKTNG 3000. May be restricted during early registration to business students only and/or students who have declared the Digital Marketing Certificate on their academic plan
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Explore Search Engine Optimization (SEO), the process of optimizing a web page and its content to increase its visibility amongst users searching for keywords relevant to your site. Learn about powerful strategies and web-based tools that can be leveraged to gain valuable insights into your web traffic and how to improve your site's user experience. Learn how to implement a successful SEO strategy, where to research keywords, how to refine them, and when to use them. Understand how to interpret analytics reports and identify trends and issues and how to evaluate data to identify opportunities for improvement. During early registration, some sections may be restricted to College of Business students who have declared a Digital Marketing certificate on their plan of study. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: CX: The Digital Customer Experience
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: MRKTNG 3000. May be restricted during early registration to business students only and/or students who have declared the Digital Marketing Certificate on their academic plan
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Understand the increasing importance of Customer Experience marketing. Learn techniques to track and analyze the ever-changing nature of your digital customers, create feedback loops and fully embed the customer experience within your business. Explore automation techniques to deliver a timely and personalized customer service experience. During early registration, some sections may be restricted to College of Business students who have declared a Digital Marketing certificate on their plan of study. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Global Marketing
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: MRKTNG 3000. May be restricted during early registration to business students only and/or students who have declared the Global Business Certificate on their academic plan
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Strategic and managerial issues associated with international trade and international marketing.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Entering Global Markets
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: MRKTNG 3000. During early registration, some sections may be restricted to College of Business students with emphasis in Marketing, or International Business with emphasis in Marketing
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Applied marketing principles for international business. Skills development for the creation of strategic marketing plans to enter global markets. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Contemporary Issues in Marketing
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: MRKTNG 3000. During early registration, some sections may be restricted to College of Business students with emphasis in Marketing, or International Business with emphasis on marketing
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Selected topical issues, their impact on marketing and marketers, and implications for firms and industries.  Emphasis on scanning the external environment, projection of trends, and analysis; strategy development based on environmental analysis.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Data Analytics and Machine Learning for Business
Marketing Supply Chain Analytics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Obtain consent in Graduate Programs Office
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with MRKTNG 4890).  This course focuses on applying data analytic tools and techniques at various supply chain stages, specifically focusing on retailers. At the end of the course, the students will develop supply chain analytical skills for solving several marketing supply chain problems such as demand forecasting, inventory management, and sales and operations planning.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Data Analytics and Machine Learning for Business
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with MRKTNG 4910). Introduction and overview of Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning applications in the domain of marketing and other business areas. Students will work with analytical tools and models, learn to derive actionable insight from using these tools, and gain knowledge of contemporary issues involving collecting, analyzing, and sharing  data.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Applied Statistics for Marketing Analytics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: MBA program consent, prior statistical coursework
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course is designed to increase students' understanding of essential statistical methods, focusing primarily on interpretation and application in marketing contexts.  During the course, students will apply statistical concepts and analyses in diverse marketing settings with a variety of data sets.  By the end of the course, students will know when and how to apply fundamental statistical techniques in marketing situations, how to interpret the results of statistical analysis, and how to present results in a managerially useful manner.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning Applications in Marketing
Introduction to Research Methods in Marketing
Seminar in Advanced Research Methods in Marketing
Seminar in Applied Multivariate Analysis in Marketing
Quantitative Reasoning
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: C- or higher in MATH _0110 or a sufficient score on the myMath test
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Promotes mathematical literacy among students. This course will cover important mathematical ideas and problem solving skills in the context of science, technology, and/or society. Topics may include: logic and critical thinking, Venn Diagrams, problem solving, sets, units of measure, percentages and ratios, counting and probability, exponential growth and decay, linear and exponential models. Quantitative Reasoning is designed to stimulate interest in and appreciation of mathematics and quantitative reasoning as valuable tools for comprehending the world in which we live. This course does not satisfy the prerequisite of any other MATH course.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: College Algebra
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: C- or higher in MATH _0110 or MyMathTest Intermediate Algebra score of 70% or higher
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: A review of exponents, order of operations, factoring, and simplifying polynomial, rational, and radical expressions. Topics include: linear, quadratic, polynomial, rational, inverse, exponential, and logarithmic functions and their applications. Students will solve equations involving these functions, and systems of linear equations in two variables, as well as inequalities.  See the Math website for specific requirements.  Students may receive credit for MATH 1100 or MATH 1160, but not both.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Trigonometry
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: C- or higher in MATH 1100 or MyMathTest College Algebra score of 70% or higher
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Students may receive credit for MATH 1140 or MATH 1160, but not both.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Precalculus Mathematics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: B+ or higher in MATH _0110 (at MU), or C- or higher in MATH 1100, or MyMathTest College Algebra score of 60% or higher
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Review of elementary algebra. Background material for MATH 1500, including algebraic, trigonometric, logarithmic, exponential functions.  Students may receive credit for MATH 1100 or MATH 1160, but not both. Students may receive credit for MATH 1140 or MATH 1160, but not both.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Finite Mathematics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Grade of C- or higher in MATH 1100 OR MATH 1160; or both a College Algebra exemption AND a MyMathTest College Algebra score of 70% or higher
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: A selections of topics in finite mathematics such as: basic financial mathematics, counting methods and basic probability and statistics, systems of linear equations and matrices.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Geometric Concepts
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: C- or higher in MATH 1100 or sufficient ALEKS exam score or MATH 1160 or equivalent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course is primarily for education majors. This course covers topics of Euclidean geometry such as the study of points, lines, angles, polygons, circles, congruence, similarity, transformations, symmetry, area, surface area, arc length, and volume. Polyhedra, spheres, cones, and other solids are discussed. The course includes constructions and proofs, and uses inductive and deductive reasoning throughout.  Math Reasoning Proficiency Course.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Calculus for Social and Life Sciences I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: grade of C- or higher in MATH 1100, or MATH 1160, or sufficient ALEKS score
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: The real number system, functions, analytic geometry, derivatives, integrals, maximum-minimum problems. No credit for students who have completed a calculus course.  Students may receive credit for MATH 1400 or MATH 1500.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Analytic Geometry and Calculus I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: grade of C- or higher in MATH 1160 or C - or higher in both MATH 1100 and MATH 1140 or sufficient ALEKS score or MyMathTest PreCalculus score of 70% or higher
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Elementary analytic geometry, functions, limits, continuity, derivatives, antiderivatives, definite integrals. Students may receive credit for MATH 1400 or MATH 1500, but not both.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Analytic Geometry and Calculus I - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: C- or higher  in MATH 1160 or C- in  both MATH 1100 and MATH 1140 and sufficient ALEKS score.  Honors Eligibility required
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Elementary analytic geometry, functions, limits, continuity, derivatives, antiderivatives, definite integrals.   Honors eligibility required.   A student may receive at most 5 units of credit among  MATH 1320 or MATH 1400 and MATH 1500.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Calculus II
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: a grade of C- or better in MATH 1500
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Definite integrals, applications and techniques of integration, elementary transcendental functions, infinite series.  Math Proficiency Reasoning course.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Calculus II - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: a grade of C- or better in MATH 1500. Honors eligibility required
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Definite integrals, applications and techniques of integration, elementary transcendental functions, infinite series.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Calculus for Social and Life Sciences II
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: C- or higher in  MATH 1320 or MATH 1400 or MATH 1500
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Riemann integral, transcendental functions, techniques of integration, improper integrals, functions of several variables and ordinary differential equations. No credit for students who have completed two calculus courses.  Math Reasoning Proficiency course.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Calculus III
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: grade of C- or better in MATH 1700
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Vectors, solid analytic geometry, calculus of several variables.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Calculus III - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: grade of C or better in MATH 1700. Honors eligibility required
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Vectors, solid analytic geometry, calculus of several variables.  .

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Discrete Mathematical Structures
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Grade of C- or higher in MATH 1700
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Sets, functions, logic, relations, induction, recursion, counting techniques, graphs, trees, algorithms.  Math Reasoning Proficiency course.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to Advanced Mathematics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Gateway to theoretical math courses.  Focus on reading and writing math proofs/rigorously developing background needed in Adv Calc/Abstract Alg.  Topics include logic, set theory, properties of functions and integers, the real number system, completeness of the real numbers, sequences of real numbers.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to Advanced Mathematics - Writing Intensive
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Gateway to theoretical math courses.  Focus on reading and writing math proofs/rigorously developing background needed in Adv Calc/Abstract Alg.  Topics include logic, set theory, properties of functions and integers, the real number system, completeness of the real numbers, sequences of real numbers.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Connecting Geometry to Middle and Secondary Schools
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Consent of Department requiredRecommended: MATH 1360 or  MATH 1500
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with MATH 7060). Euclidean foundations, logic, Euler Characteristic, congruence, area, Pick's Theorem, volume, Cavalieri's Principle, surface area, similarity, symmetry, transformations, matricies, introduction to spherical geometry.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Connecting Algebra to Middle and Secondary Schools
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: MATH 1400, enrollment is restricted to Math Education majors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with MATH 7070). A detailed study of integer and rational arithmetic and algebra.  Topics include: Bionomial Theorem, induction, division algorithm, Euclid's Algorithm, Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic, Pythogorian triples, modular arithmetic and generalizations to polynomials, matrices and other axiomatic structures.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Calculus Connections
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: MATH 1160, enrollment is restricted to Math Education majors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Course topics include: sequences, series, functions, limits, continuity, differentiation, optimization, curve sketching, antidifferentiation, areas of plane regions, lengths of plane curves, areas of surfaces of revolution, and volumes of solids.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Differential Equations
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Grade of C- or above in MATH 2300
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with MATH 7100). Traditional introductory course in ordinary differential equations. Includes 1st and 2nd order linear differential equations with numerous applications; Laplace transforms; power series solutions; numerical methods, linear systems.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Differential Equations - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Grade of C- or above in MATH 2300; Honors eligibility required
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with MATH 7100). Traditional introductory course in ordinary differential equations. Includes 1st and 2nd order linear differential equations with numerous applications; Laplace transforms; power series solutions; numerical methods, linear systems.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Graph Theory and Combinatorics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: MATH 2320 or MATH 3000 or instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with MATH 7120). This course provides an introduction to graph theory and related topics in combinatorics. Topics include counting spanning trees, colorings of graphs and chromatic polynomials, matchings, network flows, and planar graphs.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Matrix Theory
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Grade of C- or better in MATH 2300 or MATH 2320.  Writing intensive sections require ENGLSH 1000
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with MATH 7140). Basic properties of matrices, determinants, vector spaces, linear transformations, eigenvalues, eigenvectors, and Jordan normal forms. Introduction to writing proofs.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Matrix Theory - Writing Intensive
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Grade of C- or better in MATH 2300 or MATH 2320.  Writing intensive sections require ENGLSH 1000
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Basic properties of matrices, determinants, vector spaces, linear transformations, eigenvalues, eigenvectors, and Jordan normal forms. Introduction to writing proofs.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Numerical Analysis
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Grade of C- or better in MATH 2300 and MATH 4100
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with MATH 7300). Machine arithmetic, approximation and interpolation, numerical differentiation and integration, nonlinear equations, linear systems, differential equations, error analysis. Selected algorithms will be programmed for solution on computers.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Numerical Linear Algebra
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: MATH 2300 and familiarity with software such as Mathematica, MatLab, Maple, etc
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with MATH 7310). Solution of linear systems of equations by direct and iterative methods. Calculation of eigenvalues and eigenvectors of matrices. Selected algorithms programmed for solution on computers.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to Mathematical Statistics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as STAT 4710; cross-leveled with MATH 7315, STAT 7710). Introduction to theory of probability and statistics using concepts and methods of calculus.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to Probability Theory
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as STAT 4750; cross-leveled with MATH 7320, STAT 7750). Probability spaces; random variables and their distributions; repeated trials; probability limit theorems.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Theory of Numbers
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Grade of C- or higher in MATH 2300. Recommended  MATH 2320
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with MATH 7330). Divisibility, factorization, arithmetic functions, means value theorems, distribution of prime numbers, congruences, primitive roots, character theory, Riemann zeta function, and Dirichlet L-functions.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to Non-Euclidean Geometry
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with MATH 4350). Account of rise, development of non-Euclidean geometries. Intensive study of plane hyperbolic geometry.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Mathematics of Financial Derivatives I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Grade of C- or higher in  MATH 2300 and  either STAT 2500 or STAT 4710 or MATH 4315
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with MATH 7355).  Long and short positions, forward contracts, exchange traded index futures, European and American call and put options, put-call parity, trading and hedging strategies, synthetic transactions, arbitrage, currency options, fixed income portfolio management, duration, convexity, interest rate and currency swaps, embedded options.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Mathematics of Financial Derivatives I - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Grade of C- or higher in  MATH 2300 and  either STAT 2500 or STAT 4710 or MATH 4315; honors eligibility required
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with MATH 7355).  Long and short positions, forward contracts, exchange traded index futures, European and American call and put options, put-call parity, trading and hedging strategies, synthetic transactions, arbitrage, currency options, fixed income portfolio management, duration, convexity, interest rate and currency swaps, embedded options.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Interest Theory
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: grade of C-or better in MATH 2300
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with MATH 7370). This course covers the concepts underlying the theory of interest and their applications to valuation of various cash flows, annuities certain, bonds, and loan repayment.  This course is designed to help students prepare for Society of Actuaries exam FM (Financial Mathematics).  It is oriented towards problem solving techniques applied to real-life situations and illustrated with previous exam problems.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Models for Life Contingencies I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with MATH 7371). The sequence MATH 4371 - MATH 4372 is designed to help students prepare for the Society of Actuaries exam LTAM (Long-Term Actuarial Mathematics). This course teaches the basic theory of life contingent actuarial models and the applications of those models to insurance and other financial risks. Covered topics include: survival models, life tables and selection, insurance benefits, life annuities, premium calculation and reserves.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Models for Life Contingencies II
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: A grade of C- or better in MATH 4371
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with MATH 7372). The sequence MATH 4371 - MATH 4372 is designed to help students prepare for the Society of Actuaries exam LTAM (Long-Term Actuarial Mathematics). This course extends the life-death contingency models of MATH 4371 to more general multiple-state and multiple-life models applied to problems involving a wide range of insurance and pension benefits. Covered topics include: Markov chains, multiple decrement models, joint life and last survivor benefits, pension mathematics, profit testing.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to Topology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with MATH 7400). Topics from topology of Euclidean spaces, generalizations to metric spaces and topological spaces. Fundamentals of point set topology. Proficiency with sets, logic, and proofs (at the level of MATH 3000) is recommended.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Applied Analysis
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Grade of C- or higher in MATH 4100
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with MATH 7500). Solution of the standard partial differential equations (wave, heat, Laplace's eq.) by separation of variables and transform methods; including eigenfunction expansions, Fourier and Laplace transform. Boundary value problems, Sturm-Liouville theory, orthogonality, Fourier, Bessel, and Legendre series, spherical harmonics.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Higher Algebra
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Grade of C- or higher in MATH 2300 or MATH 2320
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with MATH 7510). Introduction to rings, integral domains, fields, groups.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Statistical Inference I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as STAT 4760; cross-leveled with MATH 7520, STAT 7760). Sampling; point estimation; sampling distribution; tests of hypotheses; regression and linear hypotheses.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Mathematical Modeling I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Grade of C- or higher in MATH 2300 and MATH 4100Recommended: Familiarity with software such as MATHEMATICA, MATLAB, or MAPLE
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with MATH 7540, ECE 7560). Solution of problems from industry, physical, social and life sciences, economics, and engineering using mathematical models.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Nonlinear Dynamics, Fractals and Chaos
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: MATH 4100 or MATH 7100,  MATH 4140 or MATH 7140, and familiarity with software such as MATHEMATICA, MATLAB, or MAPLE
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with MATH 7560). Conceptual introduction to nonlinear dynamics, bifurcation and stability of steady states, chaos in nonlinear differential equations and maps, fractal dimension, strange attractors, and applications to physical science.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Mathematics of Financial Derivatives II
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: MATH 2300 and either STAT 2500 or STAT 4710 or MATH 4315Recommended: MATH 4355
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with MATH 7590). Binomial and Black-Scholes pricing models.Option Greeks, delta and gamma hedging, market maker profit theory.  Asian, barrier, compound gap and exchange options.  Lognormal and Monte Carlo price simulation.  Geometric Brownian Motion and Ito's Lemma.  Interest rate models and volatility.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Mathematics of Financial Derivatives II - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: MATH 2300 and either STAT 2500 or STAT 4710 or MATH 4315; Honors eligibility requiredRecommended: MATH 4355
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with MATH 7590). Binomial and Black-Scholes pricing models.Option Greeks, delta and gamma hedging, market maker profit theory.  Asian, barrier, compound gap and exchange options.  Lognormal and Monte Carlo price simulation.  Geometric Brownian Motion and Ito's Lemma.  Interest rate models and volatility.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Advanced Calculus of One Real Variable I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Grade of C - or higher in MATH 3000
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with MATH 7700). Basic topology of the real line, numerical sequences and series, continuity, differentiability, Riemann integration, uniform convergence, power series.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to Abstract Algebra I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Grade of C- or higher in MATH 3000
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with MATH 7720). Basic properties of integers, fundamental theorem of arithmetic, introduction to groups, rings and fields.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Advanced Multivariable Calculus
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with MATH 7900). This is a course in calculus in several variables.  The following is core material:  Basic topology of n-dimensional Euclidian space; limits and continuity of functions; the derivative as a linear transformation; Taylor's formula with remainder; the Inverse and Implicit Function Theorems, change of coordinates; integration (including transformation of integrals under changes of coordinates); Green's Theorem. Additional material from the calculus of several variables may be included, such as Lagrange multipliers, differential forms, etc.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to Abstract Linear Algebra
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Grade of C- or higher in  MATH 4720
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with MATH 7920). Study of vector spaces over arbitrary fields:  topics include linear maps on finite dimensional vector spaces, bilinear and multi-linear forms, invariant subspaces and canonical forms.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to Complex Variables
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with MATH 7940). Complex functions, contour integration, power series, residues and poles, conformal mapping.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Honors in Mathematics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Special work for senior B.A. Honors and B.S. Honors candidates.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Connecting Geometry to Middle and Secondary Schools
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: MATH 1360 or MATH 1500, enrollment is restricted to Math Education majors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with MATH 4060). Euclidian foundations, basic concepts of symbolic logic, polyhedra, Euler Characteristic, congruence, area, Picks Theorem, volume, Cavalier's Principles, surface area, similarity, reflections, translations, rotations, symmetry, vectors, general transformations, determinants, matricies, transformations using matricies, brief introduction to spherical geometry.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Connecting Algebra to Middle and Secondary Schools
Differential Equations
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with MATH 4100). Traditional introductory course in ordinary differential equations. Includes 1st and 2nd order linear differential equations with numerous applications; Laplace transforms; power series solutions; numerical methods, linear systems.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Graph Theory and Combinatorics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: MATH 2320 or MATH 3000 or instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with MATH 4120).This course provides an introduction to graph theory and related topics in combinatorics. Topics include counting spanning trees, colorings of graphs and chromatic polynomials, matchings, network flows, and planar graphs.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Matrix Theory
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: graduate standing and one of MATH 2300, MATH 2320, MATH 2120 or  MATH 2340
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with MATH 4140). Basic properties of matrices, determinants, vector spaces, linear transformations, eigenvalues, eigenvectors, and Jordan normal forms. Introduction to writing proofs.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Numerical Analysis
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: graduate standing and MATH 2300 and MATH 4100 or equivalent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with MATH 4300). Machine arithmetic, approximation and interpolation, numerical differentiation and integration, nonlinear equations, linear systems, differential equations, error analysis. Selected algorithms will be programmed for solution on computers.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Numerical Linear Algebra
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: MATH 2300 and prior experience writing programs in Mathematica and /or in a computer language such as Fortran, Pascal, or CRecommended: MATH 4140
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with MATH 4310). Solution of linear systems of equations by direct and iterative methods. Calculation of eigenvalues and eigenvectors of matrices. Selected algorithms programmed for solution on computers.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Theory of Numbers
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: MATH 2300; recommended MATH 2320 or MATH 2340, and MATH 4940 or MATH 7940
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with MATH 4330). Divisibility, factorization, arithmetic functions, means value theorems, distribution of prime numbers, congruences, primitive roots, character theory, Riemann zeta function, and Dirichlet L-functions.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to Non-Euclidean Geometry
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with MATH 4350). Account of rise, development of non-Euclidean geometries. Intensive study of plane hyperbolic geometry.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Mathematics of Financial Derivatives I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: MATH 2300 and STAT 2500 or STAT 4710/ MATH 4315, or instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with MATH 4355).  Long and short positions, forward contracts, exchange traded index futures, European and American call and put options, put-call parity, trading and hedging strategies, synthetic transactions, arbitrage, currency options, fixed income portfolio management, duration, convexity, interest rate and currency swaps, embedded options.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Interest Theory
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with MATH 4370). This course covers the main probability tools applied to financial risk modeling, and the financial mathematics concepts used in calculating present and accumulated values for various cash flows.  It is a helpful tool in preparing for the Society of Actuaries exams P (Probability) and FM (Financial Mathematics), and it is oriented towards problem solving techniques illustrated with previous exam problems.  Students are encouraged to take MATH 4355 prior to this course.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Models for Life Contingencies II
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: A grade of C- or better in MATH 4371 or MATH 7371
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with MATH 4372). The sequence MATH 4371 - MATH 4372 is designed to help students prepare for the Society of Actuaries exam LTAM (Long-Term Actuarial Mathematics). This course extends the life-death contingency models of MATH 4371 to more general multiple-state and multiple-life models applied to problems involving a wide range of insurance and pension benefits. Covered topics include: Markov chains, multiple decrement models, joint life and last survivor benefits, pension mathematics, profit testing.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to Topology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with MATH 4400). Topics from topology of Euclidean spaces, generalizations to metric spaces and topological spaces. Fundamentals of point set topology. Proficiency with sets, logic, and proofs (at the level of MATH 3000) is recommended.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Applied Analysis
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with MATH 4500). Solution of the standard partial differential equations (wave, heat, Laplace's eq.) by separation of variables and transform methods; including eigenfunction expansions, Fourier and Laplace transform. Boundary value problems, Sturm-Liouville theory, orthogonality, Fourier, Bessel, and Legendre series, spherical harmonics.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Higher Algebra
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with MATH 4510). Introduction to rings, integral domains, fields, groups.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Probability and Computing
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: MATH 2320 or MATH 3000W; STAT 4710/STAT 7710 or STAT 4750/STAT 7750Recommended: MATH 4120/MATH 7120, MATH 4140/MATH 7140
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as CMP_SC 7525; cross-leveled with CMP_SC 4525, MATH 4525). This course is concerned with probabilistic methods in computer science and discrete mathematics. Its goal is to study the interplay between probability and computational complexity,  and to demonstrate how tools from modern probability theory can be exploited in the study of structures that depend on many parameters, such as networks with many nodes and functions of many variables. Covered topics may include: discrete probability, concentration inequalities, martingale methods, the probabilistic method, entropy and information, Vapnik-Chervonenkis theory. Applications to (theoretical) computer science, combinatorics, random graphs, randomized algorithms, probabilistic analysis, derandomization.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Mathematical Modeling I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: graduate standing and 3 semesters of calculus and some exposure to ordinary differential equations or instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as ECE 7560, CMP_SC 7560; cross-leveled with MATH 4540). Solution of problems from industry, physical, social and life sciences, economics, and engineering using mathematical models.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Nonlinear Dynamics, Chaos and Fractals
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: graduate standing and MATH 4100/ MATH 7100, MATH 4140/ MATH 7140, and familiarity with software such as MATHEMATICA, MATLAB, or MAPLE
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with MATH 4560). Conceptual introduction to nonlinear dynamics, bifurcation and stability of steady states, chaos in nonlinear differential equations and maps, fractal dimension, strange attractors, and applications to physical science.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Mathematics of Financial Derivatives II
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: MATH 2300 and either STAT 2500 or STAT 4710 or MATH 4315Recommended: MATH 4355
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with MATH 4590). Binomial and Black-Scholes pricing models.Option Greeks, delta and gamma hedging, market maker profit theory.  Asian, barrier, compound, gap and exchange options.  Lognormal and Monte Carlo price simulation.  Geometric Brownian Motion and Ito's Lemma.  Interest rate models and volatility.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Advanced Calculus of One Real Variable I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: MATH 2300Recommended: MATH 4140 and one other mathematics course number above MATH 2300
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with MATH 4700). Series of real numbers, limits of functions, continuity and uniform continuity, differentiability, and Riemann integration.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to Abstract Algebra I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: MATH 2300Recommended: MATH 4140 and one other Mathematics course numbered above 2300
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with MATH 4720). Basic properties of integers, fundamental theorem of arithmetic, introduction to groups, rings and fields.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Advanced Multivariable Calculus
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with MATH 4900). This is a course in calculus in several variables.  The following is core material:  Basic topology of n-dimensional Euclidian space; limits and continuity of functions; the derivative as a linear transformation; Taylor's formula with remainder; the Inverse and Implicit Function Theorems, change of coordinates; integration (including transformation of integrals under changes of coordinates); Green's Theorem. Additional material from the calculus of several variables may be included, such as Lagrange multipliers, differential forms, etc.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to Abstract Linear Algebra
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with MATH 4920). Study of vector spaces over arbitrary fields:  topics include linear maps on finite dimensional vector spaces, bilinear and multi-linear forms, invariant subspaces and canonical forms.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to Complex Variables
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with MATH 4940). Complex functions, contour integration, power series, residues and poles, conformal mapping.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Mathematics Problem Solving
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: MATH 4140 and another 4000 level Mathematics course, or instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Creative advanced problem solving bringing together methods such as integration, probability and Euclidean geometry.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Topics in Algebra
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Advanced topics in algebra.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Basic Algebra
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: MATH 4720, MATH 4920, or instructor's consent, or equivalentCorequisites: MATH 8220 and MATH 8250
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Accelerated problem solving course in linear and abstract algebra. Will prepare students for the algebra qualifying exam.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Basic Analysis
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: MATH 4700, MATH 4900, MATH 4940, instructor's consent or equivalent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Accelerated problem-solving course in advanced calculus and complex analysis.  Will prepare students for the analysis qualifying exam.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Basic Topology and Geometry
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: MATH 4700, MATH 4900, MATH 4140, or instructor's consent, or equivalentCorequisites: MATH 8210 and MATH 8220
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Topological spaces, differential manifolds, differential forms, integration of vector fields.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Algebra I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Theory of algebraic structures--groups, rings, fields, algebraic and transcendental extensions of fields.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Algebra II
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Theory of modules, Galois theory and additional topics to be selected by the instructor.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Theory of Functions of Real Variables I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: MATH 4700 or MATH 7700 and MATH 4900 or MATH 7900, or equivalent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Properties of functions of one real variable. Lebesgue measure and integration on the line.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Theory of Functions of Real Variables II
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Continuation of MATH 8420. General measure and integration theory.  Elements of the theory of Hilbert and Banach spaces, linear functions and linear operators.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Complex Analysis I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Rigorous introduction to the theory of functions of a complex variable.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Complex Analysis II
