Senior Thesis I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: PEA_ST 1050, senior standing, and instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Senior essay on a Peace Studies topic requiring major research.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Theory and Practice of Theatre of the Oppressed
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as THEATR 7240; cross-leveled with PEA_ST 4240, THEATR 4240). Theory and practice of Augusto Boal's liberatory interactive theatre process, including application of techniques of specific social issues.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Empire: Intellectual History, Literature, and Society
Law and Society: Corporate and White Collar Crime and Malfeasance
Gender and Human Rights in Cross Cultural Perspective
Personal and Family Finance
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: MATH 1050 or MATH 1100 (or higher) with grade of C- or above
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Individual and family finance, with particular emphasis on financial planning, budgeting, savings, insurance, investments, taxes, use of credit, and financial aspects of housing, retirement planning and estate planning basics. Students develop the necessary skills to make rational financial decisions in adulthood.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Personal and Family Finance - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Honors eligibility required, MATH 1050 or MATH 1100 (or higher) with grade of C- or above or instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Individual and family finance, with particular emphasis on financial planning, budgeting, savings, insurance, investments, taxes, use of credit, and financial aspects of housing, retirement planning and estate planning basics. Students develop the necessary skills to make rational financial decisions in adulthood. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Financial Planning: Computer Applications
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: FINPLN 2183 with grade of C or above or equivalent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course provides an understanding of how to use spreadsheet applications in analyzing the financial situations, needs, and goals of families and individuals. Topics covered in the course include constructing personal financial statements, cash flow analysis and projections, charts and tables, time value of money applications as they relate to education savings, retirement needs, and other areas of financial planning, pro-forma analysis, and amortization and accumulation tables. The course help students gain a working knowledge of how to analyze a family's financial position and how to project the family's future financial situations.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Financial Planning: Tax Planning
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with FINPLN 7187).  Principles, current law and practice of income taxation and its impact on personal financial planning decisions. Content includes tax regulations, tax return preparation, tax formula, and tax audit process.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Community Agencies and Volunteerism
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course provides students with an experiential learning opportunity to work one-on-one in a professional setting with individuals and families from diverse backgrounds. Students will gain an applied understanding of federal and state income taxation and experience reviewing client financial materials, creating required client documents, and resolving client complications. Students will need to attend a three-day training before the start of the semester or provide evidence of completion of the IRS VITA certification process on the first day of class. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Assessing the American Dream
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: A systems perspective examining ways choice and culture shape American levels and standards of living.  Evaluates effects of trends in personal and family values, technology, economy, mass media, diversity and inclusivity, and other social change on household resource management.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Assessing the American Dream - Writing Intensive
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with FINPLN 7380). A systems perspective examining ways choice and culture shape American levels and standards of living.  Evaluates effects of trends in personal and family values, technology, economy, mass media, diversity and inclusivity, and other social change on household resource management.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Financial Planning: Risk Management
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with FINPLN 7382).Analysis of financial risk management and insurance planning for individuals in the context of personal financial planning decisions. Content includes life insurance, health insurance, disability insurance, long-term care insurance, property and casualty insurance, social security and Medicare, annuities. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Financial Planning: Investment Management
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with FINPLN 7383). This course introduces theories and strategies of wealth management including basic concepts, investment techniques, and methodologies. Topics covered include: asset classes and market structure, risk and returns, portfolio theory, investment decisions and analysis, market efficiency and behavioral finance, fixed income and equity securities, investment companies, and taxation of investment. This course will also provide case practice and discussion and collaboration activities that facilitate students' learning and practicing their knowledge and skills.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Financial Planning: Employee Benefits and Retirement Planning
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: FINPLN 2183 and FINPLN 3283, or instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with FINPLN 7386).Fundamentals of employee benefits and retirement planning in the context of personal financial planning decisions.  Content includes a survey of various types of retirement plans, legal and tax requirements for a retirement plan, assessing and forecasting financial needs in retirement, distribution rules, and integration of retirement plans with government benefits.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Consumer and Household Economics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: ECONOM 1014 or ABM 1041, and ABM 2225 or STAT 2500, or instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with FINPLN 7387). Economic theory of consumer and household behavior, focusing on rationality, uncertainty, optimal search, heuristics, interactive decisions and considering implications for financial decision making and policy analysis.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Financial Planning: Capstone
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: FINPLN 3283 and FINPLN 4187 and FINPLN 4382 and FINPLN 4383 and FINPLN 4386 and FINPLN 4393, or instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with FINPLN 7389). The course emphasizes the use of analytical skills and techniques to develop effective financial plans for individuals and families.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Financial Planning: Estate and Gift Planning
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with FINPLN 7393). This course is an overview of the family estate and gift planning process from a financial planning perspective. Topics covered include: introduction, basic estate planning documents, types of property interests, the probate process, gift and estate taxes, transfer during life and at death, and the utilization of estate and gift planning strategies and tools. This course will also provide case practice and discussion and collaboration activities that facilitate students' learning and practicing their knowledge and skills.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Topics in Household Economics and Finance
Financial Planning: Employee Benefits and Retirement Planning
Consumer and Household Economics II
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: ECONOM 4351 or equivalent, or instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with FINPLN 4387). Economic theory of consumer and household behavior, focusing on rationality, uncertainty, optimal search, heuristics, interactive decisions and considering implications for financial decision making and policy analysis.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Financial Planning: Capstone
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: FINPLN 7187 and FINPLN 7382 and FINPLN 7383 and FINPLN 7386 and FINPLN 7393
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with FINPLN 4389). The course emphasizes the use of analytical skills and techniques to develop effective financial plans for individuals and families.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Financial Planning: Estate and Gift Planning
Readings in Household Economics and Finance
Problems in Household Economics and Finance
Seminar in Household Economics and Finance
Master's Thesis Research in Personal Financial Planning
Theories and Research in Personal Financial Planning I
Theories and Research in Personal Financial Planning II
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Course reviews theories and empirical research in household financial decision-making, drawing from macroeconomic theory, theories of household behavior, lifecycle hypothesis, behavioral economics and finance, theories of behavioral change and psychological theories of family well-being. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Advanced Risk Management
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Risk management, a building block of personal financial planning, seeks to identify the risks of a person faces and evaluate their financial impacts in the event of an occurrence. Once the relevant risks have been identified, the financial planner must determine the need for insurance based on the financial goal and assess the various risk handling tools available to select the one that can best serve client's financial goal. This course is an advanced study of risk management and insurance. The course will cover legal principles in risk and insurance, private insurance industry, and commercial property and liability risks. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Applied Research in Household Economics and Planning
Household Financial Decision Making
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: FINPLN 7383 and FINPLN 7386, or instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Critical thinking and problem solving on issues related to household financial decision making.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Advanced Projects in Personal Financial Planning
Doctoral Dissertation Research in Personal Financial Planning
The Big Questions: An Introduction to Philosophy
The Big Questions: An Introduction to Philosophy - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Introduction to traditional philosophical problems and methods of philosophical inquiry. Consideration given to different philosophical theories on the nature of reality, human beings, nature and God; knowledge and how it is acquired; values and social issues.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: The Difference Between Right and Wrong: An Introduction to Ethics
The Difference Between Right and Wrong: An Introduction to Ethics - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Introduction to different philosophical theories regarding when acts are morally right rather than wrong; when things are good rather than bad; nature of the "good life", nature of ethical reasoning and justification.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: How to Think: Logic and Reasoning for Everyday Life
How to Think: Logic and Reasoning for Everyday Life - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Methods of analyzing and evaluating arguments of all types. Uses both informal and formal techniques. Identifies informal fallacies and introduces elementary symbolic logic.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Philosophy: East and West
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as S_A_ST 2100). Compares the interpretation and role of philosophical concepts such as experience, reason, permanence, change, immortality, soul, God, etc., in Indian, Chinese and European traditions.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Philosophy and Intellectual Revolution
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Examines such revolutions as the Copernican, Darwinian, Marxian and Freudian. What are the new views? How is our place in the universe affected? What puzzles arise in replacing old by new views?

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Philosophy and Human Nature
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Philosophical exploration and examination of theories of human nature with reference to relevant developments in such sciences as biology, psychology, and economics.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Ethics and the Professions
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Examination of ethical issues confronted by members of different professions such as medicine, law, business, journalism and engineering.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Philosophies of War and Peace - Writing Intensive
Ethical Issues in Business
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Major theories of moral obligation and justice and their application to business practices. Corporate responsibility, government regulation, investment and production, advertisement, the environment, preferential hiring, etc. through case studies, legal opinions and philosophical analysis.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Contemporary Moral Issues
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Review of the major contemporary ethical theories and their contribution to the resolution of major social issues such as euthanasia, suicide, abortion, capital punishment, violence and war. Emphasis on nature, interests, and rights of persons. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Philosophy and Gender
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as WGST 2500). A critical examination of central ideas and themes in feminist philosophical thought.  Topics may include:  sex, marriage, parenthood, reproduction, body image, pornography, prostitution.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Philosophy and Gender - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: A critical examination of central ideas and themes in feminist philosophical thought. Topics may include: sex, marriage, parenthood, reproduction, body image, pornography, prostitution.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Rational Decisions
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: sophomore standing and grade of C or better in MATH 1050, MATH 1100, MATH 1160, MATH 1400, or MATH 1500
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Principles for making decisions in a rational way. Special attention to principles that use probabilities and utilities. Some discussion of decisions made in conjunction with other people, and decisions made for other people.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Elementary Logic
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: sophomore standing and grade of C or better in MATH 1050, MATH 1100, MATH 1160, MATH 1400, or MATH 1500
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as LINGST 2700). Introduces a symbolic language for representing the structure of arguments. Presents precise rules for demonstrating the validity of arguments. Covers natural deduction for sentence and predicate logic. Develops skill in constructing derivations.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Minds, Brains, and Machines
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as PSYCH 2820 and LINGST 2820).  Cognitive science is a many-splendored thing. It draws on a variety of disciplines, including psychology, neuroscience, computer science, linguistics, anthropology, and philosophy. The purpose of this course is to introduce the central questions of cognitive science, the conceptual and empirical tools used to investigate those questions, and some of the answers that have emerged so far. After an initial overview of the foundations of the cognitive-scientific enterprise as a whole, we will see what particular sectors of it have to say about mental capacities such as language, categorization, reasoning, social cognition, and consciousness.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Minds and Morals: An Introduction to Moral Psychology
Environmental Ethics - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Environmental Ethics explores the ethical, ecological, and policy dimensions of a range of issues such as climate change, land and natural resource management, sustainability, animal rights, hunting and fishing, ecofeminism, property rights, and environmental justice. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Ancient Western Philosophy
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: sophomore standingRecommended: one course in Philosophy
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as AMS 3025). Philosophical thought on nature, knowledge, the gods, human life and society, from Thales to Augustine. Emphasis on Plato and Aristotle. The relevance of the ancients to contemporary life.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Ancient Western Philosophy - Writing Intensive
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: sophomore standingRecommended: one course in Philosophy
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as AMS 3025). Philosophical thought on nature, knowledge, the gods, human life and society, from Thales to Augustine. Emphasis on Plato and Aristotle. The relevance of the ancients to contemporary life.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Medieval Philosophy
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: sophomore standingRecommended: one course in Philosophy
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Major thinkers from St. Augustine through 14th century Ockhamists.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Modern Philosophy
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: sophomore standingRecommended: one course in Philosophy
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Surveys critical and speculative thinking of modern period from Descartes to Kant in relation to scientific, religious and social movements.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Modern Philosophy - Writing Intensive
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: sophomore standingRecommended: one course in Philosophy
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Surveys critical and speculative thinking of modern period from Descartes to Kant in relation to scientific, religious and social movements.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: 19th Century Philosophy
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: sophomore standingRecommended: one course in Philosophy
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: A careful and sympathetic study of some of the major thinkers of this period, notably Kierkegaard and Nietzsche.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Existentialism
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: sophomore standingRecommended: one course in Philosophy
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: The nature of human existence, the meaning of life, the relation of the individual to nature, society, and any gods that may be, according to Kierkegaard, Nietzsche, Heidegger, Sartre, de Beauvoir, Camus and others. Students are encouraged to come to grips with the issues in relation to their own lives.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: 20th Century Philosophy
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: sophomore standingRecommended: one course in Philosophy
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: The course will be a survey of some of the notable philosophers/thinkers whose contributions have been made in the twentieth century.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Selected Modern Philosophers
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: sophomore standingRecommended: one course in Philosophy
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Advanced study of a particular philosopher or a number of philosophers from the same school in the modern period. May be taken twice for credit with permission of the department.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Selected Contemporary Philosophers
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: sophomore standingRecommended: one course in Philosophy
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Advanced study of a particular contemporary philosopher or philosophers.  May be taken twice for credit with permission of the department.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Philosophy of Language
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: sophomore standing and PHIL 2700Recommended: one other course in Philosophy
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as LINGST 4100; cross-leveled with PHIL 7100, LINGST 7100).  Examination of contemporary views of the relationship between language, minds, and the world.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Philosophy of Language - Writing Intensive
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: sophomore standing and PHIL 2700Recommended: one other course in Philosophy
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as LINGST 4100; cross-leveled with PHIL 7100, LINGST 7100).  Examination of contemporary views of the relationship between language, minds, and the world.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Advanced Logic
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as LINGST 4110; cross-leveled with PHIL 7110, LINGST 7110). Presents the method of truth trees for sentence and predicate logic. Examines proofs concerning the decidability, soundness, and completeness of formal systems. Emphasizes the theory of formal systems.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Selected Topics in Logic
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: sophomore standing and either PHIL 2700 or PHIL 4110
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with PHIL 7120). Possible topics include elementary set theory and modal logic, the logic of possibility and necessity.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Probability and Induction
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with PHIL 7130). This course studies probability, its various interpretations, and its basic principles.  It identifies forms of reasoning that establish the probability of a conclusion.  The methods of reasoning it treats are at the heart of science and practical affairs.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Metaphysics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: sophomore standingRecommended: Previous work in PHIL 1000, PHIL 3000 or PHIL 3200
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Metaphysics studies what there is and how things are, most generally speaking. Topics may include realism versus nominalism, substance and attribute, facts, modality, identity and causality.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Metaphysics - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: sophomore standingRecommended: Previous work in PHIL 1000, PHIL 3000 or PHIL 3200
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Metaphysics studies what there is and how things are, most generally speaking. Topics may include realism versus nominalism, substance and attribute, facts, modality, identity and causality.   Prerequisites: Honors Eligibility required.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Philosophy of Mind
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with PHIL 7210). Considers theories and arguments in contemporary philosophy of mind, focusing on the nature of mental states, their relation to brain states and the plausibility of various materialist theories of the mind.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Philosophy of Mind - Writing Intensive
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with PHIL 7210). Considers theories and arguments in contemporary philosophy of mind, focusing on the nature of mental states, their relation to brain states and the plausibility of various materialist theories of the mind.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Philosophy of Religion
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: sophomore standingRecommended: One course in Philosophy
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with PHIL 7220) . Considers basis for and nature of religious beliefs.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Philosophy of Religion - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: sophomore standing; Honors eligibility requiredRecommended: One course in Philosophy
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with PHIL 7220). Considers basis for and nature of religious beliefs.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Philosophy of Religion - Honors/Writing Intensive
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: sophomore standing; Honors eligibility requiredRecommended: One course in Philosophy
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with PHIL 7220). Considers basis for and nature of religious beliefs.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Philosophy of Religion - Writing Intensive
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: sophomore standingRecommended: One course in Philosophy
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with PHIL 7220) . Considers basis for and nature of religious beliefs.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Epistemology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: sophomore standingRecommended: Previous work in PHIL 1000, PHIL 3000, PHIL 3200
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with PHIL 7300). An examination of contemporary philosophical theories concerning the nature, sources and limits of knowledge and justified belief.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Philosophy of Science
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: sophomore standingRecommended: two courses in Philosophy
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with PHIL 7400). Why believe the scientific world-view? What, if anything, is the scientific method? Are today's theories really superior to past theories? Examines contemporary philosophical answers to such questions.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Philosophy of Science - Writing Intensive
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: sophomore standingRecommended: two courses in Philosophy
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with PHIL 7400). Why believe the scientific world-view? What, if anything, is the scientific method? Are today's theories really superior to past theories? Examines contemporary philosophical answers to such questions.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Philosophy of History
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: sophomore standingRecommended: two courses in Philosophy
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with PHIL 7210). Readings from classic and contemporary philosophers of history. Problems about nature and limits of historical knowledge; relation between history and other disciplines; the existence, nature, and kinds of historical laws.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Philosophy of Biology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: sophomore standingRecommended: two courses in Philosophy
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: A survey of philosophical problems arising from consideration of evolutionary theory and the biological sciences.  Topics may include reductionism, sociobiology, biological laws, and epistemic problems relating to evolutionary theory.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Political and Social Philosophy
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: sophomore standingRecommended: two courses in Philosophy
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as PEA_ST 4600; cross-leveled with PHIL 4210).  Contemporary and/or historical theories of justice and the state. Utilitarianism, Liberalism, Libertarianism, Marxism, Communitarianism and Feminism may be among the views covered.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Philosophy of Law
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: sophomore standingRecommended: one course in Philosophy
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with PHIL 7610). What is law? Are there pre- or trans-legal rights? Is punishment justifiable? How can judicial decisions be justified? What are the relations between law and morality?

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Marxism
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Sophomore standingRecommended: two courses in Philosophy
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with PHIL 7620). A philosophical examination of (a) the notion of critique as seen in Marx's early and middle writings, and (b) specific topics by such authors as Lenin, Lukacs and Plekhanov.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Art, Beauty, and the Brain: An Introduction to Aesthetics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with PHIL 7700). An introduction to aesthetics focusing on issues in the philosophy and psychology of art. Topics include theories of aesthetic appreciation and interpretation, the objectivity of aesthetic judgment, the nature of beauty and the sublime, and the neural basis of aesthetic experience.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Art, Beauty, and the Brain: An Introduction to Aesthetics - Writing Intensive
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: sophomore standingRecommended: one course in Philosophy
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with PHIL 7700). An introduction to aesthetics focusing on issues in the philosophy and psychology of art. Topics include theories of aesthetic appreciation and interpretation, the objectivity of aesthetic judgment, the nature of beauty and the sublime, and the neural basis of aesthetic experience..

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Asian Philosophy
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: sophomore standingRecommended: one course in Philosophy
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as S_A_ST 4800; cross-leveled with PHIL 7800). This course traces the origins of Indian and Chinese philosophical world views. Included are the major ideas in Hindu, Jaina, and Buddhist thought in India, and Taoism and Confucianism in China. Emphasis is placed on the diverse, assimilative, and pragmatic nature of Indian thought and its impact on contemporary Asian philosophy.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Philosophy of India
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: sophomore standingRecommended: one course in Philosophy
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as S_A_ST 4810; cross-leveled with PHIL 7810).  General development of Indian philosophy.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Senior Seminar in Philosophy
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: A capstone course required of and only open to senior Philosophy majors. Course content will vary, depending on the professor teaching the course.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Senior Seminar in Philosophy - Writing Intensive
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: A capstone course required of and only open to senior Philosophy majors. Course content will vary, depending on the professor teaching the course.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Honors I in Philosophy
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Special work for Honors candidates.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Honors II in Philosophy
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Special work for Honors candidates.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Philosophy of Language
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: PHIL 2700 or instructor's consentRecommended: Some work in PHIL 1000, PHIL 3000 or PHIL 3200
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as LINGST 7100; cross-leveled with PHIL 4100, LINGST 4100).  Examination of contemporary views of the relationship between language, minds, and the world.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Selected Topics in Logic
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with PHIL 4120).  Possible topics include elementary set theory and modal logic, the logic of possibility and necessity.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Formal Semantics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Basic proficiency in first order logic
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with PHIL 4150). The course provides a systematic introduction to the semantics of natural languages, using the tools of formal logic.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Art, Beauty, and the Brain: An Introduction to Aesthetics
Protoseminar in Philosophy
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: restricted to first year graduate students
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Introduction to graduate level work in philosophy. Required of all students entering the program, in the first year. An intensive workshop focused on skills rather than any particular philosophical content.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Topics in Modern Philosophy: 17th-19th Centuries
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Interpretation and evaluation of philosophical debates from the 17th to the 19th centuries. These will be addressed in relation to their historical context and current philosophical problems.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Plato
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Advanced studies in Plato; emphasis on recent scholarship.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Aristotle
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Advanced studies in Aristotle; emphasis on recent scholarship.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: The Rationalists
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Interpretation and evaluation of major works of Descartes, Leibniz, and/or Spinoza in relation to their historical context and current philosophical problems.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: The Empiricists
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Epistemological and metaphysical doctrines of Locke, Berkeley and Hume.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Kant
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Critique of Pure Reason: historical context, meaning and cohesion of its claims, critical assessment of them.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Russell and Wittgenstein
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Each initially defends, but then rejects logical atomism. Metaphysical and epistemological themes of such intellectual phases and shifts of one or both philosophers.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Social and Political Philosophy
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: PHIL 4600 or instructor's consent and graduate Philosophy student
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Topics of current interest in social and political philosophy. generally one of the following: social contract theory, utiltarianism, voting procedures, or convention.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: History of Eastern Ethics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Historical survey of major eastern ethical theories. Explores broad range of ethical theories developed in Asia: Hindu and Buddhist in India; Toaism and Confucianism in China; and Zen in Japan.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Decision Theory
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Principles for making rational decisions, including principles of expected utility theory, game theory, and social choice theory. A survey of basic ideas and an introduction to selected research topics.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Ethical Theory
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Contemporary theories of the right and the good. Metaethical topics such as moral language, reasoning, and justification.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Metaphysics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Theories of the categories and structures of reality, e.g., appearance and reality, causality, space and time, God, Nature, the human being.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Philosophy of Mind and Psychology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Survey of important recent work in contemporary philosophy of mind and psychology. Graduate seminar.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Foundations of Cognitive Science
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Examination of philosophical questions arising in cognitive science concerning, for instance, the nature of computation and representation, inter-disciplinary relations, the nature of cognitive scientific explanation, and its relation to folk psychological explanation.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Epistemology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Knowledge and opinion, the types, sources, and extent of knowledge, according to a variety of views.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Philosophy of Science
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Examines central issues in general philosophy of science concerning the scientific method and the role in it of observation, the nature of rational theory-choice, progress, and the status of theories postulating unobservables.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Philosophy of Language
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Topics of current interest in the philosophy of language.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Seminar in Logic
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Topics of current interest in logic. Generally one of the following: inductive logic, set theory, conditionals, epistemic logic, or formal semantics.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Seminar in Philosophy
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Special topics. May be repeated for credit.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Rehabilitation of Musculoskeletal and Neurologic Diseases
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Successful completion of the first two years of medical school
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: The rotating student will be an integral part of the inpatient team, serving in an active role on the floor and participating in the evaluation and treatment of clinic patients. Daily morning rounds will be completed with the inpatient teams and will be followed by scheduled didactic sessions with various faculty throughout the week. Outpatient rotations will be included as a fundamental clinical experience and will encompass the breadth of PM&R to the best that can be accomplished in this short block. In-depth examinations of the neurologic and musculoskeletal systems will be performed.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Human Kinesiology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Study of principles of physical laws, biomechanics and anatomic structure relative to human movement. Applications through analysis of daily functional performance, exercise, and sport.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Applied Neurophysiology for Allied Health Students

Case Management: Acute and Chronic Medical and Surgical Conditions

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as HTH_PR 4250). Study of principles of physical laws, biomechanics and anatomic structure relative to human movement. Applications through analysis of daily functional performance, exercise, and sport.

Everyday Wonders: Explaining How Ordinary Things Work

Topics covered are vectors, kinematics, dynamics, gravity, momentum, energy, rotational kinematics, rotational dynamics, fluids, simple harmonic motion, waves and sound, and thermodynamics. Three lectures, one discussion, one lab weekly. Students may receive credit for PHYSCS 1210 or PHYSCS 2750, but not both.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: College Physics II
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: grade of C- or better in PHYSCS 1210
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This introductory second semester college physics course uses algebra and trigonometry in developing some of the fundamental concepts of classical physics. Topics covered include electricity and magnetism, optics and modern physics. Three lectures, one discussion, one lab weekly. Students may receive credit for PHYSCS 1220 or PHYSCS 2760, but not both.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: College Physics II - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: grade of C- or better in PHYSCS 1210; Honors eligibility required
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This introductory second semester college physics course uses algebra and trigonometry in developing some of the fundamental concepts of classical physics. Topics covered include electricity and magnetism, optics and modern physics. Three lectures, one discussion, one lab weekly. Students may receive credit for PHYSCS 1220 or PHYSCS 2760, but not both.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Topics in Physics and Astronomy- Biological Science
Topics in Physics and Astronomy- Biological Science - Honors
Topics in Physics and Astronomy- Physical Science
Topics in Physics and Astronomy- Physical Science - Honors
Exploring the Principles of Physics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: A hands-on course covering topics in Electricity, Magnetism, Forces, Motion and Energy. Pedagogy reflects styles used in K-12 classrooms; emphasis on inquiry, concept development, quantitative applications and technology. Enrollment limited to Elementary and Early Childhood Education majors who have completed MATH 1100 or higher.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: The Beautiful Invisible: Exploring Physics, Fiction, and Reality
University Physics I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: First course in calculus-based physics for science and engineering students. Topics covered are vectors, translational and rotational kinematics, translational and rotational dynamics, energy, momentum, gravity, oscillations, waves, fluids and thermodynamics. Three lectures, one discussion, one lab weekly. Students may receive credit for PHYSCS 1210 or PHYSCS 2750, but not both.
