https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: MATH 1500 or equivalent. Honors eligibility requiredRecommended: MATH 1700
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: First course in calculus-based physics for science and engineering students. Topics covered are vectors, translational and rotational kinematics, translational and rotational dynamics, energy, momentum, gravity, oscillations, waves, fluids and thermodynamics. Three lectures, one discussion, one lab weekly. Students may receive credit for PHYSCS 1210 or PHYSCS 2750, but not both.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: University Physics II
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: MATH 1700 and grade of C- or better in PHYSCS 2750Recommended: MATH 2300
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Second semester course in calculus-based physics for science and engineering students. Topics covered are electrostatics, circuits, magnetism, electromagnetic phenomena, optics, matter waves and particles and modern physics.  Three lectures, one discussion, one lab weekly. Students may receive credit for PHYSCS 1220 or PHYSCS 2760, but not both.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: University Physics II - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: MATH 1700 and grade of C- or better in PHYSCS 2750. Honors Eligibility requiredRecommended: MATH 2300
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Second semester course in calculus-based physics for science and engineering students. Topics covered are electrostatics, circuits, magnetism, electromagnetic phenomena, optics, electromagnetic waves and relativity. Three lectures, one discussion, one lab weekly. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Topics in Physics and Astronomy - Biological Science
Topics in Physics and Astronomy -Physical Science
Introduction to Modern Astrophysics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as ASTRON 3010). Elements of stellar, and galactic astrophysics. Interpretation of observations and physical conditions of various astronomical objects including stars, gaseous nubulea and, galaxies.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Teaching Physics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Introduces modeling and inquiry methods of teaching about force, motion, energy, electricity and magnetism.  Students learn research-base physics teaching methods, including eliciting prior understanding, facilitating conceptual change, and active learning strategies.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to Modern Physics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Relativistic kinematics and Lorentz transformations; historical basis for quantum mechanics; atomic structure; physics of solids; nuclear structure and decay.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to Modern Physics - Writing Intensive
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Relativistic kinematics and Lorentz transformations; historical basis for quantum mechanics; atomic structure; physics of solids; nuclear structure and decay.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Physics of Space Explorations
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: The course provides an overview of the solar system, spaceflight history, a review of Newtonian physics and law of universal gravitation, the application of these laws to spacecraft launch, entry, and orbit, planetary trajectories, and other special topics.  Three focused case studies of actual space missions are addressed.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Physics of Energy in Technology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Physics principles as they relate to energy technology, how physics principles enable applications and provide constraints. Introduction to aspects of materials performance, thermodynamics, semiconductor physics and nuclear physics. These are in the context of energy production, power plants, engines, nuclear energy, hydroelectric, solar and wind. Students gain appreciation of physics principles and their roles in technology of importance for society. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to Methods in Mathematical Physics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: The course discusses the application of mathematical techniques that students need for upper-level physics courses. Topics include: applications of complex variables, second-order linear differential equations with applications to AC circuits, matrices/linear algebra, calculus of variations, Fourier transforms and vector analysis.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Astrophysical Techniques
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as ASTRON 4020; cross-leveled with PHYSCS 7020). Elements of modern astronomical instruments, observations and analysis, with the emphasis in the optical regime. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Electronic Laboratory
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with PHYSCS 7050). Acquaints students with the foundations and techniques of electronics design, with emphasis on data acquisition and processing.  Topics: circuits with discrete and integrated circuits, active and passive filters, amplifiers, power supplies, instrumentation and interfacing.  Integrated lectures and labs.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Advanced Physics Laboratory I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This upper-level undergraduate laboratory course familiarizes students with the methods and procedures of experimental physics at an advanced level. The course covers principles of magnetism, graphic programming and interface techniques, weak-signal detection, and some modern physics discoveries such as, magneto-optical Kerr effect, digital holography and gamma-ray spectroscopy. Students work on research projects in the areas of condensed matter physics, materials science, modern spectroscopy, superconductivity, and quantum physics.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Major Themes in Classical Physics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Introduction to classical physics: mechanics, electromagnetism and thermodynamics, emphasizing the unity and the connections between different parts of it.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Major Themes in Classical Physics - Writing Intensive
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Introduction to classical physics: mechanics, electromagnetism and thermodynamics, emphasizing the unity and the connections between different parts of it.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Electricity and Magnetism I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Mathematical preliminaries, properties of charge distributions at rest and in motion, the field concept, introduces electromagnetic radiation.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Light and Modern Optics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with PHYSCS 7110). Interaction of light with matter, spectroscopic techniques, wave optics, interferometry, multilayer films, polarization, non-linear optics, design of optical instruments, matrix methods, waveguides, fiber optics, acousto-optic and photo-elastic modulation. Includes both lectures and laboratory.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to Thermodynamics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Development of the concepts of temperature, heat, work, entropy, enthalpy and free energy. Applications to gases, liquids and solids. Statistical methods.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Mechanics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Development of fundamental concepts, principles of mechanics using mathematical methods. Many problems used.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Solar System Science
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as GEOL 4180, ASTRON 4180; cross-leveled with GEOL 7180, PHYSCS 7180).  Investigates physical states, interior structures and comparative geology of solar systems bodies:  planets, moons, asteroids, comets, sun. Solar system formation and evolution.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Physics and Chemistry of Materials
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: PHYSCS 2750, CHEM 1320 or equivalent, or instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as NU_ENG 4319, BIOL_EN 4480, CHEM 4490, BME 4480; cross-leveled with PHYSCS 7190, NU_ENG 7319, BIOL_EN 7480, CHEM 7490). Physics and Chemistry of Materials is a 3 credit hours course offered every spring semester for students from Physics, Chemistry, Engineering and Medical Departments and consists of lectures, laboratory demonstrations, two mid-term and one final exam. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Contributions to Science from Under-represented Groups
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: PHYSCS 2760 or PHYSCS 1200 or instructors consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as ASTRON 4210; cross-leveled with ASTRON 7210, PHYSCS 7210). STEM fields are amongst the areas of human endeavor that struggle with increasing their human diversity. Teaching of science rarely discusses the contributions or marginalizations of under-represented groups. Meanwhile, many women and indigenous cultures have contributed to progress in STEM but are often not recognized. In this course we will investigate these contributions, and the lack of recognition both historically and in the present day. The aim is to provide students with a better understanding of the advantages of and challenges in inclusive, diverse science. Initially the course will use astronomy as its frame of reference because the sky was one of the earliest laboratories and consequently it has a long history with many indigenous cultures developing their own cosmologies and ways of studying the sky. As we discuss the role of Indigenous peoples, people of color, and women, we will investigate the role of power structures as well as systemic biases in the marginalization of these groups. This class will be strongly discussion oriented, with assessment based on the development throughout the semester, of a final project. As many students will be pursuing graduate school in STEM fields, the final project will be to develop a Broader Impact statement. Many federal funding agencies request or even require that research grants include a component aimed at 'broadening participation', i.e. making STEM more inclusive and diverse. Student will work on a multipart assignment that will culminate in a Broader Impact statement that may well be directly applicable to an NSF GRFP (Graduate Research Fellowship Program) or NSF Post-Doctoral Fellowship. In addition to the Broader Impact statement - students will give presentations and learn how to be more inclusive in their presentation design, following the principles of Inclusive Design for Learning.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Stellar Astrophysics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as ASTRON 4250). Basic astrophysics of stable and unusual stars, stellar systems. Investigates stellar dimensions, radiation, spectra, energy, evolution, populations; interstellar medium, stellar motions and aggregation.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Galactic Astronomy
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as ASTRON 4350). Observational properties of normal galaxies and clusters of galaxies, Seyfert and emission-line structure and dynamics of galaxies; interacting galaxies, quasi-steller objects. Introduction to cosmology.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Extragalactic Astronomy
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as ASTRON 4360; cross-leveled with ASTRON 7360, PHYSCS 7360). This course introduces students to the most basic knowledge of extragalactic astronomy, starting from Milky Way and extending to the most distant universe.  Topics covered will include galaxy morphology and classification, groups and clusters of galaxies, active galactic nuclei, and galaxy formation and evolution.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: The Physics of Electronic Devices
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with PHYSCS 7400). This course is designed for graduate and undergraduate students of Physics and Electrical Engineering who have an interest in learning the basic physical idea underlying the operation of electronic devices.  The course consists of lectures, handout lecture notes, problem sets, two mid-term and one final exam. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Analysis of Biological Macromolecules and Biomaterials
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with PHYSCS 7410).This interdisciplinary, team-taught course introduces basic concepts and experimental techniques for studying bio-macromolecules and biomaterials.  A Problem Based Learn/Writing Intensive approach uses four modules: Proteins, membranes, cellular interactions and biomaterials.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to Biomedical Imaging
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as BIOL_EN 4420, BME 4420; cross-leveled with PHYSCS 7420, BIOL_EN 7420). This course offers a broad introduction to medical imaging.  Topics to be covered include the physics basics and instrumentation of X-ray, CT, PET, SPECT, ultrasound, MRI, and optical imaging, as well as recent developments in biomedical imagining.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to Cosmology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as ASTRON 4450; cross-leveled with PHYSCS 7450, ASTRON 7450).  Develops the physical concepts necessary for understanding the major recent discoveries in cosmology, such as the acceleration of the universe and dark energy.  No prior knowledge of general relativity is assumed. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Interstellar Medium
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as ASTRON 4460; cross-leveled with ASTRON 7750, PHYSCS 7750). The course discusses observational properties and physical and chemical processes occurring in the interstellar medium.  Topics include interstellar diffuse and molecular clouds, HII regions, dust grains, interstellar chemistry, star formation, supernova remnants, and interstellar shock waves.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Computational Biological Physics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with PHYSCS 7500). Provides a practical introduction (hands-on approach) to the study of the structure and function of biomolecular systems by employing computational methods and theoretical concepts familiar from the physical sciences.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Single Molecule Biophysics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as BIOCHM 4510; Cross-leveled with PHYSCS 7510).  The course provides an overview of the biophysics of enzymes, nucleic acids and the cytoskeleton.  Topics covered will include diffusion, molecular motors, polymerization and the cytoskelton and the polymer properties of nucleic acids and microtubules

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to Biophysics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: PHYSCS 1220 or PHYSCS 2760 or instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course introduces the study of biological systems from the perspective of a physicist. Students will learn how to relate the structure of a particular system and its constituents to its function. The treatment of molecular and cellular phenomena will be based on physical principles quantified through the necessary analytical tools. Prominent biophysical methods and their fundamental operating principles will also be discussed. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Cosmochemistry
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as ASTRON 4550; cross-leveled with ASTRON 7550, PHYSCS 7550).  Cosmic dust, stardust, spectra, energy, interstellar medium, meteorites, astromineralogy.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Semiconductor Optics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with PHYSCS 7600).  It is an introductory-level course in the field of optical processes in semiconductors (both inorganic and organic) and solid-state optoelectronics, designed both for graduate and undergraduate students of Physics, Chemistry and Electrical Engineering. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to Materials Science
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course on the science and technology of materials explores the interrelationship between processing, structure, properties (electrical, optical, magnetic), and performance. Observable properties of materials will be used to explore and understand the consequences of atomic- and molecular-level events. Structure-property correlations, including electronic, thermal, and mechanical properties, will be presented for different classes of materials including nanoscale materials. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Modern Condensed Matter Physics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with PHYSCS 7650).  Introduces the basic concepts and gives an overview of the latest developments of modern condensed-matter physics as the forefront of (nano) science and technology.  Combines lectures and computational laboratory, where students use and develop interactive computer simulations. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to Density-Functional Theory
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with PHYSCS 7680). This course provides an introduction to density-functional theory (DFT), the most widely used technique for calculating the electronic structure of materials. The course covers the basic formalism of DFT and practical applications, including hands-on computational exercises. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Nonlinear Dynamics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with PHYSCS 7720). This course provides an introduction to nonlinear dynamical systems and chaos, with examples from physics, chemistry, biology and engineering. The emphasis will be on applications, using a combination of analytical, computational and intuitive geometrical methods. Topics covered include phase portraits, fixed point analysis, bifurcations, limit cycles, strange-attractors, iterated maps, period doubling, chaos, fractals, scaling and universality. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Quantum Computation and Quantum Information
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: PHYSCS 3150 or PHYSCS 3150W, MATH 4140, or instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course introduces the main ideas and techniques of quantum computation - a fascinating and rapidly developing field of research. The course explains how the strange and counter-intuitive features of quantum mechanics can be harnessed to perform tasks that would be extremely time-consuming, or even impossible, if approached by classical means.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to Quantum Mechanics I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Foundations of wave mechanics; wave packets; Schrodinger equation and I-D problems; operators and eigenfunctions, spherically symmetric systems.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to Quantum Mechanics II
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Review of quantum mechanics and units, forms of radiation, radiation detectors, spacetime symmetries, internal symmetries, nuclear structure and form factors, low-energy nuclear models, recent developments.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Computational Methods in Physics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with PHYSCS 7850).  Use of modern computational techniques in solving a wide variety of problems in solid state, nuclear, quantum and statistical physics.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Senior Thesis in Physics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: instructor's consent and 3 units of PHYSCS 4950. Departmental consent required for repetition
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Special studies for senior undergraduate students in physics. The course requires an oral or poster presentations, or faculty-guided writing of a senior thesis involving independent research.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Issues in Modern Physics and Engineering
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Students are expected to write a major paper on a selected topic from modern physics or engineering.  The paper will review the current state of the experimental and theoretical research on the topic at a level appropriate to their peers.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Electronic Laboratory
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with PHYSCS 4050). Acquaints students with the foundations and techniques of electronics design, with emphasis on data acquisition and processing.  Topics: circuits with discrete and integrated circuits, active and passive filters, amplifiers, power supplies, instrumentation and interfacing. Integrated lectures and labs. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Light and Modern Optics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with PHYSCS 4110). Interaction of light with matter, spectroscopic techniques, wave optics, interferometry, multilayer films, polarization, non-linear optics, design of optical instruments, matrix methods, waveguides, fiber optics, acousto-optic and photo-elastic modulation. Includes both lectures and laboratory.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Solar System Science
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: PHYSCS 1220 or PHYSCS 2760 or instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as GEOL 7180 and ASTRON 7180; cross-leveled with GEOL 4180 and ASTRON 4180).  Investigates physical states, interior structures and comparative geology of solar systems bodies:  planets, moons, asteroids, comets, sun. Solar system formation and evolution.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Physics and Chemistry of Materials
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: PHYSCS 2750, CHEM 1320 or equivalent, or instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as NU_ENG 7319, BIOL_EN 7480, CHEM 7490; cross-leveled with PHYSCS 4190, NU_ENG 4319, BIOL_EN 4480, CHEM 4490, BME 4480). Physics and Chemistry of Materials is a 3 credit hours course offered every spring semester for students from Physics, Chemistry, Engineering and Medical Departments and consists of lectures, laboratory demonstrations, two mid-term and one final exam. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Contributions to Science from Under-represented Groups
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: PHYSCS 2760 or PHYSCS 1200 or instructors consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as ASTRON 7210; cross-leveled with PHYSCS 4210, ASTRON 4210). STEM fields are amongst the areas of human endeavor that struggle with increasing their human diversity. Teaching of science rarely discusses the contributions or marginalizations of under-represented groups. Meanwhile, many women and indigenous cultures have contributed to progress in STEM but are often not recognized. In this course we will investigate these contributions, and the lack of recognition both historically and in the present day. The aim is to provide students with a better understanding of the advantages of and challenges in inclusive, diverse science. Initially the course will use astronomy as its frame of reference because the sky was one of the earliest laboratories and consequently it has a long history with many indigenous cultures developing their own cosmologies and ways of studying the sky. As we discuss the role of Indigenous peoples, people of color, and women, we will investigate the role of power structures as well as systemic biases in the marginalization of these groups. This class will be strongly discussion oriented, with assessment based on the development throughout the semester, of a final project. As many students will be pursuing graduate school in STEM fields, the final project will be to develop a Broader Impact statement. Many federal funding agencies request or even require that research grants include a component aimed at "broadening participation", i.e. making STEM more inclusive and diverse. Student will work on a multipart assignment that will culminate in a Broader Impact statement that may well be directly applicable to an NSF GRFP (Graduate Research Fellowship Program) or NSF Post-Doctoral Fellowship. In addition to the Broader Impact statement - students will give presentations and learn how to be more inclusive in their presentation design, following the principles of Inclusive Design for Learning.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Extragalactic Astronomy
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as ASTRON 7360; cross-leveled with PHYSCS 4360, ASTRON 4360). This course introduces students to the most basic knowledge of extragalactic astronomy, starting from Milky Way and extending to the most distant universe.  Topics covered will include galaxy morphology and classification, groups and clusters of galaxies, active galactic nuclei, and galaxy formation and evolution.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Physics of Electronic Devices
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with PHYSCS 4400). This course is designed for graduate students of Physics and Electrical Engineering who have an interest in learning the basic physical idea underlying the operation of electronic devices.  The course consists of lectures, handout lecture notes, problem sets, two mid-term and one final exam.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Analysis of Biological Macromolecules and Biomaterials
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with PHYSCS 4410). This interdisciplinary, team-taught course introduces basic concepts and experimental techniques for studying bio-macromolecules and biomaterials.  A Problem Based Learn/Writing Intensive approach uses four modules: proteins, membranes, cellular interactions and biomaterials.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to Biomedical Imaging
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as BIOL_EN 7420; crossleveled with PHYSCS 4420, BIOL_EN 4420, BME 4420).  This course offers a broad introduction to medical imaging. Topics to be covered include the physics basics and instrumentation of X-ray CT, PET, SPECT, ultrasound, MRI, and optical imaging, as well as recent developments in biomedical imaging.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to Cosmology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: PHYSCS 3150 or equivalent or instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as ASTRON 7450; cross-leveled with ASTRON 7450, PHYSCS 4450).  Develops the physical concepts necessary for understanding the major recent discoveries in cosmology, such as the acceleration of the universe and dark energy.  No prior knowledge of general relativity is assumed. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Computational Biological Physics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: PHYSCS 1220 or PHYSCS 2760 or instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with PHYSCS 4500). Provides a practical introduction (hands-on approach) to the study of the structure and function of biomolecular systems by employing computational methods and theoretical concepts familiar from the physical sciences.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Single Molecule Biophysics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as BIOCHM 7510; cross-leveled with PHYSCS 4510). The course provides an overview of the biophysics of enzymes, nucleic acids and the cytoskeleton.  Topics covered will include diffusion, molecular motors, polymerization of the cytoskelton and the polymer properties of nucleic acids and microtubules

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Cosmochemistry
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as ASTRON 7550; cross-leveled with PHYSCS 4550, ASTRON 4550).  Cosmic dust, stardust, spectra, energy, interstellar medium, meteorites, astromineralogy.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Semiconductor Optics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with PHYSCS 4600).  It is an introductory-level course in the field of optical processes in semiconductors (both inorganic and organic) and solid-state optoelectronics, designed both for graduate and undergraduate students of Physics, Chemistry and Electrical Engineering.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Modern Condensed Matter Physics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with PHYSCS 4650).  Introduces the basic concepts and gives an overview of the latest developments of modern condensed matter physics as the forefront of (nano) science and technology.  Combines lectures and computational laboratory, where students use and develop interactive computer simulations. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to Density-Functional Theory
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with PHYSCS 4680). This course provides an introduction to density-functional theory (DFT), the most widely used technique for calculating the electronic structure of materials. The course covers the basic formalism of DFT and practical applications, including hands-on computational exercises. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Interstellar Medium
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as ASTRON 7750; cross-leveled with ASTRON 4460, PHYSCS 7750). The course discusses observational properties and physical and chemical processes occurring in the interstellar medium. Topics include interstellar diffuse and molecular clouds, HII regions, dust grains, interstellar chemistry, star formation, supernova remnants, and interstellar shock waves.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Computational Methods in Physics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with PHYSCS 4850).  Use of modern computational techniques in solving a wide variety of problems in solid state, nuclear, quantum and statistical physics.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Study of Techniques of Teaching College Physics
Condensed Matter Physics I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Crystal structure, reciprocal lattice, phonons, neutron and x-ray scattering, free electron theory of metals, Fermi surfaces, energy bands, static properties of solids, semiconductors, devices, and quantum structures, optical properties, excitons, introduction to magnetism and superconductivity.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Condensed Matter Physics II
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: The basic Hamiltonian, Phonons, theory of the electron gas, second quantization, Hartree and Hartree-Fock approximation, local-density method, tight-binding theory, electron-electron interaction and screening, Fermi liquid theory, transport properties, impurities, Green's function's, Localization, Quantum Hall effect, magnetism, superconductivity.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Structure, Electronic Structure and Properties of Condensed Matter
Topological Phenomena in Condensed Matter Physics
Topics in Astronomy and Astrophysics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Selected topics from solar system, stellar, galactic and extragalactic astronomy and astrophysics. May be repeated to a maximum of six hours.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Concepts in Nanoscale Materials: Interdisciplinary Science
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This interdisciplinary course covers basic concepts in nanoscale materials, their characterization, and how and why they differ from conventional bulk materials. The course focuses on neutron scattering methods and uses lectures, problem-based modules, and writing assignments.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: X-ray and Neutron Scattering Methods for Studying Surfaces/Interfaces of Nanocrystalline Materials
Stellar Structure and Evolution
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as ASTRON 8550). Reviews of atomic and molecular spectra. Investigates quantum radiation law, emission and absorption processes, radiation transfer theory, continuous and discrete line spectra of stars, stellar composition.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Classical Mechanics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: The interplay of dynamics and symmetry, Hamilton's principle and Noether's theorem, Lagrangian, Hamiltonian, Hamilton-Jacobi theories of mechanics in special relativity. Rigid body motion, small oscillation, canonical transformations and fields as continuous mechanical systems.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Electrodynamics I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Electrostatic potential and fields, boundary-value problems in electrostatics, methods of images, Green's functions, multipole expansion, dielectrics, magnetostatics, magnetic materials, Maxwell's' equations, time-varying fields.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Electrodynamics II
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Electromagnetic wave propagation, reflection, refraction, wave guides, cavities antennas and diffraction, tensors, special relativity, the Lorentz group, dynamics of relativistic particles and fields radiation by moving charges, retardation, bremsstrahlung.  Additional topics may include magnetohydrodynamics and plasma physics.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Methods in Mathematical Physics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Concentrates on mathematical techniques used in modern physics. Infinite series, functions of a complex variable, differential equations, Fourier series and integral, etc.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Thermodynamics and Statistical Mechanics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Thermodynamics as applied in physics, chemistry; laws of distribution; statistical methods of study matter, radiation.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Non-Equilibrium Statistical Mechanics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course provides an introduction to the theoretical and mathematical description of classical stochastic systems with examples from biophysics and condensed matter physics.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Quantum Mechanics I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Non-relativistic quantum theory in Hilbert space. States and self-adjoint observables, unitary time evolution in various pictures, the path-integral, identical particles, Fock space, angular momentum and some pertubation theory.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Quantum Mechanics II
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: More perturbation theory, variational methods, semi-classical methods and application to radiation theory, linear response theory and rudiments of relativistic quantum mechanics including the Klein-Gordan equation and the Dirac equation.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Relativity and Gravitation
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Special and general theories of relativity. Discussion of accelerated observers and the principles of equivalence. Einstein's gravitational field equations, black holes, gravitational waves and cosmology.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Plant Structure and Function
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Introduction to plant anatomy;physiology; how plant structures and processes are involved in growth/development.  Labs explore photosynthesis, mineral nutrition, water relations, growth, and hormonal regulation.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Grapes and Wines of the World
Ornamental Landscape Plants I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Identification and evaluation of woody and herbaceous stemmed ornamental landscape plants.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Ornamental Landscape Plants II
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Annuals, biennials, perennials, ground covers, and bulbs; their identification, nomenclature classification, culture and use.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Ornamental Landscape Plants II - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: BIO_SC 1010 or BIO_SC 1500 or BIO_SC 1200; Honors eligibility required
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Annuals, biennials, perennials, ground covers, and bulbs; their identification, nomenclature classification, culture and use.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to Floral Design
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Some sections of this course may be restricted to Plant Science Majors Only and/or students with 75 credit hours or less
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Introduction to the basics of floral design with special emphasis on design mechanics, flower processing, care and handling.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to Floral Design - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Honors eligibility required; Some sections of this course may be restricted to Plant Science Majors Only and/or students with 75 credit hours or less
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Introduction to the basics of floral design with special emphasis on design mechanics, flower processing, care and handling.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Everyday Floral Design
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Intermediate floral design course expanding skills from introductory floral design with emphasis on the elements and principles of design.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Landscape Design
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: An introduction into the processes, principles, and practices of landscape design, this course begins with site analysis and moves through the drawing and presentation of your landscape concepts.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Principles of Weed Science
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Introduction to principles of weed growth, reproduction, and impact on human activities. Discussion of weed control techniques and technology, weed identification, and developing weed management strategies.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Principles of Weed Science - Writing Intensive
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Introduction to principles of weed growth, reproduction, and impact on human activities. Discussion of weed control techniques and technology, weed identification, and developing weed management strategies.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Genetics of Agricultural Plants and Animals
Special Occasion Floral Design
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: PLNT_SCI 2220 and PLNT_SCI 2221 with grade of B or above in both
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Advanced floral design course with emphasis in silk décor, sympathy design and public ceremony design.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Wedding Floral Design
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: PLNT_SCI 2220 and PLNT_SCI 2221 with grade of B or above in both
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Advanced floral design course with emphasis in wedding floral design and personal pieces design.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Retail Floral Management
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Course focusing on all areas of retail floral management: business finance, marketing, products and services, employee management, and customer service.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Retail Floral Management - Writing Intensive
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Course focusing on all areas of retail floral management: business finance, marketing, products and services, employee management, and customer service.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Plant Breeding and Genetics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Mendelian genetic principles and related genetic developments applicable in plant breeding. Discussion of established and new plant breeding procedures applicable to cultivar development.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Principles of Viticulture I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: F_S 1010 and F_S 2195 or PLNT_SCI 2195; or PLNT_SCI 2100; or PLNT_SCI 2110; or PLNT_SCI 2125
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as F_S 3240). Grapevine growth, development, selection, propagation, training systems, pruning, and harvesting; vineyard site selection, design, and development. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Green Industry Bidding
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Plant Science major and completion of 30 credit hours
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Principles of interpreting drawings, estimating labor, equipment, materials and other costs and recordkeeping for preparation of competitive green industry bids.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Greenhouse Management
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Greenhouse design, environmental control and equipment. Practices associated with plant nutrition management, greenhouse pest control, postproduction handling and marketing of greenhouse crops, and greenhouse management are also covered.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Grain Crops
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Lecture and discussion covering production and utilization, plus growth and development of a wide range of grain crops, including Missouri crops. Problem solving tasks include agronomics, economics and environmental factors.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introductory Turfgrass Management
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Characteristics of turf materials, principles of establishment and maintenance.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Biology of Fungi
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as BIO_SC 3510). The diverse roles of fungi in the biosphere will be explored by considering fungi we eat, fungi which destroy our food, fungi in folklore and fungi as global nutrient recyclers.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Topics in Plant Science - Biological- Lab
Principles of Plant Breeding
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with PLNT_SCI 7225). This is an introductory course exploring the principles of plant breeding where we examine the application of genetics and the plant sciences to the breeding and improvement of field crops, focusing on conventional plant breeding principles. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Soil Fertility and Plant Nutrition
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as SOIL 4313; cross-leveled with PLNT_SCI 7313, SOIL 7313). Explanation of principles of delivery of plant nutrients to plants, discussion of the role of each essential nutrient in crop plants and introduction to the management of soil amendments.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Crop Physiology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with PLNT_SCI 7315). Basic course on crop growth and development. Emphasis is on physiological processes and morphology of crop plants, and their application to crop breeding and management decisions.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Advanced Plant Breeding
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: PLNT_SCI 2110 or PLNT_SCI 2125, and PLNT_SCI 3213 (or equivalent), and PLNT_SCI 3225 (or equivalent)
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with PLNT_SCI 7325). Will introduce students to the application of genetics and the plant sciences to the breeding and improvement of self-pollinated field crops. Classical, current and innovative plant breeding techniques will be addressed.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Principles of Viticulture II
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as F_S 4340).  Environmental and biological factors influencing vine physiology and winegrape quality.  Irrigation, canopy management, pest and disease control, budgets and current trends in viticulture. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Principles of Viticulture and Winemaking
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as F_S 4345; cross-leveled with PLNT_SCI 7345, F_S 7345). This course will cover the basics needed by viticulturists and winemakers to understand grape vine growth and vineyard considerations along with winemaking principles. Viticultural topics will include grapevine growth and development, vineyard design and development, cultivar selection, grapevine propagation, training systems, and harvest and pruning. Winemaking topics will include sensory analysis of grapes, chemical, microbiological and technological aspects of winemaking, and the analytical methods used for juice and wine analysis. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Advanced Turfgrass Management
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with PLNT_SCI 7355). Provides turfgrass majors a more informative and applicable look at mathematics of turfgrass management, application techniques, cultural practices, and soil/water relationships applicable to careers in golf course and sports turf management, lawn care, and professional grounds maintenance.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Precision Agriculture Science and Technology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as AG_S_TCH 4360, SOIL 4360; cross-leveled with PLNT_SCI 7360, AG_S_TCH 7360, SOIL 7360). Precision agriculture is an information-based approach to farming whereby variability is managed to optimize crop production and reduce environmental pollution. This course provides an overview of precision agriculture technologies (like GIS, GPS, remote sensing), mapping methods, and case studies illustrating decisions and management.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Greenhouse Crops Production
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with PLNT_SCI 7365). Production management decision and commercial culture of the major floriculture crops.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Plant Anatomy
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as BIO_SC 4400; cross-leveled with PLNT_SCI 7400, BIO_SC 7400). Comparative structure, growth of meristems; development, structure of important cell types, tissues systems; comparative anatomy of stem, root, leaf.  Emphasizes anatomy of gymnosperms, angiosperms.  Includes lab. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Biology and Pathogenesis of Plant-Associated Microbes
Aquatic Entomology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: PLNT_SCI 3710 or PLNT_SCI 3715 or equivalent, or instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with PLNT_SCI 7720).  Identification, life histories, ecology of aquatic insects.  Grading is based on lecture, lab, and a collection.  For students of wildlife, fisheries management, aquatic biology, advanced entomology.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Insect Pest Management for Plant Protection
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with PLNT_SCI 7730). History and concepts of Integrated Pest Management of insect pests, emphasizing complementary use of biological control, plant resistance, environmental manipulations, genetic manipulations, and selective use of insecticides.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Completion of 75 hours including two courses in department and instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Combines study, observation, and employment with an industry or government agency in area of agronomy or horticulture. Written and oral reports and faculty evaluation.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Experiential Learning in Industry Internship in Plant Science
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Learning experience combining observation, application, and reflection in a discipline-based industry internship. Course appears on transcript for zero credit and does not count toward full-time enrollment. No tuition or fees are charged. Graded on S/U basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Undergraduate Research in Plant Science
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Completion of 75 credit hours and Plant Science Majors only
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Capstone experience consisting of investigations in Plant Science in support of an undergraduate thesis or special project portfolio.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Experiential Learning in Research in Plant Science
Advanced Landscape Design

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: BIO_SC 1500 or BIO_SC 1200 and five hours of chemistry

Includes lab. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Biology and Pathogenesis of Plant-Associated Microbes
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with PLNT_SCI 4500). Diagnosis of disease of plants caused by fungi, nematodes, viruses and bacteria.  Environmental and genetic factors leading to disease development and strategies for disease management, including biotechnology.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Plant Biotechnology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: BIO_SC 2960 or equivalent; BIO_SC 2200 or equivalent; BIO_SC 2300 or equivalent; PLNT_SCI 2125
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with PLNT_SCI 4550). Principles of gene expression, metabolic pathway analysis and data mining, plant tissue culture and transformation, transgene integration and expression analysis, plant epigenome, emerging transgenic technologies, etc.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Systematic Entomology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: PLNT_SCI 3710 and PLNT_SCI 3715 or 10 hours Biological Sciences
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with PLNT_SCI 4710). Taxonomy of insects: emphasizes biology and classification of orders and suborders in lecture, and major families in lab.  Insect collection required.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Aquatic Entomology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: PLNT_SCI 3710, PLNT_SCI 3715 or equivalent or instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with PLNT_SCI 4720). Identification, life histories, ecology of aquatic insects.  Grading is based on lecture, lab, and a collection.  For students of wildlife, fisheries management, aquatic biology, advanced entomology.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Insect Pest Management for Plant Protection
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with PLNT_SCI 4730).   History and concepts of Integrated Pest Management for insects pests, emphasizing complementary use of biological control, plant resistance, environmental manipulations, genetic manipulations, and selective use of insecticides.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Principles of Insect Physiology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: PLNT_SCI 3710, PLNT_SCI 3715 and PLNT_SCI 7810 or equivalent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Major concepts of insect physiology emphasizing functions of organ-systems sensory physiology hormones in development, nutrition.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Advanced Landscape Design
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with PLNT_SCI 4975). Development of project presentation techniques by analysis of the social, cultural, historical and ecological aspects of landscape design.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Molecular Breeding and Genomic Technology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Development of molecular plant breeding, including genome sequencing, molecular markers,  genotyping methods, and genome editing. The course provides the principles and application of marker-assisted trait introgression, genomics-assisted selection, and fundamental and methodology of genome editing for crop improvement.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Advanced Weed Science
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Discussion of herbicide physiology and fate in the environment, current development in weed science theory and methodology, and application of analytical procedures in weed research.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Herbicide Mode of Action and Symptomology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Designed for graduate students to gain an understanding of the in-depth processes by which herbicides interrupt normal plant growth and development at a tissue, cellular, and enzymatic level while learning to diagnose visual symptoms associated with herbicide injury.  Course maybe repeated for credit.  Graded on A-F basis.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to Bioinformatics Programming
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Instructor's consentRecommended: Undergraduate or graduate course in Genetics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as AN_SCI 8430). This course provides the basics of programming and database development to students in the life sciences who have little prior programming experience. It covers Unix/Linux, Perl, MySQL, the relational database design process, and common data formats used in genome informatics. Students will learn how programming skills can enhance their ability to analyze large biological datasets, and will gain hands on experience with examples focused on genomics and bioinformatics. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Statistical Applications in Agriculture
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: STAT 4530/STAT 7530 or equivalent or instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as AN_SCI 8441). Techniques of experimentation, with application to livestock production and management. Exercises in methods of planning, conducting, analyzing, evaluating and reporting research.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Research with Plant Stress Agents
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: PLNT_SCI 7500 and PLNT_SCI 7510 or PLNT_SCI 7315, or PLNT_SCI 7320, or equivalent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Students will learn key research strategies for abiotic and biotic plant stress agents. Students will complete two focused hands-on projects. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Insect Behavior
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: PLNT_SCI 3710 and PLNT_SCI 3715 or 10 hours of Biological Sciences
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: An examination of the breadth of behaviors found in insects, such as orientation mechanisms, communication, dispersal and migration, defensive mechanisms, lost location, feeding strategies, pollination, courtship and reproduction, and social behavior.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Ecology of Grazing Lands Systems
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Students travel to grazing lands ecosystems to learn: the components and function of grazing lands; research techniques in soil-plant-animal research; forage-livestock ecology; and the role of forages in conservation practices, wildlife habitat, and sustainable agriculture.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Applied Quantitative and Statistical Genetics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: PLNT_SCI 4330,  STAT 4510, STAT 4530, AN_SCI 9423, or equivalent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Estimation of genetic effects using means and variances, diallel analysis, environmental stability responses, index selection, and gain from selection.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Genetics of Plant-Microorganism Interaction
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: PLNT_SCI 7500 and PLNT_SCI 7510, one course each in Biochemistry and Genetics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Molecular and general genetics of the interactions between plants and pathogenic or symbiotic microorganisms.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Insect Ecology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: PLNT_SCI 3710 and PLNT_SCI 3715, STAT 1400 and BIO_SC 3650 or instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Ecological aspects of insect populations and communities including population dynamics, predator-prey interactions, competition, diversity and stability. Quantitative methods are emphasized.

Missouri Politics - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course examines the government and politics of the state of Missouri. We will study the Missouri Constitution, the structure and function of the Missouri state government, and the politics - partisan and otherwise - of the state of Missouri. We will consider public policy development and implementation and examine several areas of that public policy: health, public safety, education, resource management, and others.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Globalization, Identity and Citizenship - Writing Intensive
The Intellectual World of the American Founders
The Intellectual World of the American Founders - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as CNST_DEM 2450H). This course demonstrates that truly understanding the American constitutional and democratic traditions begins with acknowledging and studying how, in framing the Constitution and in imagining the new nation, the Founders drew on the work and cobbled together the ideas of thinkers from multiple eras and continents and, moreover, thinkers of vastly different political ideologies and disciplinary expertise.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Constitutional Debates
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as CNST_DEM 2455). This is an undergraduate seminar on the political thought surrounding the drafting and ratification of the United States Constitution. It is not a course in "high theory." We will make reference to theorists including Locke, Montesquieu, and Rousseau, and describe the underlying beliefs and values of the Founders in terms of various theses (Small Republic, Balance of Orders, Natural Rights among others). However, our primary task is to understand the specific objectives that shaped the design of the Constitution and United States government.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Constitutional Debates - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as CNST_DEM 2455H).This is an undergraduate seminar on the political thought surrounding the drafting and ratification of the United States Constitution. It is not a course in "high theory." We will make reference to theorists including Locke, Montesquieu, and Rousseau, and describe the underlying beliefs and values of the Founders in terms of various theses (Small Republic, Balance of Orders, Natural Rights among others). However, our primary task is to understand the specific objectives that shaped the design of the Constitution and United States government.

It examines the meaning of "explanation" and "causal reasoning." and research strategies designed to make valid causal inferences.  The course overview experimental design, measurement, hypothesis formulation and testing, and the display of information, using substantive examples from two or more fields of political science for illustrative purposes. Graded on A-F basis only.

The course overview experimental design, measurement, hypothesis formulation and testing, and the display of information, using substantive examples from two or more fields of political science for illustrative purposes. "Chasing Ghost", The History of Irregular Warfare

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Study of national and state legislative systems and legislative policy making, with emphasis on Congress.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Evolution of the presidency; particular emphasis on constitutional and political roles played by chief executive in shaping public policy.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: The American Presidency - Writing Intensive
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Evolution of the presidency; particular emphasis on constitutional and political roles played by chief executive in shaping public policy.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Development, organization, functions, activities, internal politics of special interest groups such as business, labor, agricultural and public interest groups; lobbying and techniques for influencing public policy in the American political system.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Development, organization, functions, activities, internal politics of special interest groups such as business, labor, agricultural and public interest groups; lobbying and techniques for influencing public policy in the American political system.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Leading American constitutional principles as they have evolved through important decisions of the United States Supreme Court.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Survey of Supreme Court cases involving the Constitution's protections for life, liberty, and property and guarantee of equal protection of the law.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Constitutional Rights - Writing Intensive
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Survey of Supreme Court cases involving the Constitution's protections for life, liberty, and property and guarantee of equal protection of the law.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Role of Supreme Court in American system of government; particular attention given to reading biographies and writings of the Justices.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Civil liberties in the American constitutional context emphasizing freedom of expression (religion, speech, press, assembly), rights of accused and right to privacy.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Analyzes similarities and differences of state politics and the ways in which such politics are shaped by political and socioeconomic environments of the states.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Public Policy
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Introduction to the study of public policy in the United States. Analyzes public policy choices at the national, state and local level and the variety of forces which serve to shape policy decisions.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Public Policy - Writing Intensive
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Introduction to the study of public policy in the United States. Analyzes public policy choices at the national, state and local level and the variety of forces which serve to shape policy decisions.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Law, Policy, and Regulation
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Off in the quiet corners of the policy process, public servants distribute public benefits, write rules that have the force of law, adjudicate conflicts and selectively enforce the law. Frequently the government delegates these tasks to non-profit organizations. These public and quasi- public administrative organizations play, therefore, a critical role in the politics of who gets what, when and how - the essential question of public policy. Administrative organizations in the United States play this powerful role, however, within a constitutional democracy. This course focuses on policymaking through the administrative state and the relationship between the administrative state, democracy and the U.S. Constitution.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Law, Policy, and Regulation - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Off in the quiet corners of the policy process, public servants distribute public benefits, write rules that have the force of law, adjudicate conflicts and selectively enforce the law. Frequently the government delegates these tasks to non-profit organizations. These public and quasi- public administrative organizations play, therefore, a critical role in the politics of who gets what, when and how - the essential question of public policy. Administrative organizations in the United States play this powerful role, however, within a constitutional democracy. This course focuses on policymaking through the administrative state and the relationship between the administrative state, democracy and the U.S. Constitution.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: United States Health Politics and Policy
Politics of International Economic Relations - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Study of reciprocal interaction between global politics and economics. Includes politics of north/south relations, multinational non-state actors, arms transfers and dependency.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Policies and Institutions of the European Union
Korean Politics: North and South Korea
America's Wars in Asia/War and Peace in Asia
Democracy in America (and Elsewhere)
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as CNST_DEM 4830). This course focuses on the dynamics of democracy. We will explore various topics in the history, development, and practice of democracy through an examination of the writings of Alexis de Tocqueville, one of the most insightful and prescient observers of American political culture.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Developing Dynamics of Democracy
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as POL_SC 4840). This course examines developments in the theory and practice of democracy from the ancient Greeks to the present.  Beginning with the origins of democracy in the Hellenic city states, we consider the transformation of democratic concepts in the classical liberal period, review the development of democratic institutions in the United States and Europe, examine the emergence of supra-national democratic institutions such as the European Union, and assess the future of democratization in the 21st century.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Scots and the Making of America
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as CNST_DEM 4850). This class is on the influence of the Scottish Enlightenment on the founding of the United States.  The Scottish Enlightenment refers to uniquely Scottish advances in social, political, scientific and literary thought that transpired in the 18th and early 19th centuries.  This line of thought, especially in its social and political dimensions, was especially influential in shaping the founding of the United States.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Scots and the Making of America - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This class is on the influence of the Scottish Enlightenment on the founding of the United States.  The Scottish Enlightenment refers to uniquely Scottish advances in social, political, scientific and literary thought that transpired in the 18th and early 19th centuries.  This line of thought, especially in its social and political dimensions, was especially influential in shaping the founding of the United States.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Beltway History and Politics: American Constitutional Democracy in Theory and Practice
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: This course is limited to students participating in the Kinder Scholars Washington D.C. Internship program
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as HIST 4900, CNST_DEM 4900).  This course is an experiential overview of American political history for students on the Kinder Forum's Washington program, showing how American constitutional democracy was developed and implemented right here on the Potomac, as much as possible in the actual places where the events occurred. Emphasis will be placed on interplay between constitutional theory and actual political experience over time, and the tensions and institutional changes that emerged as Americans and their government coped with cataclysmic social changes, unparalleled economic development, and fearsome international challenges.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introductory Statistics for Political Science
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: MATH 1100 or MATH 1120 or equivalentCorequisites: POL_SC 4010
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Basic course in applied statistics and inference using extensive examples from voting behavior, congressional behavior, international relations and public policy. https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Military Innovation in Peace and War
Ph D Research in Political Science
Evolution of American Legislatures, 1619 to the Present
China and Political Science Research
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This is a graduate-level seminar on Chinese politics and foreign policy since 1949 covering the key historical events in Chinese political development and foreign policy. These events and developments will be examined in light of major theories in and methodological approaches adopted by the subfields of comparative politics and international relations, with the goal of exploring the strengths and weaknesses of alternative perspectives. At the end of the course, students should be familiar with the key debates and questions in the study of Chinese politics and foreign policy, and have a better sense of how to research questions on these topics. The course is also intended to encourage a dialogue between the study of China and the broader fields of comparative politics and international relations. Thus by the end of the course, students should have a sense not only for how the study of Chinese politics and foreign policy applies broader CP/IR theories to explain key patterns and events in China, but also gain insight into the question of what China as a case (or cases) can contribute back to major theories and debates in these fields.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Independent Readings for Ph.D. Comprehensive Examinations
Elementary Portuguese II
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Grade in the C range or better in PORT 1100 or its equivalent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This is the second course in the three-part elementary Portuguese-language sequence. The focus is on increasing vocabulary (including common idiomatic expressions) and reviewing basic verb tenses and syntax. The course also includes further study of key grammatical concepts such as irregular and reflexive verbs, progressive and past tenses, the imperative, and pronoun usage. Students gain practice with Brazilian Portuguese through written and oral homework assignments, as well as in-class structured conversation and discussion of texts, videos, music and other cultural materials related to Brazilian and additional Lusophone cultures. Audio and video recordings provide ample exposure to a variety of native speakers of Brazilian Portuguese, and to a lesser extent of European Portuguese.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Elementary Portuguese III
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: grade in the C range or better in PORT 1200 or equivalent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This is the third course in the three-part elementary Portuguese-language sequence. The focus is on a review of basic verb tenses and syntax, and an introduction to more advanced grammatical structures including present, past and future subjunctive usages, as well as conditional, future and perfect verb forms. Students continue to build on their existing vocabulary base and to gain practice with Brazilian Portuguese through written and oral homework assignments, as well as in-class structured conversation and discussion of texts, videos, music and other cultural materials related to Brazilian and additional Lusophone cultures. Audio and video recordings provide ample exposure to a variety of native speakers of Brazilian Portuguese, and to a lesser extent of European Portuguese. Graded on A-F basis only.

Instructor provides a thematic framework for films within the context of film theory, Latin American cinematic history and cultural studies. Course taught in English. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Designed for rapid acquisition of a reading knowledge of Portuguese. Cannot be taken to fulfill undergraduate language requirement.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Mind, Brain, and Behavior - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Honors eligibility required.  This course may be restricted to Undergraduate Psychology Majors during Early RegistrationRecommended: PSYCH 1000
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Introduction to the structures and processes of the mind and the nervous system, including the psychobiology of eating, sleeping, emotion, stress and learning. No credit if taken after PSYCH 4210.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Drugs and Behavior
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: This course may be restricted to Undergraduate Psychology Majors during Early RegistrationRecommended: PSYCH 1000
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Basic principles of drug action on the nervous system; the effects of important psychoactive drugs; drug use and society.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Drugs and Behavior - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Honors eligibility required.   This course may be restricted to Undergraduate Psychology Majors during Early RegistrationRecommended: PSYCH 1000
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Basic principles of drug action on the nervous system; the effects of important psychoactive drugs; drug use and society.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Social Psychology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: This course may be restricted to Undergraduate Psychology Majors during Early RegistrationRecommended: PSYCH 1000
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: An introduction to how people's thoughts, feelings and behaviors are influenced by the actual or imagined thoughts, feelings and behaviors of others.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Social Psychology - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Honors eligibility required. This course may be restricted to Undergraduate Psychology Majors during Early RegistrationRecommended: PSYCH 1000
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: An introduction to how people's thoughts, feelings and behaviors are influenced by the actual or imagined thoughts, feelings and behaviors of others.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: The Art and Science of Living
Introduction to Personality
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: This course may be restricted to undergraduate psychology majors during Early RegistrationRecommended: PSYCH 1000
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Personality is the scientific study of individual differences (e.g., traits, motives, abilities). This course reviews historical theoretical perspectives as well as current research. Students will have an opportunity to learn about on their own motives and traits.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Developmental Psychology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: This course may be restricted to Undergraduate Psychology Majors during Early RegistrationRecommended: PSYCH 1000
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Origins and development of child behavior, emphasizing basic physical, cognitive, affective and social processes, and theory and research rather than application or guidance.  Cannot receive credit for more than one of the following: PSYCH 2410, H_D_FS 2420 or H_D_FS 3420 or ESC_PS 2500.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Developmental Psychology - Honors
