Students analyze the potential and limitations/ effects of blogs and the web in specific contemporary cultural contexts and as part of the broader historical evolution of the web.  The course is taught in English.  The goal of this course is two-fold; students learn the particulars of web blogging, explore various features of the contemporary social network landscape while focusing on the concept of culture, in particular the cultures of Europe and the US.  Questions asked are: what is culture? What is common or popular right now in other cultures? And how do new social networks amplify or alter certain features or culture across national and international contests?

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Totalitarianism and Culture - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Honors eligibility requiredRecommended: Junior standing or above; students taking this course for WI should have taken a 2000- or 3000-level WI course before beginning this class
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as GERMAN 4840H; cross-leveled with GERMAN 7840, RUSS 7840). In this course, we will explore the politics and poetics of totalitarian culture by examining the paintings, music, sculptures, buildings, and films produced under the rule of these regimes. In the process, we will learn how Nazi and Soviet culture producers made carefully calibrated appeals to their respective mass audiences, drawing upon the German and Russian cultural traditions - and on scientific rhetorics of cultural history and racial destiny - in crafting their utopian visions of worlds transformed, wrongs righted, and societies perfected.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Totalitarianism and Culture - Honors/Writing Intensive
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Honors eligibility requiredRecommended: Junior standing or above; students taking this course for WI should have taken a 2000- or 3000-level WI course before beginning this class
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as GERMAN 4840HW; cross-leveled with GERMAN 7840, RUSS 7840). In this course, we will explore the politics and poetics of totalitarian culture by examining the paintings, music, sculptures, buildings, and films produced under the rule of these regimes. In the process, we will learn how Nazi and Soviet culture producers made carefully calibrated appeals to their respective mass audiences, drawing upon the German and Russian cultural traditions - and on scientific rhetorics of cultural history and racial destiny - in crafting their utopian visions of worlds transformed, wrongs righted, and societies perfected.

Exploration in Social and Economic Justice
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as PEA_ST 2000). This course explores issues of fairness and equality in economic, political and social systems, and applies social justice principles to major social problems. Course may be repeated two times for credit. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as PEA_ST 2000). This course explores issues of fairness and equality in economic, political and social systems, and applies social justice principles to major social problems. Course may be repeated two times for credit. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Human Behavior in the Social Environment

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Human Behavior in the Social Environment - Writing Intensive
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: The first of two required courses providing an introduction to selected theories, multidisciplinary knowledge, and perspectives into human development and behavior. Graded on A-F basis only.

Understanding Personality in a Social Context
Social Statistics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Descriptive, analytic techniques applied to qualitative and quantitative social data. Math Reasoning Proficiency Course.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Addiction Treatment and Prevention
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with SOC_WK 7330). Provides knowledge generic to social work and other disciplines involved in substance abuse treatment. Integrated approach to problems of substance abuse and development of self-awareness are emphasized. Didactic and experiential methods employed.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Working with Minority Youth
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as BL_STU 4360). Develops awareness and understanding of social/psychological and cognitive realities influencing the behavior of minority youth. Content draws upon theories, research and practice skills relevant to understanding and counseling minority youth.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Delinquency, Corrections and Social Treatment
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with SOC_WK 7370). Focuses on problems and causative factors in developing and maintaining delinquent and criminal behavior and attitudes: addressing critical and comparative understanding of social change strategies employed in this field.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Helping Strategies With Children and Adolescents
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with SOC_WK 7390). Theory and practice of work with children and adolescents. Focus on youth in transition, protective services and permanency planning, and special needs populations.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Death, Grief and Loss
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with SOC_WK 7395). This course is designed to provide an awareness of the impact of grief and loss whether as a result of a death or major life alteration.  The perspective that grief exists in many contexts beyond death will be a focal point of the course.  Theory associated with the process of dying, grief and grief resolution will be examined.  Additionally, students will explore influencing factors such as life span development, religion, culture and personal responses to loss.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Domestic Violence
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as WGST 4400; cross-leveled with SOC_WK 7400, WGST 7400). Covers history of the domestic violence movement, intimate partner violence theories and data, legislative and organizational policy issues, and intervention models for practice with individuals who have experienced domestic violence including co-occurring issues such as trauma.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Social Welfare and the Law
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with SOC_WK 7410). This course explores the intersection of human services, law, and policy. It explores how law shapes services directed at children, families, women, and racial and sexual minorities. Students learn to work with legal professionals, prepare for proceedings, and avoid malpractice.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Professional Perspectives on Child Welfare Services in the 21st Century
Direct Practice with Older Adults
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with SOC_WK 7480). This course provides foundational knowledge and skills in working with older adults and their families. Emphasis is placed on assessment strategies and intervention techniques with these populations. The interrelationship between the older adult, the family, organizations, and society is explored, as these factors affect all levels of practice. Students gain practical skill that can be applied to multidisciplinary practice settings, such as the health and social sciences.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Social Justice and Social Policy
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: junior standing and departmental consent required
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Based on the concepts of human need and social justice, a historical and analytical approach to social welfare policies and programs. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Social Justice and Social Policy II
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Advanced course in the analysis of policies and programs relevant to social work and social welfare.  Prepares students to understand and conduct policy analysis of public, voluntary, and proprietary human service organizations.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Variations in Human Behavior
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: junior standing and departmental consent required
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Basic concepts and principles regarding psychological/social dynamics of deviance; implications for social welfare policy and social interventions.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to Social Work Practice
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Social Work Professional Standing and departmental consent required
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Introductory, generalist practice theory course promoting student's understanding of professional social work practice as holistic, identifiable, unique configuration of knowledge, values and skills. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to Community and Organizational Processes
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Social Work professional standing and departmental consent required
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Introduction to contextual framework of social work practice with particular emphasis on community and organization as social systems. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Interaction Skills Workshop
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Social Work Professional standing and departmental consent required
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Generalist practice at individual, group and community levels. Group communication and social influence theories address generic and unique aspects of interaction across systems. Uses laboratory instruction. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Theory and Practice of Social Group Work
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Focuses on small group dynamics and models of group work practice suitable in all social work fields. Emphasizes practice theory and skills. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Strategies of Direct Practice
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: SOC_WK 4730 and SOC_WK 4750; third semester professional program standing; departmental consent requiredCorequisites: SOC_WK 4971 and SOC_WK 4970
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Examines social structures, processes, underlying assumptions/concepts of social change, client constellation, organizational arrangements, role relationships by which social workers define professional intervention.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Strategies of Direct Practice - Writing Intensive
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: SOC_WK 4730 and SOC_WK 4750; third semester professional program standing; departmental consent requiredCorequisites: SOC_WK 4971 and SOC_WK 4970
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Examines social structures, processes, underlying assumptions/concepts of social change, client constellation, organizational arrangements, role relationships by which social workers define professional intervention.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Advanced Study for Social Work Honors
Research for Social Work Practice
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Social Work Professional standing or consent required
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course introduces social work research and its relevance to practice, emphasizing the School of Social Work's social justice mission. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Research for Social Work Practice - Writing Intensive
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Social Work Professional standing or consent required
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course introduces social work research and its relevance to practice, emphasizing the School of Social Work's social justice mission. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Research Methods for Social Work
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Social Work Professional standing or consent required
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Survey of research methods germane to the development of the knowledge base of social work practice. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Research Methods for Social Work - Writing Intensive
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Social Work Professional standing or consent required
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Survey of research methods germane to the development of the knowledge base of social work practice. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Senior Professional Seminar
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Integrative professional practice seminar for BSW students, focusing on the principles of generic social work and its application to direct practice in diverse fields, career planning and responsibilities. Enrollment is limited to students who have completed SOC_WK 2220, SOC_WK 4710, SOC_WK 4730, SOC_WK 4740, SOC_WK 4750, SOC_WK 4760, and SOC_WK 4720; and currently enrolled in SOC_WK 4770 and SOC_WK 4971.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Senior Professional Seminar - Writing Intensive
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Integrative professional practice seminar for BSW students, focusing on the principles of generic social work and its application to direct practice in diverse fields, career planning and responsibilities. Enrollment is limited to students who have completed SOC_WK 2220, SOC_WK 4710, SOC_WK 4730, SOC_WK 4740, SOC_WK 4750, SOC_WK 4760, and SOC_WK 4720; and currently enrolled in SOC_WK 4770 and SOC_WK 4971.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Undergraduate Field Practicum
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: senior standing; SOC_WK 2220, SOC_WK 4710, SOC_WK 4730, SOC_WK 4740, SOC_WK 4750, SOC_WK 4760, and SOC_WK 4720; departmental consent requiredCorequisites: SOC_WK 4770 and SOC_WK 4970
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Supervised social work practice in a school-approved agency focusing on development of direct practice skills. Fall semester, three days per week. Graded on S/U basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Advanced Social Work Practice in Integrated Healthcare
Substance Use Disorders Assessment and Intervention
Helping Strategies With Children and Adolescents
Professional Perspectives on Child Welfare Services in the 21st Century
Organizational Issues in Social Work Practices in Child Welfare
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Intensive seminar in meso-level practice in the field of child welfare. Examines communication theory, team building, and interorganizational dynamics as they affect professional practice in child welfare.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Family Treatment
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Comparative study of theories and methods required for work with problems of family functioning. Both conjoint and subsystem approaches to family treatment are examined. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Social Policy and Service Delivery in Social Work
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: restricted to graduate Social Work majors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Covers historic and contemporary issues in social welfare policy. Focuses on relationships among social problems, public policies, private actions, poverty, racism, sexism and social work practice/values. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Foundations of Human Behavior
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: restricted to graduate Social Work majors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Substantive sources from behavioral sciences used in social work toward understanding the biosocial processes and constraints of human development. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Social Work Skills
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: graduate standing in social work; Foundation level course
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Introduces theory and application of strengths-based generalist practice. Develops knowledge, values, and techniques of professional social work practice at micro, mezzo, and macro levels, emphasizing assessment and interaction skills.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Large Group Theory
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Examination of social environment in which social work is practiced with particular emphasis on development of analytic framework for understanding formal organizations and communities. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Social Justice Seminar
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: restricted to graduate Social Work majorsCorequisites: SOC_WK 7971
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Provides integrative learning experience in social work practice in foundation level social work practice focusing on social and economic justice experiences in field practicum. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Strategies of Clinical Social Work Intervention
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: graduate standing in social work; departmental consent required
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Strategies of social treatment with individuals and small groups applicable to practice in public and private social agency settings. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Fundamentals of Social Work Administration
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: restricted to graduate Social Work majors. A grade of B or higher in SOC_WK 7740
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Basic managerial skills which social workers need for supervision, planning, staff development and administrative positions in social agencies; focus on individual management functions and skills associated with them. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: DSM and Psychopathology: A Social Work Perspective
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Graduate standing in Social Work. A grade of B or higher in SOC_WK 7720
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Examines psychopathology of human behavior within social work context, prevailing diagnostic models (Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders), and historically oppressive categorizations. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Advanced Foundations of Human Behavior for Administrators
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: graduate Social Work majors. A grade of B or higher in SOC_WK 7720
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Examination of relevant theoretical and behavioral foundations in order that students can acquire the knowledge to function as a social work administrator. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Research Methods in Social Work
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Examines research methodology and design as applied to the study of social work techniques and problems. Emphasizes differential uses of scientific observation and techniques for developing knowledge and improving practice. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Child Abuse and Neglect Assessment and Intervention
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: SOC_WK 7770; instructor's consent for non MSW students
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: In-depth exploration of identification of and interventions with abused/neglected children and their families. Examines roles for social work with both victims and perpetrators. Examines how environmental factors affect successful intervention.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Resiliency and Solution-Focused Practice
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: SOC_WK 7770; graduate level Social Work Majors only. Graded on A/F basis only
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Focuses on brief therapy approaches to dealing with clinical problems in a time-efficient, clinically effective method. Various approaches to solution-oriented work based in resiliency theory are presented.  Stresses client empowerment across the lifespan.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Trauma Informed Practice and Intervention
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: SOC_WK 7770; graduate level Social Work majors only
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This clinical practice course focuses on evidence-based techniques for intervening with survivors of trauma. Content includes developmental theories on trauma and attachment, holistic and culturally aware assessment of post-traumatic stress disorder, the impact of trauma on the development of 'self', and evidence-based models for micro clinical practice. Resiliency, generational trauma, and trauma-informed agency are additional topics used to facilitate learning. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Cognitive Behavioral Practice
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: SOC_WK 7770.  Restricted to graduate Social Work majors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Focuses on the theory, concepts, and techniques of cognitive behavioral therapies, with a particular emphasis on clinical intervention methods that may be used by the social worker to address specific client needs. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to Dialectical Behavioral Therapy Practice
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Graduate level Social Work majors only
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course is an introduction to the theory, concepts and practice of Dialectical Behavioral Therapy, an evidenced-based practice and form of cognitive-behavioral treatment. There will be an emphasis on application methods across settings that a social worker may use to work with clients with pervasive emotion dysregulation as well as other difficult to treat clients where other forms of treatment have not been effective. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Policy and Advocacy for Empowered Aging
Management of a Social Agency
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: restricted to Graduate Social Work majors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Basic resource management and control techniques common to social agencies with emphasis on personnel management, information and data management, and fiscal management. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Evaluative Research in Clinical Social Work Practice
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: SOC_WK 7952. Restricted to graduate Social Work majors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Develop ability to systematically evaluate effectiveness of interventive strategies designed to produce positive change in clients' environment and/or cognitive, affective and behavioral functioning.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Evaluative Research in Social Work
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: SOC_WK 7952.  Restricted to graduate Social Work majors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Develop ability to design and implement appropriate evaluative research methods and strategies employed in social and human service delivery. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Professional Practice Seminar I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: restricted to graduate Social Work majorsCorequisites: SOC_WK 8971
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Provides integrative learning experience in social work practice in an area of beginning specialization in autonomous social work practice. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Knowledge Building I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Advanced systemic review of theories requisite for study and implementation of practice and policy centered research in social welfare and development; emphasis placed on critical analysis of theories needed for research and study of integrated social development.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Statistical Concepts in the Social and Behavioral Sciences
Research Methodology and Design Seminar
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Review of historical development of social welfare and social work research with emphasis on critical analysis of seminal studies; examination of "state-of-the-art" social welfare and development initiatives, designs and methodology.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Advanced Quantitative and Qualitative Methods in Social Research
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: The course provides an in-depth understanding of the use of both quantitative and qualitative methods. The curriculum emphasizes an integration of quantitative and qualitative approaches, methods, and data analysis. Computer application sessions are included. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Macro Social Theory
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (Same as NURSE 9400). Building on the foundation laid in SOC_WK 9100, in depth examination of human development and social environment theories appropriate to scientific examination of social welfare practice with formal organizations, interorganizational combinations, communities and larger political entities.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Pedagogical Methods in Social Work and Applied Professional Programs
Dissertation Seminar
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course will assist doctoral students in planning and writing the dissertation.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Doctoral Dissertation Research in Social Work
Introduction to Sociology Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Nature of organization and activities of human groupings-family, community, crowd, social class, etc.; structure, function of institutions; social influences shaping personality, behavior, social change. No credit for both SOCIOL 1000 and RU_SOC 1000.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: The Female Experience: Body, Identity, Culture
Amish Communities - Honors/Writing Intensive
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Honors Eligibility requiredRecommended: RU_SOC 1000, SOCIOL 1000 or ANTHRO 1000
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as PEA_ST 2150). This course focuses on the guiding values of the Amish such as family and community and how these values are lived out through rules, rituals, and symbols. We explore how and why they resist certain aspects and embrace other aspects of modern American life and how these decisions vary between Amish communities. Students will develop critical thinking about human culture and their own values and assessments of life and well-being.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Critical Dialogues: Nonviolence in Peace/Democracy Movements
Critical Dialogues: Nonviolence in Peace/Democracy Movements - Writing Intensive
Social Inequalities - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as BL_STU 2200). Survey of inequalities based upon criteria such as race, ethnicity, sex, age, religion and social class in contemporary societies. Focus on dynamics by which privilege and inequalities are structured.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Race, Democracy, and Violence in Cuba and Haiti
Race, Democracy, and Violence in Cuba and Haiti - Writing Intensive
Nuclear Weapons: Environmental, Health and Social Effects
Nuclear Weapons: Environmental, Health and Social Effects - Writing Intensive
Large Corporations, Economic Crisis, Social Responsibility
Technological Futures, National Security, and Civil Liberties
Technological Futures, National Security, and Civil Liberties - Writing Intensive
Recent Theories in Sociology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Sociology majors only. Non-sociology majors may petition the instructor to add the course
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as RU_SOC 3100). Introduction to major theoretical positions and issues in contemporary American sociology. Logical and intellectual structure of major theoretical schools: functionalism, conflict, exchange, symbolic interaction, phenomenological-ethnomethodological theories.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Queer Theories/Identities
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as WGST 3300). Analysis of gay, lesbian, bisexual, transgender (GLBT) and queer identities in culture and society with an emphasis on the contributions of queer theory and other GLBT standpoint theories to sociology and the study of society.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Queer Theories/Identities - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: SOCIOL 2200 or instructor's consent; Honors eligibility required
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as WGST 3300). Analysis of gay, lesbian, bisexual, transgender (GLBT) and queer identities in culture and society with an emphasis on the contributions of queer theory and other GLBT standpoint theories to sociology and the study of society.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Queer Theories/Identities - Writing Intensive
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as WGST 3300). Analysis of gay, lesbian, bisexual, transgender (GLBT) and queer identities in culture and society with an emphasis on the contributions of queer theory and other GLBT standpoint theories to sociology and the study of society.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Fake News and Media Politics - Writing Intensive
Technology and Society - Honors/Writing Intensive
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: In the last few decades science and technology have permeated our lives as never before.  This has led to wide ranging intellectual debates and social movements in and around the issue of relationship between science, technology, and society.  This course, which is organized on a lecture-seminar format, will critically investigate different aspects of the relationship between science, technology, and society.   Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: The Sociology of Work
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Analysis of occupational, professional aspects of American society. Division of labor; occupational mobility; work and the self; colleagueship and informal organizations of work.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Work in the 21st Century - Writing Intensive
Settler Colonialism and Native American/Indigenous Communities
Service Learning in Sociology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: The service learning course combines an independent study with a faculty member with practical experience in a related non-profit or other worksite.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Social Research
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Introduction to principles of methodology; theory and research; survey of basic research designs and perspectives; preparation for understanding and conducting social research.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Social Research I - Writing Intensive
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Introduction to principles of methodology; theory and research; survey of basic research designs and perspectives; preparation for understanding and conducting social research.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Aging and the Life Course
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Junior standing or aboveRecommended: At least three credits in Sociology prior to enrollment is preferred
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Course will take a life course perspective on the sociological aspects of aging in contemporary American society. Begins with birth, then childhood, adolescence, emergent adulthood, middle life, old age, and death. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Race and Ethnic Relations
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: The experience of racial and ethnic minorities; inequality, assimilation, ethnic and racial conflict, accommodation.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Social Demography
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: SOCIOL 1000 or RU_SOC 1000 and junior standing
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with SOCIOL 7315).  General demographic theories; age, sex, and ethnic composition of population; fertility, mortality and migration as components of population change; social, economic and political implications of demographic trends.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Culture, Identity and Interaction
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: SOCIOL 3310 graduate standing or instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Examines the interplay between culture, identity, and interaction as these intersect with issues of social inequality, social control, social change, and the everyday production of subjectivities.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Social Change and Development
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: RU_SOC 1000 or SOCIOL 1000 and junior standing
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with SOCIOL 7335). Nature of social change and development. Emphasizes sociological theories of social change and development contrasting them with approaches from the disciplines.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Sociology of Education
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as ED_LPA 4458; cross-leveled with  ED_LPA 7458 and SOCIOL 7410). Contexts, structures and processes of schooling; effects on class, race, ethnicity and gender; social change, educational policy, and organizational dynamics; higher education and the economy.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Research Practicum in Health, Place, and Community
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: SOCIOL 2950, SOCIOL 3950, or equivalent. Junior or senior standing
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with SOCIOL 7450). This course is a research practicum with a substantive focus on health, place, and community. The course combines lecture and field work outside the classroom. Students take part in real-world research projects with local organizations, government agencies, and/or businesses. Projects are based on the needs of participating organizations and will be conducted using a variety of research methodologies. Students will engage in data analysis, write research reports for community partners, and present findings as applicable. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Sociology of Social Policy
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with SOCIOL 7500). Sociological theories and methodologies focused on social policy; policy as process; contextual and critical policy analyses; assessing policy effects and consequences.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Social Movements and Conflicts
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: SOCIOL 3520, SOCIOL 3700, or SOCIOL 3320 or graduate standing
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Survey of approaches and research on social movements and social change. Historical and contemporary social movements in the U.S.; collective protest and violence; political revolutions. MA core course.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Political Sociology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as PEA_ST 4520). Social bases of power and politics, economic and political elites, the political economy of the advanced societies, sources of political conflict and change.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Gender and Human Rights in Cross Cultural Perspective
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: WGST 1120 or SOCIOL 2200; senior standing required
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as WGST 4550 and PEA_ST 4550; cross-leveled with WGST 7550, SOCIOL 7550, PEA_ST 7550).  This course focuses on the global discourse on human rights and gender, emphasizing cross-cultural theories.  Course includes the meaning of rights, Western and non-western perspectives, feminist contributions, important substantive debates, violations, policymaking and activism.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Society and Social Control
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with SOCIOL 7610). The concept of social control is analyzed from both micro and macro theoretical perspectives. Focus is on patterns of social domination.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Research in Sociology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Students gain research experience by assisting a faculty member with a research project in sociology. Enrollment is limited to Sociology majors with Junior standing. Repeatable upon consent of the department.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Senior Seminar
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: SOCIOL 3950 and SOCIOL 3100 and senior sociology major
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Integrates perspectives, methods, substantive foci of undergraduate courses. Analysis of sociology as a discipline and profession. Discussion of opportunities for graduate study, employment.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Senior Seminar - Writing Intensive
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: SOCIOL 3950 and SOCIOL 3100 and senior sociology major
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Integrates perspectives, methods, substantive foci of undergraduate courses. Analysis of sociology as a discipline and profession. Discussion of opportunities for graduate study, employment.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Honors in Sociology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: for honors candidates; SOCIOL 3950 and SOCIOL 3100
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Intensive work in a selected field within sociology, including readings and research. Repeatable up to 6 hours with departmental consent.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Social Statistics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with SOCIOL 4120). Descriptive statistics and bivariate quantitative analysis techniques commonly used by social scientists. Includes coverage of parametric and non-parametric methods. Introduction to computer analysis.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Social Demography
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with SOCIOL 4315).  General demographic theories; age, sex, and ethnic composition of population; fertility, mortality and migration as components of population change; social, economic and political implications of demographic trends.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Culture, Identity and Interaction
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Examines the interplay between culture, identity, and interaction as these intersect with issues of social inequality, social control, social change, and the everyday production of subjectives.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Social Change and Development
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with SOCIOL 4355). Nature of social change and development. Emphasizes sociological theories of social change and development contrasting them with approaches from the disciplines.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Research Practicum in Health, Place, and Community
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with SOCIOL 4450). This course is a research practicum with a substantive focus on health, place, and community. The course combines lecture and field work outside the classroom. Students take part in real-world research projects with local organizations, government agencies, and/or businesses. Projects are based on the needs of participating organizations and will be conducted using a variety of research methodologies. Students will engage in data analysis, write research reports for community partners, and present findings as applicable. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Gender and Human Rights in Cross Cultural Perspective
Society and Social Control
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with SOCIOL 4610). The concept of social control is analyzed from both micro and macro theoretical perspectives. Focus is on patterns of social domination.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Special Readings in Sociology for the Graduate Level
Advanced Social Statistics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Introduction to multivariate analysis for social scientists. Emphasis on non-experimental applications of analysis of variance and correlation-regression. Computer applications emphasized.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Seminar in Population Health
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Graduate Seminar on the social distribution of morbidity and mortality.  Covers major theoretical perspectives and the state of empirical evidence regarding several individuals and contextual explanations of health disparities.   Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Seminar on Interview Theory and Technique
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: The seminar has three goals: First is the consideration of literature dealing with recent theoretical formulations of the interview. This will provide a basis, second, for critically examining a number of popular interview guidebooks. The third goal is to offer the opportunity to put theory and technique into practice by analyzing selected interview material.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Media and Power in Comparative Perspective Seminar
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: undergraduate seniors may enroll with instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course traces the historical development of U.S. and selected international media systems.  We analyze and debate the relationship of differing media systems to political power, popular culture, and the facilitation or inhibition of democratic practices.  Students do comparative analyses of international media institutions and related analyzes of media content.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Seminar on Narrative and Identity
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: graduate standing required; instructor's consent required

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Graduate Seminar in Medicine, Technology, and Globalization
Seminar in Criminology and Deviant Behavior
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Survey of empirical research and sociological theory in criminology and deviant behavior. May be repeated once with instructor's consent.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Seminar in Sociological Theory I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Traces development of sociological theory from the "generation of 1890" through the 1940s, including the work of Durkheim, Weber, Parsons and others.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Seminar in Qualitative Methods in Sociology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Examination of various qualitative methods of research, including problem-formulation, access and interpretation of data, theory-generation, and preparation of research reports.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Ethnographic Fieldwork
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: History of sociological ethnography, the analysis of key ethnographic texts, forms of ethnographic fieldwork, and recent debates related to representational practices.  Applications to participant observation, field interviewing, and strategies of discourse analysis in various social settings.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Seminar in Sociological Theory II
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Theoretical developments in sociology in Europe and United States since 1950. Recent formulations, controversies.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Culture, Difference, and Inequality
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: restricted to Sociology graduate students or instructor permission
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course is an examination of exemplary, interdisciplinary texts employing a variety of cultural approaches to understanding difference and inequality.  In this seminar, we will think about what is gained from various cultural approaches to difference and inequality, now such approaches can be achieved methodologically, and how students can apply such approaches to their own research.  The main focus of the course is on cultural studies and poststructural feminist studies, but readings will also be included from intersectionality studies, affect studies, critical race studies and cultural sociology.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Topical Seminar in Historical Sociology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Methodological approaches to sociological explanation of historical phenomena; related sociological theories of historical development, including Weberian, Marxist and other perspectives applied to a topical historical problem.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Graduate Seminar in Body and Society
Independent Readings in Preparation f/Comprehensive Examinations
Soils and the Environment
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: SOIL 2100 and ENGLSH 1000Recommended: 3 hours of chemistry
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as ENV_SC 3290). Addresses the role of soils and soil properties on environmental pollution and management. Emphasis will be placed on carbon, nitrogen, phosphorus, and sulfur transformations and transport in natural and disturbed ecosystems and soil management practices and technology to prevent or remediate environmental pollution.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Soils and the Environment - Writing Intensive
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: SOIL 2100 and ENGLSH 1000Recommended: 3 hours of chemistry
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as ENV_SC 3290W). Addresses the role of soils and soil properties on environmental pollution and management. Emphasis will be placed on carbon, nitrogen, phosphorus, and sulfur transformations and transport in natural and disturbed ecosystems and soil management practices and technology to prevent or remediate environmental pollution.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Environmental Soil Physics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as ENV_SC 4305; cross-leveled with ENV_SC 7305, SOIL 7305). Study of soil physical properties and processes important in solving environmental problems. Topics include soil solids, water content and energy, and transport of water, solutes, gas and heat.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Soil Conservation
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with SOIL 7308).  Conservation of soil with respect to topsoil, soil productivity, and fertility.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Environmental Soil Microbiology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as ENV_SC 4312; cross-leveled with SOIL 7312, ENV_SC 7312). Microbiology/ecology of life in the soil ecosystem. Emphasis is placed on the role of microbes in nutrient cycling, microbial pesticide/xenobiotic transformation bioremediation, etc.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Soil Fertility and Plant Nutrition
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as PLNT_SCI 4313; cross-leveled with SOIL 7313, PLNT_SCI 4313). Explanation of principles of delivery of plant nutrients to plants, discussion of the role of each essential nutrient in crop plants and introduction to the management of soil amendments.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Environmental Soil Chemistry
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: SOIL 2100 or GEOL 2400, CHEM 1320 and CHEM 1330; junior standing or  instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as ENV_SC 4318 and GEOL 4318; cross-leveled with ENV_SC 7318, GEOL 4318, SOIL 7318). Study of chemical constituents and processes occurring in soils.  Topics include soil minerals, and weathering processes, organic matter, solution chemistry, oxidation-reduction reactions and adsorption processes.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Precision Agriculture Science and Technology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as AG_S_TCH 4360, PLNT_SCI 4360; cross-leveled with SOIL 7360, AG_S_TCH 7360, PLNT_SCI 7360). Precision agriculture is an information-based approach to farming whereby variability is managed to optimize crop production and reduce environmental pollution. This course provides an overview of precision agriculture technologies (like GIS, GPS, remote sensing), mapping methods, and case studies illustrating decisions and management.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Experiential Learning in Industry Internship in Soil Science
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Learning experience combining observation, application, and reflection in a discipline-based industry internship. Course appears on transcript for zero credit and does not count toward full-time enrollment. No tuition or fees are charged. Graded on S/U basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Environmental Soil Physics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as ENV_SC 7305; cross-leveled with SOIL 4305, ENV_SC 4305). Study of soil physical properties and processes important in solving environmental problems. Topics include soil solids, water content and energy, and transport of water, solutes, gas and heat.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Soil Conservation
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with SOIL 4308).  Conservation of soil with respect to topsoil, soil productivity, and fertility.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Environmental Soil Microbiology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: general microbiology, SOIL 2100, or instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as ENV_SC 7312; SOIL 4312, ENV_SC 4312). Microbiology/ecology of life in the soil ecosystem. Emphasis is placed on the role of microbes in nutrient cycling, microbial pesticide/xenobiotic transformations bioremediation, etc.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Soil Fertility and Plant Nutrition
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as PLNT_SCI 7313; cross_leveled with SOIL 4313, PLNT_SCI 4313). Explanation of principles of delivery of plant nutrients to plants, discussion of the role of each essential nutrient in crop plants and introduction to the management of soil amendments.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Soil Fertility and Plant Nutrition Laboratory
Environmental Soil Chemistry
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: SOIL 2100 or GEOL 2400,  CHEM 1320 and CHEM 1330; junior standing or instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as GEOL 7318 and ENV_SC 7318; cross_leveled with ENV_SC 4318. GEOL 4318, SOIL 4318). Study of chemical constituents and processes occurring in soils.  Topics include soil minerals, and weathering processes, organic matter, solution chemistry, oxidation-reduction reactions and adsorption processes.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Genesis of Soil Landscape
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: introductory soil science or introductory geology or permission of instructor
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with SOIL 4320). The co-evolution of soil landscapes. The role of water in the accumulation of parent materials and development of soil horizons. Factors and processes of soil genesis. Distribution of soil in their natural settings.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Precision Agriculture Science and Technology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as AG_S_TCH 7360 and PLNT_SCI 7360; cross-leveled with SOIL 4360, AG_S_TCH 4360, PLNT_SCI 7360). Precision agriculture is an information-based approach to farming whereby variability is managed to optimize crop production and reduce environmental pollution. This course provides an overview of precision agriculture technologies (like GIS, GPS, remote sensing), mapping methods, and case studies illustrating decisions and management.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Solute Transport in the Vadose Zone
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as ENV_SC 8400). Transport of water and solutes in geomedia with emphasis on development of the equations of flow.  Evaluation of analytical and numeral solutions to equations describing transport phenomena.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Chemistry of the Vadose Zone
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: SOIL 7318 or GEOL 7300 or instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as ENV_SC 8500). Chemical reactions occurring in geomedia with emphasis on understanding molecular scale processes occurring at the solid-water interface, aqueous geochemistry, and soil organic matter.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Pedology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: SOIL 7320, one statistics course beyond ANOVA
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Three one-hour lectures. Detailed study of processes of soil horizonization and current topics in soil genesis including quantitative assessment of spatial and temporal variability and application of GIS in landuse planning.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Philosophy: East and West
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as PHIL 2100). Compares the interpretation and role of philosophical concepts such as experience, reason permanence, change, immortality, soul, God, etc., in Indian, Chinese and European traditions.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Buddhism of South and Southeast Asia
Yoga and Meditation in the Modern World
Indian Cinema
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as ANTHRO 3490, FILMS_VS 3490, ARH_VS 3790). Overview of  key genres and themes of Indian film, including Bollywood, art cinema/parallel cinema, Indian regional cinemas, and diaspora cinema. The course combines film studies, anthropological, historical, and visual culture analyses to provide a holistic view of Indian culture and society through cinema.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Culture and Society in South Asia
Asian Philosophy
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: sophomore standing and one course in Philosophy; or instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as PHIL 4800). This course traces the origins of Indian and Chinese philosophical world views. Included are the major ideas in Hindu, Jaina, and Buddhist thought in India, and Taoism and Confucianism in China. Emphasis is placed on the diverse, assimilative, and pragmatic nature of Indian thought and its impact on contemporary Asian philosophy.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Elementary Spanish I - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This designated honors section of Elementary Spanish will challenge students to explore more deeply the currently existing thematic units of the SPAN 1100 curriculum.  Students will participate in group discussions, creative projects, independent study and use of authentic written and aural material from primary sources.  Honors Spanish 1100 will integrate cultural events outside the classroom such as movies, guest lectures, art exhibits, seminars or concerts as available.  Once a semester, Honors Spanish 1100 will meets with Honors SPAN 1200H and SPAN 2100H as a cohort group for further intellectual exchange and enrichment.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Elementary Spanish II - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course, designed for students who have taken SPAN 1100 or an equivalent course and enrolled in the Honors College, offers an introduction to the Spanish language and the many cultures in encompasses.  Your course work will allow you to develop all four language skills: reading, speaking, listening and writing along with the cultural background necessary to help you to communicate effectively in Spanish.  With the honors designation section, the course will allow students to access greater challenges in the existing thematic units in the curriculum through group discussion, creative projects and authentic situations.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Elementary Spanish III - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: A multi-skill course following SPAN 1200, centering on cultural/literary readings, and including a grammar review, practice in the spoken language, as well as some practice in written expression.  The course seeks to improve student's fluency in Spanish and to expose them to the many cultures it encompasses.  This course will integrate cultural events outside the classroom as well such as movies, guest lectures, art exhibits, seminars or concerts as available.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Intermediate Spanish Composition and Conversation
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course is designed specifically to strengthen overall writing skills and to develop further conversational ability with equal emphasis on both of these aspects. Classwork will involve written compositions and oral presentations.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Intermediate Spanish Composition and Conversation - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: SPAN 2100 or equivalent from any other institution.  Honors eligibility required
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This class is fundamentally different from other 2160 classes in that it focuses on the application and refinement of grammatical concepts through the introduction of new vocabulary and cultural topics. In this course it is assumed that students have mastered the vocabulary and grammatical concepts taught in the elementary levels. Throughout the semester students enrolling in Spanish 2160 for Honors credit will write a series of essays on current and past events, as well as literary analysis utilizing the grammar and material learned in learned in class. The goal is to strengthen their communicative and written skills while allowing them to be creative and engage in research.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Literature of Spanish Civil War
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as PEA_ST 2320). Study of the Spanish Civil War: History, Politics, Literature.  May not be included in the area of concentration in Spanish.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Hispanic Minority Literature
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: This course studies the literature of Hispanic minorities in the United States: Chicanos (Mexican American), Mainland Puerto Ricans, and Cuban exile writers. It explores the question of minority versus majority literatures and the creation of a Hispanic minority discourse. No knowledge of Spanish required.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Advanced Spanish Conversation
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Course puts into practice the linguistic skills learned at intermediate levels.  It develops and increases the capacity for comprehension and oral expression in the language.  Focus is on practice of certain syntactic structures and idiomatic expressions, and on acquisition of new vocabulary.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Advanced Spanish Conversation - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: SPAN 2160 or equivalent. Honors Eligibility required
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Course puts into practice the linguistic skills learned at intermediate levels.  It develops and increases the capacity for comprehension and oral expression in the language.  Focus is on practice of certain syntactic structures and idiomatic expressions, and on acquisition of new vocabulary.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Advanced Spanish Composition
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Course emphasizes writing at an advanced level, with a certain degree of sophistication about varied subjects and using different techniques of composition.  Classwork consists mainly of the discussion of both the ideas and techniques used in different textual forms.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Conversational Spanish Practice
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Study Abroad Conversational Spanish course for students who have already completed SPAN 3150, but want more practice.  Does not count for majors/minors.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Commercial Spanish
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Business terminology and forms. Translate and compose business letters and documents for advertising and promotion, trade and commerce, imports and exports, money and banking.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to Hispanic Literature I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Selected prose fiction and nonfiction prose of Spain and Spanish America.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to Hispanic Literature I - Writing Intensive
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Selected prose fiction and nonfiction prose of Spain and Spanish America.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to Hispanic Literature II
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Selected plays and poetry of Spain and Spanish America.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to Hispanic Literature II - Honors
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: SPAN 3160 or equivalent.  Honors eligibility required
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Selected plays and poetry of Spain and Spanish America.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Introduction to Hispanic Literature II - Writing Intensive
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Selected plays and poetry of Spain and Spanish America.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Survey of Minority and Creole Languages of the U.S. and the Caribbean
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as FRENCH 3710 and LINGST 3710). Analysis of the state of the minority languages of the U.S. and the Creole languages of the Caribbean with particular attention to the social status of these languages and speakers' attitudes toward them in the context of ethnic, culture and national identity (taught in Eng.).

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Spanish Phonetics
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as LINGST 3721). Introductory course to the study of Spanish phonological, phonetic and spelling systems, practice of pronunciation, phonetic transcriptions, and introduction to the variation of Spanish pronunciation in the Hispanic world.  The course is conducted in Spanish.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Twenty-First Century South American Cinema
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as FILMS_VS 3885, PORT 3885). Broad overview of the major national cinemas of the 21st century in South America. Approximately 14 feature films screened from Argentina, Brazil, Chile and other nations of the region. Instructor provides a thematic framework for films within the context of film theory, Latin American cinematic history and cultural studies. Course taught in English. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Intensive Beginning Spanish
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Designed for rapid acquisition of a reading knowledge of Spanish. Cannot be taken to fulfill undergraduate language requirement.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Foreign Language Teaching Methodology
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as FRENCH 4120, LATIN 4121; cross-leveled with FRENCH 7120, SPAN 7120). Theory and techniques of current foreign language methodology and their application in the classroom. Presentation of instructional projects, classroom observations, and strategies for classroom management. May not be used towards Arts and Science major.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Golden Age Poetry
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with SPAN 7420).  Poetry of the principal Spanish poets of the 16th and 17th centuries and of literary criticism devoted to it.  Special emphasis is placed on the works of Garcilaso de la Vega, Fray Luis de Leon, among others.  Short papers and explications are generally required.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Spanish Theatre in the Golden Age
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with SPAN 7422).  Dramatists to be studied include Lope de Vega, Calderon, Ruiz de Alarcon, Tirso de Molina, Guillen de Castro, Velez de Guevara, and some of Cervantes' theatre.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Don Quijote
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with SPAN 7423).  In this course students read the two parts of Don Quijote in the original Spanish.  Analysis and class discussion highlight elements of literary interest.  Neo-positivist methodology, factual background, formalist considerations and psychoanalytic approaches are used in this course.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Advanced Contemporary Culture of Spanish America
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with SPAN 7460). A study of Spanish-American culture and civilization through selected readings in history and literature, and the use of visual media. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Advanced Spanish Civilization
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with SPAN 7461). A survey of Spanish culture and Spanish history from the Middle Ages to the present with special emphasis on contemporary culture. Students will be provided with knowledge of chronology, geography and contemporary issues from readings of journals, novels and Internet news.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Survey of Spanish American Literature I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with SPAN 7470).  This is an introductory course in Spanish American literature. The reading material in prose and verse is studied in chronological order from the early 16th to the early 20th century.  Readings include selections from 22 major Spanish American authors.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Survey of Spanish American Literature II
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with SPAN 7471).  Survey of contemporary Latin American literature from approximately 1910 to the present.  Close analysis and reading of representative major texts of Latin American literature.  Students read complete selections and short excerpts from a standard anthology, and three complete novels.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Mexican Literature
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with SPAN 7480).  Analysis of selected poetry, prose, and drama of contemporary Mexico.  Course examines the writings of major and minor figures from several critical perspectives.  Works by Agustin, Aviles, Fabila, Carballido, Castellanos, Fuentes, Paz, and others are read.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Hispanic Oral Traditions
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with SPAN 7490). This course proposes to examine the Hispanic Oral Tradition through a study of romances and related genres, the corrido, decima and folktale.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: The Spanish American Theatre
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with SPAN 7530).  Intended as an overview of a vital genre in contemporary Spanish American studies, this survey introduces dramatists whose works are the focus of increasing attention from international specialists.  The works of Emilio Carballido, Egon Wolff, Griselda Gambaro and Osvald Dragun, among others are discussed.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Afro-Hispanic Literature
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with SPAN 7540).  A study of prose, poetry, and drama, in Spanish, written by authors of African descent in the Americas.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: History of the Spanish Language
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Completion with a passing grade of any Linguistics course at the 3000 level or above or instructor's consentRecommended: SPAN 3420 and SPAN 3430
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as LINGST 4711; cross-leveled with SPAN 7711).  ). Diachronic analysis of phonological, morphological, and syntactical systems of Spanish, from Vulgar Latin to contemporary dialects.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Structure of Modern Spanish
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as LINGST 4721;  cross-leveled with SPAN 7721). Synchronic analysis of phonology, morphology and syntax of spoken Spanish dialects.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Spanish Across the Continents
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as LINGST 4722; cross-leveled with SPAN 7722).  This course focuses on the effects of migratory movements on language change, considering the Spanish spoken in Latin America, Puerto Rico, Spain and the USA.  The class sharpens awareness and recognition of the linguistic diversity of the Spanish-speaking regions of the world.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Spanish Across the Continents - Writing Intensive
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as LINGST 4722; cross-leveled with SPAN 7722).  This course focuses on the effects of migratory movements on language change, considering the Spanish spoken in Latin America, Puerto Rico, Spain and the USA.  The class sharpens awareness and recognition of the linguistic diversity of the Spanish-speaking regions of the world.  Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Special Themes in Spanish
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: Subject varies according to instructor.  May be repeated for credit.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Capstone in Latinx Literature - Writing Intensive
Golden Age Poetry
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with SPAN 4420).  Poetry of the principal Spanish poets of the 16th and 17th centuries and of literary criticism devoted to it.  Special emphasis is placed on the works of Garcilaso de la Vega, Fray Luis de Leon, among others.  Short papers and explications are generally required.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Spanish Theatre in the Golden Age
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with SPAN 4422).  Dramatists to be studied include Lope de Vega, Calderon, Ruiz de Alarcon, Tirso de Molina, Guillen de Castro, Velez de Guevara, and some of Cervantes' theatre.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Don Quijote
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with SPAN 4423).  In this course students read the two parts of Don Quijote in the original Spanish.  Analysis and class discussion highlight elements of literary interest.  Neo-positivist methodology, factual background, formalist considerations and psychoanalytic approaches are used in this course.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Advanced Contemporary Culture of Spanish America
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with SPAN 4460). A study of Spanish-American culture and civilization through selected readings in history and literature, and the use of visual media. Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Advanced Spanish Civilization
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with SPAN 4461). A survey of Spanish culture and Spanish history from the Middle Ages to the present with special emphasis on contemporary culture. Students will be provided with knowledge of chronology, geography and contemporary issues from readings of journals, novels and Internet news.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Survey of Spanish American Literature I
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with SPAN 4470).  This is a course in Spanish American literature. The reading material in prose and verse is studied in chronological order from the early 16th to the early 20th century.  Readings include selections from 22 major Spanish American authors.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Survey of Spanish American Literature II
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with SPAN 4471).  Survey of contemporary Latin American literature from approximately 1910 to the present.  Close analysis and reading of representative major texts of Latin American literature.  Students read complete selections and short excerpts from a standard anthology, and three complete novels.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Mexican Literature
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with SPAN 4480).  Analysis of selected poetry, prose, and drama of contemporary Mexico.  Course examines the writings of major and minor figures from several critical perspectives.  Works by Agustin, Aviles, Fabila, Carballido, Castellanos, Fuentes, Paz, and others are read.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Hispanic Oral Traditions
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with SPAN 4490). This course proposes to examine the Hispanic Oral Tradition through a study of romances and related genres, the corrido, decima and folktale.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: The Spanish American Theatre
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with SPAN 4530).  Intended as an overview of a vital genre in contemporary Spanish American studies, this survey introduces dramatists whose works are the focus of increasing attention from international specialists.  The works of Emilio Carballido, Egon Wolff, Griselda Gambaro and Osvald Dragun, among others are discussed.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Afro-Hispanic Literature
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with SPAN 4540). A study of prose, poetry, and drama, in Spanish, written by authors of African descent in the Americas.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: History of the Spanish Language
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.prerequisites: Completion with a passing grade of any Linguistics course at the 3000 level or above or instructor's consent
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as LINGST 7711; cross-leveled with SPAN 4711, LINGST 4711). Diachronic analysis of phonology, morphology, and syntax from Vulgar Latin to modern period.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Structure of Modern Spanish
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (same as LINGST 7721; cross-leveled with LINGST 4721, SPAN 4721). Synchronic analysis of phonology, morphology and syntax of spoken Spanish dialects.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Spanish Across the Continents
https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.description: (cross-leveled with LINGST 4722, SPAN 4722).  This course focuses on the effects of migratory movements on language change, considering the Spanish spoken in Latin America, Puerto Rico, Spain and the USA.  The class sharpens awareness and recognition of the linguistic diversity of the Spanish-speaking regions of the world.   Graded on A-F basis only.

https://catalog.missouri.edu/courseoffer.title: Studies in Spanish Literature of the Medieval Period
Studies in Spanish Literature in the Golden Age
Studies in Colonial Spanish American Literature
Old Spanish--Phonology, Morphology and Syntax
